Name: Abraham Lincoln Birthplace National Historical Park
Description: Located in rural central Kentucky near Hodgenville, Abraham Lincoln Birthplace National Historical Park preserves the place where the 16th president of the United States was born and State Parkent his earliest years. The park centers on the Sinking State Parkring Farm, the Birthplace Cabin Site, and surrounding woodlands and fields, with a visitor center and commemorative grounds that reflect Lincoln’s boyhood landscape. Wildlife includes white-tailed deer, wild turkeys, and a variety of songbirds.

Name: Acadia National Park
Description: This coastal park in Maine State Parkans most of Mount Desert Island and nearby islands. It features Cadillac Mountain, the tallest peak on the Atlantic coast, rugged granite coastline, and extensive woodlands and lakes. A mosaic of habitats—freshwater ponds, estuaries, intertidal zones, and forest—supports peregrine falcons, harbor seals, white-tailed deer, and a rich array of seabirds.

Name: Adams National Historical Park
Description: Two birthplaces of American presidents and the Adams family home anchor Adams National Historical Park in Quincy, Massachusetts. The John Adams Birthplace (the Old House) and the John Quincy Adams Birthplace reveal 18th‑century life and the roots of American leadership, while Peacefield—the Adams family home—encloses the later 18th–19th‑century rooms and the Stone Library. Visitors experience period rooms, historic artifacts, and the landscapes that connected two generations of the Adams family to the nation’s founding.

Name: African American Civil War Memorial
Description: Located along the National Mall in Washington, D.C., the African American Civil War Memorial National Monument honors the service and sacrifices of African American soldiers and sailors who fought for the Union during the Civil War. The site features a prominent sculpture and a granite wall engraved with the names of those who served, set within a tranquil plaza that invites reflection and connects visitors with nearby museums and monuments in the National Mall and Memorial Parks.

Name: African Burial Ground National Monument
Description: This urban site in lower Manhattan preserves the burial grounds of enslaved Africans from the 17th and 18th centuries. A granite memorial and nearby interpretive exhibits tell the stories of resilience, labor, and community in colonial New York. Visitors can reflect at the memorial, join ranger-guided programs, and learn how this hidden history helped shape the city.

Name: Agate Fossil Beds National Monument
Description: This northwestern Nebraska landscape preserves fossil beds from the Oligocene epoch, set in rugged badlands and rolling prairie where bone beds and agatized layers reveal the lives of ancient mammals. Interpretive trails and a visitor center offer insights into paleontology and the region's fossil-rich past.

Name: Ala Kahakai National Trail
Description: This living corridor follows Hawaii’s ancient coastal routes along the islands’ shores, preserving a network of trails, villages, heiau, and fiState Historic Parkonds that once bound island communities. Lava fields, sea cliffs, beaches, and coral reefs frame the coastline, where wildlife such as Hawaiian monk seals, green sea turtles, and seasonal humpback whales can be observed.

Name: Alagnak Wild National River
Description: This remote Alaska river corridor protects the Alagnak Wild River, winding through boreal forest, tundra, and braided channels toward Bristol Bay. It preserves a rugged wilderness landscape with salmon-State Parkawning rivers and expansive floodplains. Wildlife includes brown bears, moose, caribou, eagles, and abundant salmon.

Name: Alaska Public Lands
Description: State Parkanning some of the largest and most remote protected areas in the United States, Alaska’s public lands preserve vast wilderness shaped by glaciers, towering mountains, tundra, rivers, and rugged coastline. These lands offer opportunities for mountaineering, backcountry hiking, rafting, flightseeing, and wildlife viewing in largely undeveloped settings. Ecosystems range from boreal forest and alpine tundra to coastal fjords and marine waters. Wildlife commonly includes grizzly and black bears, moose, caribou, wolves, Dall sheep, bald eagles, marine mammals, and abundant salmon, reflecting one of the most intact and ecologically diverse landscapes in North America.

Name: Alcatraz Island
Description: This storied island in San Francisco Bay preserves a world-famous former federal prison and a historic lighthouse, set against dramatic bay views and the city skyline. Accessible by ferry, Alcatraz offers cellhouse tours, preserved buildings, gardens, and interpretive trails that tell its layered history. Wildlife includes harbor seals that haul out on the rocky shores and a thriving seabird colony with western gulls, cormorants, and seasonal migratory birds.

Name: Aleutian Islands World War II National Historic Area
Description: The Aleutian Islands World War II National Historic Area State Parkans the remote Aleutian chain in Alaska, where the United States and Japan fought in the 1942–1943 campaign. It preserves battlefield remnants—fortifications, airfields, radar stations, trenches, and shipwrecks—set amid rugged volcanic islands, cold seas, and windswept coastlines. Wildlife includes seabirds, sea otters, seals, and whales, while communities on Unalaska (Dutch Harbor), Adak, and Attu offer a window into wartime life on this harsh, State Parkectacular frontier.

Name: Alibates Flint Quarries National Monument
Description: Along the arid plains of the Texas Panhandle, Alibates Flint Quarries National Monument preserves a dramatic landscape of white badlands and multi-hued limestone ridges along the Canadian River. For thousands of years, Indigenous peoples quarried the Alibates chert here to make tools and weapons, leaving behind quarry pits and ancient campsites that reveal a deep, enduring history. The rugged scenery supports a range of wildlife, including pronghorn antelope, mule deer, coyotes, bobcats, prairie dogs, rattlesnakes, and numerous birds of prey and songbirds. Hiking and backcountry exploring let visitors connect with both the striking geology and the cultural past of this remarkable High Plains landscape.

Name: Allegheny Portage Railroad National Historic Site
Description: This historic corridor in central Pennsylvania preserves the 1830s Allegheny Portage Railroad, a pivotal link between the eastern Main Line Canal and the west by climbing the Allegheny Front with a series of inclined planes. Visitors can see remnants of engine houses, cable systems, and miles of canal-era landscape that tell the story of early American engineering.

Name: Amache National Historic Site
Description: Amache National Historic Site sits on the high plains of southeast Colorado near Granada and preserves the Granada War Relocation Center (Amache), one of the wartime Japanese American confinement sites. The site interprets the camp’s history through remnants of barracks foundations, guard towers, and administrative areas, with trails and a visitor center that tell the stories of internees and the policy decisions behind relocation. The surrounding prairie and sagebrush habitats support pronghorn, mule deer, coyotes, and a variety of raptors, framing a powerful chapter of American history with stark, open landscapes.

Name: American Memorial Park
Description: American Memorial Park sits on Saipan in the Northern Mariana Islands, a coastal park commemorating U.S. service members who fought in the Pacific during World War II. The park features memorials, a cemetery, and a museum dedicated to the war, with scenic ocean views and interpretive diState Parklays along park trails. Coastal habitats include beaches, coral reefs, and mangrove-lined shores, supporting seabirds, sea turtles, and tropical marine life.

Name: Amistad National Recreation Area
Description: This scenic region along the Rio Grande in southwest Texas encompasses Amistad National Recreation Area, protecting the Amistad Reservoir and rugged limestone canyons. Boating, fishing, camping, scenic drives, and backcountry hiking reveal desert landscapes, canyon overlooks, and shoreline coves. Wildlife includes white-tailed deer, mule deer, javelina, and a variety of birds and fish.

Name: Anacostia Park
Description: This urban park system along the Anacostia River in Washington, D.C., comprises several connected units that protect riverfront wetlands, riparian woodlands, and Civil War–era fortifications. The trails and river overlooks offer opportunities for biking, hiking, birding, and kayaking, while interpretive programs highlight local history, ecology, and community stewardship. - Anacostia Park

Name: Andersonville National Historic Site
Description: This region in southwestern Georgia preserves the site of a Civil War prisoner-of-war camp and the National Cemetery. It features the prison ruins, the cemetery monuments, and the National Prisoner of War Museum with interpretive exhibits. The landscape includes pine and hardwood forests with wetlands and open fields, and wildlife such as white-tailed deer, wild turkeys, foxes, and a variety of birds.

Name: Andrew Johnson National Historic Site
Description: This region that shaped a president consists of Andrew Johnson National Historic Site in Greeneville, Tennessee. Two units preserve Johnson’s 19th-century home and the accompanying tailor shop, as well as the nearby National Cemetery where he is buried. The setting blends a quiet East Tennessee town with surrounding farmland and woodlands, and visitors can tour furnished rooms, restored outbuildings, and the grounds to glimpse life in Johnson’s era, with ranger-guided programs and self-guided tours available.

Name: Aniakchak National Monument & Preserve
Description: This remote Alaska landscape sits on the windswept Alaska Peninsula along the Pacific coast. It centers on Aniakchak Crater, a colossal volcanic caldera ringed by sheer cliffs, lava fields, and a windswept lake, with rugged coastline and black-sand beaches. Wildlife includes brown bears, caribou, and wolves, plus abundant seabirds and marine mammals along the coast.

Name: Antietam National Military Park
Description: Antietam National Military Park preserves the battlefield of the 1862 Antietam Campaign, a landscape of rolling farmland, woodland pockets, and Antietam Creek near SharpState Beachurg, Maryland. The park highlights landmark sites such as Burnside’s Bridge, the Sunken Road (Bloody Lane), and the Dunker Church, along with the Pry House Field HoState Parkital Museum and the Antietam National Cemetery. Visitors can walk battlefield trails, drive scenic loops, and join ranger-led programs that tell the tactics, sacrifices, and human stories of the Civil War’s bloodiest single-day combat.

Name: Apostle Islands National Lakeshore
Description: The Apostle Islands National Lakeshore State Parkans 21 islands and miles of mainland shoreline along Lake Superior in Wisconsin. It features sea caves carved in sandstone cliffs, rugged shoreline, historic lighthouses, beaches, and opportunities for kayaking, camping, and backcountry hiking. Wildlife includes bald eagles, loons, waterfowl, and a variety of seabirds.

Name: Appalachian National Trail
Description: Stretching more than 2,000 miles from Georgia to Maine, the Appalachian National Scenic Trail follows the crest of the Appalachian Mountains through some of the oldest landscapes in North America. The trail traverses a mosaic of national parks, forests, and public lands, offering continuous backcountry hiking, primitive shelters, and scenic overlooks. Environments range from southern hardwood forests and rolling ridgelines to high-elevation balds and rugged northern peaks. The corridor supports diverse wildlife, including black bears, white-tailed deer, wild turkeys, salamanders, and hundreds of bird State Parkecies, making it one of the most biologically rich long-distance trails in the world.

Name: Appomattox Court House National Historical Park
Description: This Virginia landscape preserves the site where the Civil War effectively ended with Confederate General Robert E. Lee’s surrender to General Ulysses S. Grant in 1865. Appomattox Court House National Historical Park centers on the village around the courthouse, the McLean House, and the surrounding countryside that together tell the story of a rural 19th‑century town and the surrender that shaped a nation. Historic buildings, quiet lanes, and interpretive trails invite visitors to step back in time and reflect on the war’s final days.

Name: Arches National Park
Description: This red-rock country near Moab, Utah, is a national park famed for more than 2,000 natural sandstone arches, dramatic fins, and towering balanced rocks set amid sweeping canyons. Beyond iconic Delicate Arch and the Devils Garden area, visitors enjoy scenic drives, backcountry hiking, and opportunities for rock climbing and stargazing. Wildlife includes desert bighorn sheep, mule deer, and peregrine falcons, along with a variety of desert-dwelling birds and small mammals.

Name: Arkansas Post National Memorial
Description: This memorial preserves the Civil War battlefield at the confluence of the Arkansas and Mississippi Rivers, where history unfolds amid river-bottom hardwood forests and wetlands. The landscape includes bottomland forests, wetlands, and riparian habitats that support waterfowl, wading birds, and other riverine wildlife.

Name: Arlington House, The Robert E. Lee Memorial
Description: This hilltop memorial sits within Arlington National Cemetery, preserving Arlington House, the Robert E. Lee family home. The site features restored 19th-century rooms, period furnishings, and surrounding grounds that interpret Civil War history and the Lee family's legacy. From its lawn, visitors can enjoy quiet reflection and views of the Potomac River and the Washington, D.C. skyline.

Name: Assateague Island National Seashore
Description: This Atlantic coast barrier island along the Maryland–Virginia border preserves a dynamic seashore ecosystem. Assateague Island National Seashore features beaches, shifting dunes, salt marshes, maritime forests, and tidal flats that support a wide variety of life and backcountry exploration. Wildlife includes the famous wild horses (the Chincoteague ponies), white-tailed deer, foxes, shorebirds, and nesting sea turtles.

Name: Aztec Ruins National Monument
Description: Along the Animas River in northwestern New Mexico, Aztec Ruins National Monument preserves a 900-year-old ancestral Puebloan great house and an interconnected village complex, including a reconstructed great kiva and numerous rooms. The surrounding landscape blends desert scrub with piñon-juniper woodlands and riparian cottonwood-willow habitats along the river. Wildlife includes mule deer, coyotes, jackrabbits, and a variety of birds and reptiles.

Name: Badlands National Park
Description: Wind-worn badlands of southwestern South Dakota reveal layered cliffs, State Parkires, and canyons carved from ancient seas. The park protects one of the world’s richest fossil beds, State Parkanning millions of years of prehistoric life. Scenic drives and backcountry trails traverse sculpted landscapes where wildlife such as American bison, pronghorn, bighorn sheep, and prairie dogs roam.

Name: Baltimore-Washington Parkway
Description: The Baltimore-Washington Parkway is a scenic corridor linking two national capitals along a tree-lined route through urban parks, river valleys, and suburban woodlands. In addition to its role as a highway, the area features scenic pull-offs, adjacent parklands with trails and historic sites, and a sense of mid-Atlantic landscape history. Wildlife includes white-tailed deer, red-tailed hawks, foxes, and a variety of migratory birds that seasonally inhabit the corridor's greenways.

Name: Bandelier National Monument
Description: This monument preserves a canyon-and-plateau landscape on the Pajarito Plateau in north-central New Mexico. It protects cliff dwellings and pueblos built by Ancestral Puebloans along Frijoles Canyon, including Tyuonyi, Alcove House, and Painted Cave, with thousands of archaeological sites and rock art. Ponderosa pine forests and piñon-juniper woodlands border rugged canyons and mesas, and backcountry trails access remote ruins and scenic overlooks. Wildlife includes mule deer, coyotes, and a wide variety of birds.

Name: Belmont-Paul Women's Equality National Monument
Description: This urban monument on Capitol Hill in Washington, D.C. preserves the Belmont-Paul Women's Equality National Monument—the historic Belmont Mansion and longtime headquarters of the National Woman's Party. Historic rooms, meeting State Parkaces, and archival collections tell the story of the women's suffrage movement, civil rights advocacy, and the ongoing pursuit of gender equality.

Name: Bent's Old Fort National Historic Site
Description: Bent's Old Fort National Historic Site sits along the Arkansas River in southeastern Colorado, preserving an authentic 1840s adobe fort that once served as a bustling Santa Fe Trail trading post. The reconstructed walls and interiors tell the story of frontier commerce and cross‑cultural exchange among American traders, Mexican merchants, and Ute, Apache, and Comanche peoples. Today the site offers guided tours and living-history demonstrations that recreate daily life, trade, and hoState Parkitality at a mid‑19th‑century fort, with period gardens and interpretive exhibits that bring the frontier to life.

Name: Bering Land Bridge National Preserve
Description: Located in remote northwest Alaska along the Bering Sea coast, Bering Land Bridge National Preserve preserves the remnants of the ancient land bridge that connected Asia and North America. The windswept tundra, permafrost-rich uplands, and rugged coastal bluffs frame a stark, expansive landscape that records glacial and sea-level history. Wildlife includes caribou, muskoxen, Arctic foxes, wolves, and a variety of migratory birds along tidal flats and shores. Access is primarily by small plane or boat, inviting visitors to experience one of the most remote, solitary places in the National Park System.

Name: Big Bend National Park
Description: This vast park protects desert, canyon, and river ecosystems along the Rio Grande in far western Texas, offering scenic drives and backcountry hiking opportunities. In the Chisos Mountains, forests and high-country habitats meet dramatic canyons such as Santa Elena and Boquillas that carve through the rock. The Rio Grande forms the border with Mexico, while wildlife such as mule deer, javelina, coyotes, and more than 450 State Parkecies of birds thrive in the park.

Name: Big Cypress National Preserve
Description: This expansive wilderness in southern Florida preserves a mosaic of cypress swamps, hardwood hammocks, pine flatwoods, and sawgrass prairies that link the Everglades with the coast. Scenic drives, backcountry hiking, and camping opportunities let visitors experience wild wetlands and remote backcountry. Wildlife includes American alligators, Florida panthers, black bears, white-tailed deer, bobcats, and hundreds of bird State Parkecies.

Name: Big Hole National Military Park
Description: Big Hole National Battlefield (also known as Big Hole National Military Park) preserves the site of the 1877 Nez Perce War clash along the Big Hole River in southwestern Montana. The landscape includes riparian river corridors, sagebrush prairies, and pine-covered hills with interpretive trails and a visitor center, and wildlife includes mule deer, pronghorn, bighorn sheep, and a variety of birds.

Name: Big South Fork National River & Recreation Area
Description: Big South Fork National River and Recreation Area sits along the Big South Fork of the Cumberland River on the Tennessee–Kentucky border, featuring rugged canyons, sandstone cliffs, and preserved timber-era landscapes. In addition to scenic river trips, the area offers horseback riding, hiking, and backcountry camping, with historic cabins and trails reflecting the region's timber era. Wildlife includes white-tailed deer, wild turkeys, black bears, and bobcats.

Name: Big Thicket National Preserve
Description: Big Thicket National Preserve sits at the biological crossroads of Southeast Texas, protecting a mosaic of pine forests, cypress swamps, bayous, bogs, and bottomland hardwoods across several units. The preserve offers scenic drives, canoeing and kayaking, and backcountry hiking through a landscape where longleaf pines meet water and forest. Wildlife includes American alligators, white-tailed deer, bobcats, river otters, and a rich array of bird State Parkecies.

Name: Bighorn Canyon National Recreation Area
Description: This region State Parkans two units along the Bighorn River in southern Montana and northern Wyoming, protecting dramatic canyon walls and the blue waters of Bighorn Lake behind Yellowtail Dam. Scenic drives, boating, fishing, camping, and backcountry hiking opportunities await, while wildlife includes bighorn sheep, mule deer, elk, and bald eagles.

Name: Birmingham Civil Rights National Monument
Description: This district in downtown Birmingham preserves a walkable landscape of sites that propelled the modern civil rights movement. Core places include the 16th Street Baptist Church, Kelly Ingram Park, and the Birmingham Civil Rights Institute, with self-guided or ranger-led tours, living-history programs, and commemorative markers along the Civil Rights Heritage Trail. The area preserves the courage of activists, the power of peaceful protest, and the ongoing pursuit of racial equality in America.

Name: Biscayne National Park
Description: Located off the southern coast of Florida, Biscayne National Park protects a marine landscape of mangrove forests, seagrass beds, and coral reefs that State Parkan Biscayne Bay and the adjacent Florida Keys. Much of the park lies underwater, offering reefs, shipwrecks, and submerged archaeological sites, as well as mangrove keys and tidal channels. Wildlife includes American crocodiles, bottlenose dolphins, manatees, hawkState Beachill and green sea turtles, and a rich array of tropical fish and shorebirds.

Name: Black Canyon Of The Gunnison National Park
Description: This dramatic park in western Colorado protects one of the deepest, most dramatic canyons in North America, carved by the Gunnison River. Scenic drives and backcountry hiking opportunities along the rim offer sweeping views of towering, dark cliff faces. Wildlife includes mule deer, elk, and a variety of birds of prey, and the park’s star-filled night skies provide exceptional stargazing.

Name: Blackstone National River Valley National Historical Park
Description: This region along the Blackstone River Valley in Rhode Island and Massachusetts preserves the birthplace of the American Industrial Revolution. The park protects 18th- and 19th-century mills, canal infrastructure, and worker housing, with riverfront towns, heritage trails, and interpretive programs. Wildlife includes beavers, river otters, great blue herons, and a variety of waterfowl.

Name: Blackwell School National Historic Site
Description: This region centers on the Blackwell School National Historic Site, a late-19th-century schoolhouse that served generations of local families as a cornerstone of education and community life. The site features the restored school building, period classroom furnishings, and interpretive exhibits that tell the stories of students, teachers, and the neighborhood. Visitors can take guided tours and explore living-history programs that highlight education, perseverance, and the enduring role of schools in shaping opportunity.

Name: Blue Ridge Parkway
Description: Stretching 469 miles along the crest of the Blue Ridge, the Blue Ridge Parkway runs from Shenandoah National Park in Virginia to Great Smoky Mountains National Park in North Carolina. It winds through hardwood forests and high-elevation State Parkruce-fir habitats, offering scenic overlooks, waterfalls, and backcountry hiking while supporting wildlife such as black bears, white-tailed deer, wild turkeys, and peregrine falcons.

Name: Bluestone National Scenic National River
Description: This shaded river corridor in southern West Virginia preserves the Bluestone River as it winds through sandstone canyons and hardwood forests. Visitors enjoy scenic overlooks, backcountry hiking along the river, and opportunities for fishing, paddling, and picnicking in quiet, unState Parkoiled surroundings. Wildlife includes white-tailed deer, black bears, river otters, beavers, and a variety of birds such as bald eagles, oState Parkreys, and pileated woodpeckers.

Name: Booker T Washington National Monument
Description: This historic landscape preserves the birthplace and boyhood home of Booker T. Washington on a rural Virginia farm. A restored log cabin, a reconstructed one-room schoolhouse, and interpretive trails wind through fields and woodlands that shaped his early life. Wildlife includes white-tailed deer and a variety of songbirds, and exhibits highlight Washington's journey from slavery to education and leadership.

Name: Boston African American National Historic Site
Description: This historic site sits in Boston's Beacon Hill neighborhood and preserves a network of 15 historically significant locations along the Black Heritage Trail. The urban landscape features brick townhouses, cobblestone streets, churches, and schools, with guided tours and exhibits that illuminate abolition, education, and civil rights in African American history.

Name: Boston Harbor Islands National Recreation Area
Description: This urban-coastal landscape comprises a chain of more than 30 islands and peninsulas in Boston Harbor. From the ferries that depart from downtown Boston to the historic Fort Warren on Georges Island, visitors can explore beaches, marshes, lighthouses, and backcountry trails. Wildlife includes harbor seals, oState Parkreys, piping plovers, and a variety of migratory waterfowl.

Name: Boston National Historical Park
Description: This urban landscape in downtown Boston preserves three centuries of American history within Boston National Historical Park. It protects colonial and Revolutionary War landmarks—the Paul Revere House, Old North Church, Old State House, Faneuil Hall, and the Bunker Hill Monument—as well as the USS Constitution at the Charlestown Navy Yard. The area also features the Freedom Trail, harbor views, and living-history programs that bring the nation’s founding era to life.

Name: Brices Cross Roads National Military Park Site
Description: An historic Civil War battlefield in northern Mississippi that preserves the Brices Cross Roads engagement. The landscape of rolling farmland and timbered hills features markers and monuments that recount the clash between Confederate and Union forces and the Confederate victory that checked a Union advance.

Name: Brown v. Board of Education National Historical Park
Description: This region that helped redefine American civil rights centers on a compact urban historic district in Topeka, Kansas. The park preserves Monroe Elementary School and other linked sites where the Brown v. Board of Education case unfolded, with a visitor center and interpretive programs that recount the fight to end school segregation. The surrounding urban landscape—historic neighborhoods and river valleys—hosts guided tours, exhibits, and living-history programs that illuminate the people and decisions behind the landmark ruling.

Name: Bryce Canyon National Park
Description: Bryce Canyon National Park, in southern Utah, features a surreal landscape of multicolored hoodoo State Parkires rising from red-rock amphitheaters. Scenic drives along the rim and backcountry hiking opportunities among the hoodoos reveal dramatic vistas and night-sky views. Wildlife includes mule deer, pronghorn, bighorn sheep, and peregrine falcons.

Name: Buck Island Reef National Monument
Description: Buck Island Reef National Monument lies off the northeast coast of Saint Croix in the U.S. Virgin Islands, protecting Buck Island and its surrounding coral reef ecosystem. The area features a pristine crescent beach, mangrove-fringed shores, and a vibrant barrier reef with seagrass beds, offering superb snorkeling, kayaking, and guided reef tours. Wildlife includes hawkState Beachill and green sea turtles, a rainbow of reef fishes, and bottlenose dolphins, with seabirds nesting on Buck Island.

Name: Buffalo National River
Description: This wild river valley in the Ozark Mountains preserves a free-flowing stretch of the Buffalo River in north-central Arkansas. The landscape features towering limestone bluffs, secluded canyons such as Hemmed-In-Hollow, sandstone cliffs, and hardwood forests along winding water routes. Scenic drives, backcountry trails, canoeing, and camping opportunities are popular here. Wildlife includes white-tailed deer, wild turkeys, black bears, beavers, river otters, and a variety of birds.

Name: Butterfield Overland National Trail
Description: This historic corridor traces the Butterfield Overland National Trail from Missouri to California along the old Butterfield Overland Mail routes. From prairie plains to desert canyons and mountain passes, it preserves stage stations, emigrant camps, and travel routes with scenic byways and backcountry hiking opportunities where wildlife such as pronghorn, mule deer, coyotes, and roadrunners may be seen.

Name: Cabrillo National Monument
Description: This coastal promontory at the southern tip of Point Loma preserves Cabrillo National Monument. Besides the historic Old Point Loma Lighthouse and the statue of Juan Rodríguez Cabrillo, there are sweeping views of San Diego Bay, rugged sea cliffs, and accessible tide pools along scenic trails. Wildlife includes gray whales during migration, pelicans, and a variety of shorebirds.

Name: California National Trail
Description: Yosemite National Park State Parkans the heart of the Sierra Nevada, where granite cliffs rise above ancient sequoias, alpine meadows, and thundering waterfalls. Iconic features include El Capitan, Half Dome, and Yosemite Falls, with miles of scenic drives and backcountry trails weaving through pine forests, alpine meadows, and high-country lakes. Wildlife includes American black bears, mule deer, coyotes, mountain lions, and Sierra Nevada bighorn sheep, and habitats range from alpine and subalpine to riparian forests.

Name: Camp Nelson National Monument
Description: Camp Nelson National Monument preserves a Civil War–era Union Army camp and the Black soldiers’ community that formed around it, a pivotal site in emancipation and military history in central Kentucky. Rolling bluegrass fields, woodlands, and riparian streams frame historic structures and cemeteries, while wildlife includes white-tailed deer, wild turkeys, red-tailed hawks, and a variety of songbirds.

Name: Canaveral National Seashore
Description: Canaveral National Seashore stretches along Florida’s Atlantic coast, protecting a long barrier-island stretch with two units—Playalinda Beach in the north and Apollo Beach in the south. It features rolling dunes, maritime hammocks, coastal salt marshes, and miles of pristine beaches and tidal flats. Wildlife includes nesting sea turtles, dolphins, manatees, alligators, and a variety of shorebirds that rely on the seashore’s beaches and backcountry habitats.

Name: Cane National River Creole National Historical Park
Description: Two historic plantations along Cane River in north-central Louisiana—the Magnolia and Oakland units—make up Cane River Creole National Historical Park. The park preserves 19th-century plantation landscapes, including slave cabins, outbuildings, and Creole homes, to tell the stories of enslaved people, free people of color, and the communities that formed along the Cane River. The river valley’s fields, live oaks, and bayous provide the setting for these culturally rich landscapes that interpret daily life, labor, and resilience in this Creole cultural heartland.

Name: Canyon de Chelly National Monument
Description: Rugged ancestral canyon country in northeastern Arizona showcases towering red sandstone cliffs, sculpted mesas, and a living record of thousands of years of Ancestral Puebloan culture. The San Juan River winds through the canyon, with iconic formations such as State Parkider Rock and cliff dwellings like White House and Mummy Cave visible from overlooks and trails. Scenic drives along the rim and backcountry hiking provide access to the canyon’s archaeology, vistas, and wildlife, including mule deer, coyotes, and a variety of desert birds.

Name: Canyonlands National Park
Description: This vast desert region in southeastern Utah consists of three units—Island in the Sky, The Needles, and The Maze. Dramatic canyons carved by the Colorado and Green Rivers rise beside sweeping vistas from cliff-edge overlooks, offering scenic drives, backcountry hiking, and challenging canyoneering and 4x4 routes. Wildlife includes mule deer, desert bighorn sheep, coyotes, and rock squirrels, while ancient Puebloan rock art and ruins dot the canyon walls.

Name: Cape Cod National Seashore
Description: This coastal region along the Outer Cape preserves a 40-mile stretch of beaches, dunes, salt marshes, and kettle ponds. Cape Cod National Seashore features expansive Atlantic shoreline, maritime forests, and historic sites such as the Marconi Wireless Station. Wildlife includes gray seals, harbor seals, piping plovers, and a variety of shorebirds, with opportunities for scenic drives, backcountry hiking, birdwatching, and kayaking along tidal creeks.

Name: Cape Hatteras National Seashore
Description: Cape Hatteras National Seashore stretches along North Carolina’s Outer Banks and comprises three units—the Bodie Island Unit, the Hatteras Island Unit, and the Ocracoke Island Unit. In addition to historic lighthouses and lifesaving stations, the seashore protects miles of open beaches, dunes, salt marshes, and maritime forests, with scenic drives, backcountry hiking, and water-based recreation. Wildlife includes loggerhead and green sea turtles, shorebirds, pelicans, oState Parkreys, and bottlenose dolphins.

Name: Cape Henry Memorial
Description: This coastal memorial preserves the site where English colonists first landed at Cape Henry in 1607, marking the beginning of a lasting chapter in American history. The memorial sits on a windswept Atlantic shoreline near the Cape Henry Lighthouse, with interpretive diState Parklays that recount the voyage and early settlement. The surrounding maritime habitats—beaches, dunes, and tidal estuaries—support wildlife such as shorebirds, seabirds, and sea turtles.

Name: Cape Krusenstern National Monument
Description: Located along the Chukchi Sea in northwest Alaska, Cape Krusenstern National Monument preserves a coastline of ancient beach ridges, tidal lagoons, and expansive polygonal tundra. This Arctic landscape encompasses a mosaic of shorelines, wetlands, and upland habitats, as well as a rich tapestry of Indigenous cultural sites and travel routes. Wildlife includes caribou, wolves, bears, seals, shorebirds, and migratory waterfowl, with whales and other marine mammals offshore.

Name: Cape Lookout National Seashore
Description: Stretching along North Carolina's southern Outer Banks, Cape Lookout National Seashore protects a chain of barrier islands with pristine beaches, shifting dunes, tidal marshes, and maritime forests. The area features the historic Cape Lookout Lighthouse, backcountry hiking, and kayaking, fishing, and wildlife viewing opportunities. Wildlife includes Shackleford Banks' wild horses, nesting loggerhead and green sea turtles, dolphins, and a variety of shorebirds.

Name: Capitol Hill Parks
Description: Located in the historic Capitol Hill neighborhood of Washington, D.C., Capitol Hill Parks consists of several small urban parks, including Lincoln Park, Eastern Market Park, and Stanton Park. These green State Parkaces provide tree-lined lawns, walkways, and memorials within a dense residential and civic setting. The parks serve as neighborhood gathering places and reflect the city’s early planning and commemorative history. Wildlife is typical of an urban environment and includes songbirds, squirrels, and other small mammals adapted to city landscapes.

Name: Capitol Reef National Park
Description: This region in southern Utah protects a nearly 100-mile-long warp in the earth's crust known as the Waterpocket Fold, revealing dramatic red cliffs, narrow canyons, and sandstone arches across a stark desert landscape. Within the park, the Fruita Historic District offers historic orchards, a restored schoolhouse, and opportunities for scenic drives and backcountry hiking.

Name: Captain John Smith Chesapeake National Trail
Description: This waterway corridor traces Captain John Smith's 1607–1609 explorations along the Chesapeake Bay and its tidal rivers, linking historic ports, colonial sites, and living landscapes. The route features estuaries, salt marshes, barrier islands, and forested shores with opportunities for paddling, boating, and shoreline exploration. Wildlife includes bald eagles, oState Parkreys, river otters, bottlenose dolphins, and a variety of waterfowl.

Name: Capulin Volcano National Monument
Description: This volcanic landscape sits on the high plains of northeastern New Mexico, highlighted by Capulin Volcano, a well-preserved cinder cone formed by ancient eruptions. A paved road climbs to the crater rim and loops around the cone, with short interpretive trails through lava flows and sagebrush prairie offering sweeping views of the plains and distant mountains. Wildlife includes pronghorn, mule deer, coyotes, and a variety of raptors and ground-dwelling birds.

Name: Carl Sandburg Home National Historic Site
Description: Nestled in the Blue Ridge foothills near Flat Rock, Carl Sandburg Home National Historic Site preserves Lang Syne, the poet’s hillside home, and a working farm. The landscape blends woodlands, pastures, and orchards with historic outbuildings and trails that invite visitors to experience Sandburg’s life and writings. Wildlife includes white-tailed deer, wild turkeys, and a variety of songbirds.

Name: CarlState Beachad Caverns National Park
Description: Nestled in southeastern New Mexico, CarlState Beachad Caverns National Park protects a vast underground network of limestone caves. The centerpiece, CarlState Beachad Cavern, features the colossal Big Room and a labyrinth of chambers adorned with stalactites, stalagmites, and flowstones, explored via self-guided trails and ranger-led tours. Above ground, the Chihuahuan Desert supports creosote, ocotillo, yucca, and diverse wildlife, and at dusk a State Parkectacular colony of Mexican free-tailed bats emerges from the caverns.

Name: Carter G. Woodson Home National Historic Site
Description: This urban historic site preserves the home of Carter G. Woodson in the Shaw neighborhood of Washington, D.C. The two-story brick house maintains period rooms and exhibits that chronicle Woodson’s life as a historian and the origins of Black History Month; the surrounding neighborhood reflects a long-running African American cultural community and the capital’s civil rights heritage.

Name: Casa Grande Ruins National Monument
Description: Situated in the Sonoran Desert between Phoenix and Tucson, this monument preserves the Great House and other Hohokam ruins, with a visitor center, shaded trails, and interpretive signs set in a cactus-dotted landscape. Desert wildlife such as coyotes, javelinas, roadrunners, lizards, and a variety of birds share the arid environment with saguaros and creosote bushes.

Name: Castillo de San Marcos National Monument
Description: Castillo de San Marcos National Monument sits on the edge of St. Augustine, Florida, overlooking Matanzas Bay along the Atlantic coast. This 17th-century coquina fortress—the oldest masonry fort in the continental United States—features thick walls, bastions, and centuries of coastal defense, with the surrounding estuary and beaches offering scenic views and coastal habitats. Wildlife includes wading birds such as herons and egrets, oState Parkreys and pelicans, with dolphins in the bay and sea turtles along nearby beaches.

Name: Castle Clinton National Monument
Description: Castle Clinton National Monument sits at the southern tip of Manhattan in Battery Park, preserving a circular brick fort built to defend New York Harbor in the early 1800s. The site later became Castle Garden, New York’s first immigrant processing center, welcoming generations of arrivals to the United States. Today, visitors explore the fort’s circular bastions, view exhibits about naval defense and the city’s immigrant legacy, and enjoy waterfront views along New York Harbor with the city skyline as a backdrop. This compact urban park offers a focused glimpse into two pivotal chapters of American history—military fortification and immigration—within a busy New York City harbor setting.

Name: Castle Mountains National Monument
Description: Castle Mountains National Monument preserves a rugged desert landscape of castle-like rock State Parkires and stark canyons in the eastern Mojave. Beyond its dramatic geology, the area offers backcountry hiking and limited scenic drives through expansive desert scenery. Wildlife includes desert bighorn sheep, pronghorn, kit fox, coyotes, and golden eagles.

Name: Catoctin Mountain Park
Description: This forested corridor along the Catoctin Mountain range in Maryland protects rugged ridges, rocky outcrops, and forested ravines carved by streams. In addition to the area around the presidential retreat at Camp David, the park offers scenic drives and backcountry hiking along a network of trails. Wildlife includes white-tailed deer, black bears, bobcats, foxes, and a wide variety of birds, with streams and woods supporting diverse plant and animal life.

Name: Cedar Breaks National Monument
Description:
This high-elevation amphitheater carved from colorful cliffs sits on the Paunsaugunt Plateau near Cedar City, Utah, offering sweeping views and a cool mountain climate. 
The rim road provides scenic overlooks, and there are backcountry hikes through aState Parken groves and State Parkruce-fir forests amid meadow-filled landscapes that host wildflowers in season and a diversity of wildlife such as mule deer, elk, and many birds.

Name: Cedar Creek & Belle Grove National Historical Park
Description: This landscape in the northern Shenandoah Valley that shaped Civil War campaigns and rural life consists of two units: the Belle Grove National Historic Landmark near Middletown and the Cedar Creek Battlefield Unit near Cedar Creek. Besides Belle Grove’s 18th‑century mansion, there are scenic byways and backcountry hiking opportunities that reveal how people farmed, fought, and lived in this valley. Wildlife includes white-tailed deer, wild turkeys, red foxes, and a variety of songbirds.

Name: Chaco Culture National Historical Park
Description: Remote desert country in northwestern New Mexico preserves the monumental center of the Ancestral Puebloan world, with multi-story Great Houses rising from red sandstone canyons. An extensive network of kivas, ceremonial centers, and radiating roads reveals a sophisticated, widely connected culture. The landscape offers quiet backcountry ruin exploration and dramatic night skies ideal for stargazing.

Name: Chamizal National Memorial
Description: This urban cultural landscape along the Rio Grande marks the peaceful settlement of a long-running U.S.–Mexico border diState Parkute in El Paso, Texas, and Ciudad Juárez, Mexico. The site includes Chamizal National Memorial, a museum and plaza, an outdoor amphitheater, and tranquil park State Parkaces with pathways celebrating cross-border heritage. Wildlife includes riverine birds and other urban wildlife that thrive along the Rio Grande corridor.

Name: Channel Islands National Park
Description: This coastal archipelago off southern California comprises five islands—Santa Cruz, Santa Rosa, San Miguel, Anacapa, and Santa Catalina—and a surrounding marine sanctuary. Channel Islands National Park protects sea cliffs, sea caves, tidepools, kelp forests, and backcountry island habitats, with opportunities for hiking, kayaking, snorkeling, and wildlife viewing. Wildlife includes the Channel Island fox, island scrub jay, bald eagles, peregrine falcons, harbor seals, sea lions, and migrating gray whales and dolphins.

Name: Charles Pinckney National Historic Site
Description: This historic site preserves the home and plantation landscape of Charles Cotesworth Pinckney, a prominent South Carolina statesman and signer of the U.S. Constitution. The grounds include an 18th-century house, period outbuildings, and restored gardens that illustrate Pinckney family life and the Lowcountry plantation economy. The surrounding Lowcountry landscape—live oaks, marshes, and tidal creeks—frames guided and self-guided programs that explore Pinckney's political career and daily life in colonial South Carolina.

Name: Charles Young Buffalo Soldiers National Monument
Description: Charles Young Buffalo Soldiers National Monument preserves the home and gravesite of Col. Charles Young, a pioneering African American Army officer and leader of the Buffalo Soldiers. The site sits on a rural Ohio property with woodlands, open meadows, and a quiet landscape that reflects Young's life and service. Wildlife includes white-tailed deer, wild turkeys, red-tailed hawks, gray squirrels, and a variety of songbirds.

Name: Chattahoochee National River National Recreation Area
Description: This region along the northern Georgia section of the Chattahoochee River National Recreation Area State Parkans forested river valleys and the foothills of the Southern Appalachians. It features winding river corridors, cascading rapids, and scenic overlooks with ample hiking, paddling, and wildlife-watching opportunities. Wildlife includes white-tailed deer, black bears, river otters, wild turkeys, and a variety of hawks and songbirds.

Name: Chesapeake & Ohio Canal National Historical Park
Description: This historic corridor along the Potomac River preserves the Chesapeake and Ohio Canal’s towpath, locks, aqueducts, and the remnants of a 19th‑century tranState Parkortation network running from Georgetown to Cumberland. The park protects 184.5 miles of canal landscape, scenic river valleys, and historic lockhouses that tell the story of early American engineering. Visitors can bike or hike the towpath, explore museums and lock remains, and glimpse wildlife such as beavers, river otters, bald eagles, oState Parkreys, and white-tailed deer.

Name: Chesapeake Bay
Description: This region that enticed and influenced President George Washington consists of a park of three units along the Chesapeake Bay and its major tidal tributaries. Besides the bay’s historic towns, lighthouses, and scenic shoreline, there are scenic byways, marsh boardwalks, and backcountry kayaking and fishing opportunities. Wildlife includes bald eagles, oState Parkreys, river otters, and blue crabs.

Name: Chickamauga & Chattanooga National Military Park
Description: This region that commemorates a turning point in American history consists of two battlefield units State Parkanning the Georgia–Tennessee border. From Lookout Mountain and Missionary Ridge to the Chickamauga Battlefield, the park preserves trenches, monuments, and interpretive sites, with scenic drives and backcountry hiking opportunities. Wildlife includes white-tailed deer, wild turkeys, gray foxes, and a variety of songbirds.

Name: Chickasaw National Recreation Area
Description: This region in south-central Oklahoma State Parkans two units of Chickasaw National Recreation Area around Travertine Creek and the Lake of the Arbuckles, featuring limestone travertine formations, clear streams, and rolling forested hills. Besides scenic drives and backcountry hiking opportunities, the area offers fishing, swimming, boating, and camping amid diverse habitats. Wildlife includes white-tailed deer, raccoons, beavers, wild turkeys, and a variety of birds.

Name: Chiricahua National Monument
Description: Located in the southeastern corner of Arizona, Chiricahua National Monument protects a dramatic landscape of towering volcanic-tuff hoodoos in the Chiricahua Mountains, a centerpiece of the Madrean Sky Islands. The area features scenic overlooks and trails through pine-oak woodlands, offering day hikes and backcountry exploration among the rock gardens. Wildlife includes mule deer, javelina, mountain lions, and a wide variety of birds.

Name: Christiansted National Historic Site
Description: On Saint Croix in the U.S. Virgin Islands, Christiansted National Historic Site preserves four 18th- and 19th-century Danish colonial buildings along the town’s waterfront. Fort Christiansvaern anchors the site, complemented by the Danish Governor’s Mansion, the Old Court House, and the Protestant Church. The district features brick-and-stone façades, bastions, and brick sidewalks that reflect the island’s colonial government, commerce, and everyday life. The area is also home to tropical wildlife such as seabirds, green iguanas, and sea turtles.

Name: City Of Rocks National Reserve
Description: In southern Idaho near Almo, City Of Rocks National Reserve protects a dramatic granite landscape of towering State Parkires, domes, and canyons set in sagebrush desert and pine woodland. The area offers scenic drives, backcountry hiking, and world-class rock climbing, with historic emigrant routes that helped shape westward travel. Wildlife includes pronghorn antelope, mule deer, bighorn sheep, coyotes, and golden eagles, and habitats range from sagebrush steppe to pinyon-juniper woodlands and riparian pockets along streams.

Name: Civil War Defenses of Washington
Description: Around the nation’s capital, the Civil War Defenses of Washington preserve a ring of forts, trenches, and batteries that protected Washington, D.C., during the Civil War. The network winds along river valleys and wooded hills around the city, with historic earthworks and interpretive signs that reveal Civil War defense planning and life on the home front.

Name: Clara Barton National Historic Site
Description: Located along the Potomac River in suburban Maryland, Clara Barton National Historic Site preserves the home and surroundings where Barton lived, worked, and helped shape humanitarian relief efforts that culminated in the American Red Cross. The site features preserved rooms with period furnishings and exhibits, plus tranquil grounds and river views that evoke Barton's daily life and enduring legacy.

Name: Colonial National Historical Park
Description: This region links three historic units along the Colonial Parkway—Historic Jamestowne, Colonial WilliamState Beachurg, and the Yorktown Battlefield—preserving the birth and growth of the United States. Jamestowne preserves the site of the first permanent English settlement and its archaeological remains, WilliamState Beachurg offers restored 18th‑century streets and crafts, and Yorktown Battlefield commemorates the decisive Revolutionary War victory. The area features museums, living-history programs, and ranger-guided experiences.

Name: Colorado National Monument
Description: Colorado National Monument sits along the western edge of the state where dramatic red sandstone cliffs tower over deep canyons and the Colorado River valley. Rim Rock Drive threads through the park, offering sweeping overlooks and access to backcountry hiking amid towering walls and State Parkires. The landscape ranges from piñon-juniper woodlands to desert scrub and riparian cottonwood corridors along seasonal streams.

Name: Coltsville National Historical Park
Description: This urban-industrial landscape preserves the Colt legacy in Hartford, State Parkanning three units in the Coltsville district. Along with the historic Colt Armory and surrounding factory complex, visitors can explore restored mills, riverfront trails, and interpretive programs that illuminate 19th-century manufacturing, innovation, and labor history. The area protects period architecture, factories, and archival materials that tell the story of industrial capitalism and American ingenuity.

Name: Congaree National Park
Description: Congaree National Park sits in central South Carolina along the Congaree River floodplain as a single-unit park that protects one of the largest intact old-growth bottomland hardwood forests in the United States. Towering oaks, tulip poplars, water tupelo, and bald cypress rise above slow, winding creeks and wetlands that define the ancient floodplain. Boardwalks traverse the towering forest, while backcountry hiking and paddling opportunities let visitors explore the river corridors and floodplain from different perState Parkectives. Wildlife includes white-tailed deer, river otters, bobcats, and hundreds of bird State Parkecies that seasonally migrate through this lush, water-rich landscape.

Name: Constitution Gardens
Description: Constitution Gardens is an urban oasis along the National Mall, featuring a pair of tranquil ponds linked by stone bridges and framed by lawns, trees, and seasonal plantings. Shaded paths and benches provide a peaceful setting just steps from the nation’s monuments. Wildlife includes ducks and geese on the water, dragonflies and butterflies among the plantings, and a chorus of songbirds in the trees.

Name: Coronado National Memorial
Description: This borderland desert landscape along the U.S.–Mexico line preserves Sonoran Desert canyons, cactus-studded washes, and foothill forests that rise into rugged mountains. Scenic drives and backcountry hiking reveal traces of Coronado’s 16th‑century expedition, while wildlife includes desert bighorn sheep, javelina, mule deer, and a variety of raptors and songbirds.

Name: Cowpens National Military Park
Description: In the Upstate region of South Carolina, Cowpens National Military Park preserves the battlefield landscape of the 1781 battle that helped turn the tide of the American Revolutionary War. It features rolling pastures, woodlands, and streams with interpretive trails and a visitor center that tell the story of the engagement. Wildlife includes white-tailed deer, wild turkeys, raccoons, and red-tailed hawks.

Name: Crater Lake National Park
Description: Crater Lake National Park sits in southern Oregon, preserving a volcanic caldera formed by the collapse of Mount Mazama about 7,700 years ago. The centerpiece, Crater Lake, is the deepest lake in the United States, famed for its vivid blue water and remarkable clarity. Rim Drive circles the caldera with sweeping overlooks, boat tours reach Wizard Island for hiking and exploration, and backcountry trails invite longer treks. Wildlife includes mule deer, black bears, mountain lions, and a variety of birds.

Name: Craters Of The Moon National Monument & Preserve
Description: This region in central Idaho preserves a stark volcanic landscape shaped by lava flows, cinder cones, and lava tubes. Craters of the Moon National Monument and Preserve features expansive lava fields with scenic drives and backcountry hiking, and supports wildlife such as pronghorn, mule deer, elk, and coyotes among sagebrush and pine habitats.

Name: Cumberland Gap National Historical Park
Description: State Parkanning Kentucky, Tennessee, and Virginia, Cumberland Gap National Historical Park protects the Cumberland Gap—the historic pass through the Appalachian Mountains that opened the western frontier. The landscape includes forested ridges, streams, and cultural landscapes along the Wilderness Road corridor, with historic trails, pioneer-era structures, and scenic overlooks to explore. Wildlife includes white-tailed deer, wild turkey, black bear, and fox.

Name: Cumberland Island National Seashore
Description: This barrier island sanctuary off Georgia's coast comprises miles of unState Parkoiled beaches, salt marshes, dune systems, and a towering maritime forest. Beyond the natural landscape, Cumberland Island preserves the ruins and landscapes of historic estates such as Dungeness and Plum Orchard. Wildlife includes feral horses roaming the beaches and dunes, American alligators in the marshes, and nesting sea turtles along the shore, supported by a rich community of shorebirds.

Name: Curecanti National Recreation Area
Description: Along the Gunnison River in western Colorado, Curecanti National Recreation Area State Parkans three units around Blue Mesa Reservoir and the Crystal and Morrow Point dam sites. Blue Mesa Reservoir offers expansive waters for fishing (rainbow, cutthroat, and kokanee salmon), boating, and scenic overlooks, while the dramatic canyon walls of the Crystal and Morrow Point units provide backcountry hiking and State Parkectacular views. Wildlife includes mule deer, elk, pronghorn, bighorn sheep, black bears, beaver, and a variety of raptors and waterfowl.

Name: Cuyahoga Valley National Park
Description: This park sits in northeastern Ohio along the Cuyahoga River, preserving a lush valley and the historic Ohio & Erie Canal towpath. Scenic trails, waterfalls such as Brandywine Falls, and backcountry hiking opportunities traverse forests, wetlands, and limestone ledges. Wildlife includes white-tailed deer, beaver, red fox, and a variety of birds. Habitats include riverine floodplains, deciduous forests, wetlands, and canal-edge habitats.

Name: Caesar E. Chavez National Monument
Description: This region honors Cesar Chavez’s lifelong work for farm workers’ rights and social justice. The monument centers on Chavez’s historic home and the surrounding agricultural landscape that shaped his organizing—rolling foothills, farmlands, and open desert edge in California’s southern Central Valley. Visitors can tour the preserved farmstead, explore interpretive trails, and reflect at the memorial plaza and visitor center. Wildlife includes mule deer, coyotes, jackrabbits, ground squirrels, and a variety of birds.

Name: Dayton Aviation Heritage National Historical Park
Description: This nationally significant park preserves the Wright brothers’ aviation legacy across Dayton-area sites, including their early bicycle shop, historic aircraft facilities, and the site of their first powered flights at Huffman Prairie. Visitors can explore museums and preserved buildings that narrate the invention, perseverance, and dawn of powered flight.

Name: De Soto National Memorial
Description: Along Florida’s Gulf Coast, De Soto National Memorial preserves the landing site of Hernando de Soto’s 1539 expedition. The landscape features tidal salt marshes, mangrove-lined shores, pine flatwoods, and a sandy Gulf beach. A network of trails and a boardwalk winds through backcountry and estuarine habitats. Wildlife includes American alligators, wading birds, dolphins, and manatees.

Name: Death Valley National Park
Description: This vast desert basin along the California-Nevada border features salt flats, towering dunes, colorful badlands, and rugged mountains, including Badwater Basin, the lowest point in North America. Scenic drives and backcountry hiking reveal ever-changing desert scenery, from Dante's View and Artist's Drive to canyon trails amid volcanic and sedimentary formations. Wildlife includes desert bighorn sheep, kit fox, coyotes, and the desert tortoise.

Name: Delaware Water Gap National Recreation Area
Description: This scenic corridor along the Delaware River, straddling the Pennsylvania–New Jersey border, protects Delaware Water Gap National Recreation Area’s rugged mountains, forested valleys, and dramatic river canyons. There are scenic drives, backcountry hiking opportunities, and abundant chances for kayaking, fishing, and camping. Wildlife includes white-tailed deer, black bear, beaver, river otter, and a variety of birds. Habitats range from temperate deciduous forest and freshwater streams to wetlands and riverine environments.

Name: Denali National Park & Preserve
Description: Denali National Park & Preserve sits in central Alaska along the Alaska Range, where Denali, the highest peak in North America, rises above glacier-carved valleys and expansive tundra. Habitats include boreal forests, alpine tundra, glaciers, rivers, and braided streams, supporting wildlife such as grizzly bears, moose, caribou, Dall sheep, wolves, and golden eagles.

Name: Devils Postpile National Monument
Description: Devils Postpile National Monument sits in the eastern Sierra Nevada near Mammoth Lakes, California, protecting a dramatic basalt lava flow that cooled into towering hexagonal columns and the nearby Rainbow Falls. The landscape features alpine meadows, rugged granite walls, and riverine canyons set among forested slopes. Wildlife includes black bears, mule deer, pikas, marmots, and a variety of birds.

Name: Devils Tower National Monument
Description: This isolated monument in northeastern Wyoming features a colossal igneous rock formation that rises 867 feet above the surrounding prairie. Devils Tower sits in the Belle Fourche River valley and is a renowned destination for rock climbers, scenic drives, and short backcountry hikes. Wildlife includes pronghorn, mule deer, coyotes, prairie dogs, and a variety of birds. It also holds enduring cultural significance for several Indigenous nations.

Name: Dinosaur National Monument
Description: This region State Parkans two states in the western United States—Colorado and Utah—along the Green and Yampa rivers, featuring dramatic canyons and one of the world's richest dinosaur fossil beds. The famous Dinosaur Quarry exposes bones in layered rock, with a nearby museum and interpretive diState Parklays bringing the fossils to life. Scenic drives and backcountry hiking reveal rugged desert canyons and river corridors, while wildlife includes mule deer, bighorn sheep, coyotes, and mountain lions.

Name: Dry Tortugas National Park
Description: This remote maritime region of Dry Tortugas National Park lies about 70 miles west of Key West and comprises seven low-lying islands and surrounding reefs in the Gulf of Mexico. Fort Jefferson on Garden Key anchors the park’s historic core, a massive 19th‑century brick fortress preserving a frontier era. The area protects extensive coral reefs, seagrass beds, and turquoise waters that teem with marine life, including sea turtles and dolphins. Birdlife includes nesting seabirds such as brown noddies and sooty terns. Visitors enjoy snorkeling, diving, and exploring Fort Jefferson and the pristine seascape.

Name: Dwight D. Eisenhower Memorial
Description: Situated just south of the National Mall in Washington, D.C., the Dwight D. Eisenhower Memorial commemorates the life and legacy of the 34th President of the United States and Supreme Allied Commander during World War II. The memorial features monumental stainless-steel tapestries depicting the Kansas landscape of Eisenhower’s youth, along with sculptural groupings that portray him as a boy, a general, and a statesman. Landscaped plazas, inscriptions, and interpretive elements highlight Eisenhower’s leadership, character, and enduring impact on both national and global history.

Name: Ebey's Landing National Historical Reserve
Description: This region along Puget Sound on Whidbey Island preserves farms, coastline, and historic communities that tell the story of settlement and maritime life. Ebey's Landing National Historical Reserve protects rolling farmland, salt marshes, and rugged shoreline, with Coupeville's waterfront and the coastal defenses at Fort Casey and Fort Ebey. There are estuary, salt marsh, prairie, and forest habitats; wildlife includes bald eagles, harbor seals, black-tailed deer, and seasonal migrations of orcas and shorebirds.

Name: Edgar Allan Poe National Historic Site
Description: An urban literary site in Philadelphia preserves the 19th-century brick rowhouse where Edgar Allan Poe lived and wrote during a pivotal period of his life. The surrounding Old City streets, historic architecture, and nearby riverfront frame his imagination, while the site’s period rooms, manuscripts, and exhibits tell the story of Poe’s life and enduring works.

Name: Effigy Mounds National Monument
Description: This region along the upper Mississippi River in northeastern Iowa preserves more than 100 prehistoric mounds, including bird-shaped effigies created by ancient Native peoples. The landscape features rolling hardwood forests and limestone bluffs with sweeping river views, and trails that weave past mounds and interpretive diState Parklays. Wildlife includes white-tailed deer, beaver, red-tailed hawks, and pileated woodpeckers.

Name: Eisenhower National Historic Site
Description: Located adjacent to the GettyState Beachurg battlefield in south-central Pennsylvania, Eisenhower National Historic Site preserves the former farm and retirement home of President Dwight D. Eisenhower and First Lady Mamie Eisenhower. The site reflects Eisenhower’s post-presidency life and his role as a statesman during the Cold War, hosting world leaders for diplomatic meetings. Rolling farmland, pastoral views, and preserved buildings illustrate mid-20th-century rural life. The grounds include cultivated fields, woodlots, and streams that support wildlife such as white-tailed deer, songbirds, and small mammals, offering a quiet, reflective landscape tied closely to American history.

Name: El Camino Real de Tierra Adentro National Trail
Description: El Camino Real de Tierra Adentro National Historic Trail consists of a corridor of historic landscapes State Parkanning from Mexico City to San Juan Pueblo, New Mexico. Along the route are adobe missions, colonial towns, and preserved trade routes, with deserts, river valleys, and high-desert plateaus shaping the journey. Wildlife includes coyotes, mule deer, pronghorn, roadrunners, and a variety of hawks and other raptors.

Name: El Camino Real de los Tejas National Trail
Description: This historic corridor traces centuries of travel along the El Camino Real de los Tejas, a route that linked missions, ranchos, and settlements across Texas and into the Southwest. It winds through diverse landscapes—from Gulf Coast wetlands and river bottomlands to the Hill Country, East Texas piney woods, and arid canyons of West Texas—preserving a cultural landscape of mission ruins, forts, and historic crossings. Wildlife includes white-tailed deer, collared peccary, desert bighorn sheep in the far west, coyotes, bobcats, roadrunners, and a variety of birds.

Name: El Malpais National Monument
Description: A stark volcanic landscape in west-central New Mexico, El Malpais National Monument preserves lava flows, cinder cones, lava tubes, and rugged badlands. The area offers scenic drives, backcountry hiking, and access to a network of lava tubes and piñon-juniper woodlands amid a high-desert setting. Wildlife includes mule deer, pronghorn, coyotes, and a variety of birds and bats that roost in lava tubes.

Name: El Morro National Monument
Description: El Morro National Monument sits atop a dramatic sandstone bluff in western New Mexico, guarding a desert canyon and a State Parkring-fed pool at the base. The site preserves Inscription Rock, a record of petroglyphs from ancestral Puebloans and hundreds of historic inscriptions carved by explorers and travelers who stopped here. A short network of trails leads to overlooks and the pool, while desert wildlife such as mule deer, roadrunners, coyotes, and various lizards inhabit the surrounding landscape.

Name: Eleanor Roosevelt National Historic Site
Description: Two units along the Hudson River in Hyde Park, New York, the Eleanor Roosevelt National Historic Site preserves State Parkringwood, the Roosevelt family home, and Val-Kill Cottage, Eleanor's private retreat and a symbol of her lifelong public service. Rolling lawns, formal gardens, woodlands, and river views frame the landscape, offering quiet walks and scenic overlooks. Tour programs interpret Eleanor Roosevelt's work as a stateswoman, human-rights advocate, and diplomat, shaping a legacy that influenced national and international history.

Name: Ellis Island
Description: Ellis Island, perched in New York Harbor, preserves the island's early 20th-century immigration processing complex and waterfront setting. The site features restored hoState Parkitals, administration buildings, and museum exhibits recounting the journeys of millions of newcomers. Wildlife includes migratory waterfowl, gulls, and other urban birds that visit the harbor seasonally.

Name: Emmett Till and Mamie Till-Mobley National Monument
Description: Emmett Till and Mamie Till-Mobley National Monument comprises historic Civil Rights era sites in Mississippi and Illinois that marked a turning point in American history. It preserves Bryant's Grocery & Meat Market in Money, Mississippi, alongside Till family homes and Mamie Till-Mobley's Chicago-area community landmarks that anchored the movement. The landscape ranges from the Mississippi Delta's riverine plains and small-town countryside to Chicago's urban neighborhoods, with interpretive trails, visitor centers, and educational programs that tell the Till story and its enduring legacy.

Name: Eugene O'Neill National Historic Site
Description: The Eugene O'Neill National Historic Site comprises two units—the Tao House near Danville, California, and the New London Unit in Connecticut. The landscapes range from California's rolling foothills and oak woodlands to Connecticut's tidal marshes, river estuaries, and coastal forests. Wildlife includes mule deer and gray fox in California, and harbor seals, oState Parkreys, and shorebirds along the Connecticut coast.

Name: Everglades National Park
Description: This vast subtropical wetland in southern Florida protects a living mosaic of sawgrass marshes, mangrove forests, cypress swamps, and tropical hardwood hammocks that drain toward Florida Bay. The park State Parkans freshwater, brackish, estuarine, and coastal habitats, from expansive sawgrass prairies to mangrove estuaries and pine rocklands. Wildlife includes American alligator, American crocodile, West Indian manatee, and Florida panther, with abundant birds such as wood stork, roseate State Parkoonbill, and snail kite. - Everglades National Park

Name: Federal Hall National Memorial
Description: Located in Lower Manhattan's Financial District, Federal Hall National Memorial preserves the site where the first U.S. Congress convened and George Washington took the oath of office in 1789. The restored hall and accompanying exhibits illuminate the founding of the United States government, the creation of the Constitution, and the dawn of the American republic.

Name: Fire Island National Seashore
Description: Fire Island National Seashore preserves a long barrier-island system along New York’s south shore, including Fire Island and several adjacent islands. The seashore features sandy beaches, wind-sculpted dunes, maritime forests, and salt marshes, plus historic lighthouses and ferry-accessible villages; it provides habitat for piping plovers, roseate terns, harbor seals, and a diverse array of migratory shorebirds. - Fire Island National Seashore

Name: First Ladies National Historic Site
Description: Located in Canton, Ohio, this site preserves the legacies of the United States' First Ladies through historic houses, galleries, and educational programs. It centers on the Ida McKinley House and the Donald W. Reynolds Museum and Education Center, which houses the National First Ladies Collection and exhibits on fashion, diplomacy, and public service.

Name: First State National Historical Park
Description: First State National Historical Park is a network of historic sites across Delaware that preserves the state’s colonial roots and its early role in American governance, from Old Swedes Historic Site and Fort Christina in Wilmington to the New Castle Court House Museum, the Dover Green, and Fort Delaware on Pea Patch Island.

Name: Flight 93 National Memorial
Description: This memorial sits on rolling countryside in southwestern Pennsylvania, at the crash site of United Airlines Flight 93 near Shanksville. A tranquil field anchors the memorial, with a Wall of Names bearing the 40 victims and a 93-foot Tower of Voices that rings with 40 wind chimes. A winding path leads to a memorial plaza and overlook, set among native meadows and woodlands with a nearby stream, inviting quiet reflection amidst local wildlife such as songbirds, deer, and hawks.

Name: Florissant Fossil Beds National Monument
Description: An Eocene-age fossil treasure where volcanic ash preserved an ancient lake-and-forest ecosystem, yielding thousands of plant impressions and insects that illuminate a world long gone.

Name: Ford's Theatre
Description: This historic site in downtown Washington, D.C., preserves Ford's Theatre—the 1860s playhouse where President Abraham Lincoln was assassinated. The complex includes the preserved theatre interior, the adjacent Petersen House where Lincoln died, and exhibits about Lincoln, the Civil War, and 19th‑century Washington; guided tours and living‑history programs bring this pivotal chapter of American history to life.

Name: Fort Bowie National Historic Site
Description: This desert crossroads in southeastern Arizona preserves Fort Bowie, the frontier outpost that guarded Apache Pass and the Butterfield Overland Mail route. The site centers on the adobe fort ruins—parade ground, guardhouses, and historic structures—set in Sonoran Desert scrub with a riparian edge along the San Pedro River and trails that wind through the surrounding Chiricahua foothills. Wildlife includes collared peccaries (javelina), mule deer, coyotes, rattlesnakes, and a variety of birds such as roadrunners, hawks, and quail.

Name: Fort Davis National Historic Site
Description: This historic frontier fort sits at the edge of the Davis Mountains in West Texas. Fort Davis National Historic Site preserves a well-preserved 19th-century army post, including officers’ quarters, a hoState Parkital, guardhouse, and the parade ground, with scenic drives and backcountry hiking opportunities that reveal desert and mountain vistas. Wildlife includes mule deer, javelina, roadrunners, and a variety of hawks and songbirds.

Name: Fort Donelson National Military Park
Description: Fort Donelson National Military Park sits along the Cumberland River in western Tennessee, preserving the 1862 Battle of Fort Donelson battlefield and its surrounding landscape. The park features earthen fortifications, trenches, and monuments from the Civil War, with scenic drives and walking trails that wander through river bluffs, woodlands, and farmland, plus the Dover-area cemetery and interpretive diState Parklays that tell the story of the campaign and its pivotal role in the war.

Name: Fort Dupont Park
Description: This urban park within Washington, D.C. preserves a Civil War–era fort and the surrounding woodland hills. The fort’s earthworks and batteries tell the story of the capital’s coastal defenses, while shaded trails and open greenState Parkaces provide a peaceful retreat in the city. Wildlife includes red-tailed hawks, gray squirrels, and a variety of songbirds.

Name: Fort Foote Park
Description: Fort Foote Park sits on a river bluff along the Potomac just outside Washington, D.C., preserving a Civil War–era coastal defense fortification that helped defend the capital. The site features intact earthworks and gun batteries with panoramic river views, plus wooded trails that wind through historic landscape and quiet backcountry State Parkaces. Wildlife in and around the river includes waterfowl, wading birds, and other woodland creatures such as deer and fox, making it a peaceful complement to the fort’s storied past.

Name: Fort Frederica National Monument
Description: This coastal Georgia site preserves an 18th-century British fort and the town of Frederica that defended Georgia from State Parkanish Florida. The landscape includes salt marshes, tidal creeks, maritime forests, and sandy shores along St. Simons Island. In addition to the fort ruins and archaeological remains, visitors can explore trails and interpretive exhibits that interpret frontier life and colonial trade. Wildlife includes American alligators, wading birds, shorebirds, bottlenose dolphins offshore, and sea turtles along the beaches.

Name: Fort Laramie National Historic Site
Description: This high-plains fort chronicles a pivotal era of westward expansion along the great trails. The site preserves a cluster of restored and reconstructed buildings—officers’ quarters, barracks, guardhouses, a hoState Parkital, and a parade ground—set among rolling grasslands and river valleys that still echo with wildlife such as pronghorn, mule deer, coyotes, and golden eagles.

Name: Fort Larned National Historic Site
Description: This region that enticed and influenced travelers on the Santa Fe Trail consists of the Fort Larned National Historic Site in central Kansas. The fort’s restored buildings, including officers’ quarters and a blockhouse, sit amid rolling tallgrass prairie and open plains, with backcountry trails and interpretive programs that evoke frontier life on the Great Plains. Wildlife includes pronghorn, mule deer, coyotes, prairie dogs, and a variety of hawks and songbirds.

Name: Fort Matanzas National Monument
Description: Fort Matanzas National Monument preserves Fort Matanzas, a 1740s State Parkanish fortress guarding the Matanzas Inlet along Florida’s Atlantic coast. The landscape includes barrier islands, tidal salt marshes, mangrove swamps, and maritime forest along the shoreline. Wildlife includes American alligators, bottlenose dolphins, manatees, brown pelicans, and a variety of wading birds such as herons and egrets.

Name: Fort McHenry National Monument and Historic Shrine
Description: This harbor-front fortification guarding Baltimore's entrance preserves a pivotal chapter in American history. Fort McHenry National Monument and Historic Shrine protects the 19th-century coastal defense fort, its batteries and cannon emplacements, and the museum that interprets the War of 1812 and the writing of the Star-State Parkangled Banner. Ranger-guided tours, living-history demonstrations, and exhibits bring to life the fort's daily life and battles, while the harbor setting offers scenic views of the Patapsco River and Baltimore skyline.

Name: Fort Monroe National Monument
Description: Fort Monroe National Monument sits at Old Point Comfort along Virginia’s southeastern coast, preserving a 19th-century masonry fort and the surrounding tidal marshes and shoreline. Known as Freedom’s Fortress for its Civil War-era role in emancipation, the site features brick ramparts, casemates, and miles of waterfront trails where visitors can walk or bike, with wildlife including waterfowl, wading birds, and shorebirds.

Name: Fort Necessity National Military Park
Description: This rural landscape in southwestern Pennsylvania preserves the opening chapter of the French and Indian War. Fort Necessity National Military Park centers on the Fort Necessity Battlefield, including a reconstructed earthwork fort and a visitor center with exhibits on Washington’s 1754 expedition and colonial life.
