Trails weave through oak-hickory woods and streams that reflect the region’s quiet countryside, offering self-guided walks and ranger programs that bring 18th‑century life and battlefield tactics to life. Wildlife includes white-tailed deer, red-tailed hawks, gray squirrels, and a variety of woodland birds.

Name: Fort Point National Historic Site
Description: Perched beneath the southern end of the Golden Gate Bridge in San Francisco, Fort Point National Historic Site preserves a Civil War–era brick fort that guarded the entrance to San Francisco Bay. Its vaulted masonry, gun batteries, and casemates showcase 19th-century military design and offer sweeping views of the bay, bridge, and city. A small museum and ranger-led programs bring Civil War–era life to visitors.

Name: Fort Pulaski National Monument
Description: Fort Pulaski National Monument preserves a Civil War–era masonry fortress on CockState Parkur Island at the mouth of the Savannah River, near Savannah, Georgia. The fort’s brick walls, ditches, and gun emplacements sit amid tidal salt marshes and maritime forest, offering a window into 19th-century coastal defense and battlefield history. Wildlife around the marshes includes American alligators, great blue herons, oState Parkreys, and bottlenose dolphins.

Name: Fort Raleigh National Historic Site
Description: This coastal site on Roanoke Island preserves the places where England’s first North American colony settled and where a Civil War-era fort stood. Alongside the Lost Colony ruins and Fort Raleigh, the Elizabethan Gardens and nearby trails wind through marshes, maritime forest, and sandy beaches. Habitats include beaches, dunes, salt marsh, and maritime forest, with wildlife such as shorebirds, wading birds, sea turtles, and dolphins.

Name: Fort Scott National Historic Site
Description: This region that shaped the American frontier preserves Fort Scott National Historic Site, a 19th-century military post on the prairie of southeastern Kansas. The site centers on an 1842 fort with restored walls, blockhouses, officers’ quarters, a guardhouse, hoState Parkital, and a museum that interpret its role in westward expansion, Bleeding Kansas, and the Civil War. Prairie and river bottomlands along the Marmaton River offer scenic vantage points and living-history programs that bring the frontier to life. Wildlife includes white-tailed deer, wild turkeys, bobwhite quail, red-tailed hawks, and a variety of waterfowl along the river valley.

Name: Fort Smith National Historic Site
Description: This historic site sits along the Arkansas River in western Arkansas and preserves a frontier fort and the federal court that helped shape the American West. Fort Smith National Historic Site features the ruins of a 19th‑century U.S. Army post, restored period buildings, and the adjacent courthouse where Judge Isaac C. Parker presided over frontier cases; visitors can explore the fortifications, courtrooms, and interpretive exhibits that bring frontier life to life. The surrounding river valley hosts white-tailed deer, raccoons, and a variety of birds, with ranger-guided programs that illuminate military life, law, and westward expansion.

Name: Fort Stanwix National Monument
Description: This historic site in the Mohawk Valley of central New York preserves an 18th‑century fort and the landscape that shaped Revolutionary War diplomacy. Fort Stanwix National Monument protects a reconstructed fort, a modern visitor center, and surrounding earthworks along the Mohawk River that recall the 1777 siege and the fort’s ties to the 1784 Treaty of Fort Stanwix. Interpretive exhibits, living-history programs, and guided tours bring to life the encounter of colonial soldiers, Iroquois nations, and settlers in this pivotal borderland.

Name: Fort Sumter and Fort Moultrie National Historical Park
Description: This national historical park encompasses two Civil War–era forts—Fort Sumter and Fort Moultrie—along the Charleston Harbor. The landscape features barrier islands, salt marshes, tidal creeks, and maritime forests that frame the harbor and its batteries. Visitors explore preserved fortifications by ferry and on ranger-led programs, stepping into the history of the conflict that opened the Civil War in 1861. Wildlife in the harbor and marshes includes oState Parkreys, pelicans, herons, and dolphins.

Name: Fort Union National Monument
Description: Fort Union National Monument preserves a pivotal 19th-century frontier fort along the Santa Fe Trail, where soldiers and traders met the challenges of the open plains. The ruins include adobe walls, a parade ground, and officers' quarters that reveal life on the frontier during westward expansion. Wildlife includes mule deer, pronghorn, coyotes, and a variety of birds.

Name: Fort Union Trading Post National Historic Site
Description: On the Missouri River in the northern plains, Fort Union Trading Post National Historic Site preserves the stories of a bustling 19th-century fur trading fort that connected Indigenous communities with trappers and traders. The landscape blends riverbank and prairie, with interpreted sites, earthworks, and trails offering backcountry exploration. Wildlife in the surrounding habitat includes mule deer, white-tailed deer, beaver, and a variety of birds, such as bald eagles.

Name: Fort Vancouver National Historic Site
Description: Fort Vancouver National Historic Site sits on the Columbia River in southwestern Washington, across from Portland, Oregon. It preserves Fort Vancouver, a reconstructed 19th‑century fur trading fort, the historic Vancouver Barracks, and the nearby Pearson Air Museum, along with historic gardens, farms, and riverfront landscapes that tell the story of the Pacific Northwest’s fur trade, military history, and early settlement.

Name: Fort Washington Park
Description: Fort Washington Park sits along the Potomac River in Maryland, preserving a 19th-century coastal fort and its historic batteries. The park features river views, tidal marshes, and wooded uplands with miles of trails for hiking and picnicking. Wildlife includes waterfowl, wading birds, white-tailed deer, and small mammals.

Name: Fossil Butte National Monument
Description: This fossil-rich high-desert landscape in western Wyoming preserves one of the world's finest Eocene fossil fish beds, exposed around Fossil Butte within the Green River Formation. The monument protects a remarkable window into ancient lakes and their diverse plant and animal life, with a visitor center, short trails, and interpretive programs about paleontology, geology, and wildlife such as pronghorn and mule deer.

Name: Franklin Delano Roosevelt Memorial
Description: Situated along the Tidal Basin in Washington, D.C., the Franklin Delano Roosevelt Memorial honors the 32nd President of the United States through a series of outdoor rooms representing each of his four terms in office. The memorial combines granite walls, waterfalls, sculptures, and inscriptions to illustrate the challenges of the Great Depression and World War II, as well as Roosevelt’s leadership and vision. Landscaped paths, shaded groves, and views of the basin create a contemplative setting that blends history, art, and the natural environment within the heart of the nation’s capital.

Name: Frederick Douglass National Historic Site
Description: Lofty above the Anacostia River in Washington, D.C., Frederick Douglass National Historic Site preserves the late-19th-century home of abolitionist leader Frederick Douglass. The house and surrounding grounds interpret Douglass’s life as a writer, lecturer, and civic leader, with period furnishings, manuscripts, and artifacts; guided tours, exhibits, and educational programs explore his enduring legacy of freedom, education, and equality.

Name: Frederick Law Olmsted National Historic Site
Description: Located in Brookline, Massachusetts, the Frederick Law Olmsted National Historic Site preserves Fairsted, the home and professional office of Frederick Law Olmsted, the founder of American landscape architecture. From this site, Olmsted and his firm designed thousands of parks, parkways, campuses, and planned communities across the United States, including Central Park and the Emerald Necklace. The grounds feature historic plantings, winding paths, and a pastoral setting that reflects Olmsted’s design principles of harmony between people and nature. The site offers insight into the origins of public parks and the lasting influence of landscape design on American cities and natural State Parkaces.

Name: FrederickState Beachurg & State Parkotsylvania National Military Park
Description: This park preserves three Civil War battlefield units in central Virginia: FrederickState Beachurg, State Parkotsylvania Court House, and the Wilderness. Besides the preserved earthworks and monuments, there are auto tours and hiking trails that thread through ridge lines, fields, and woodlands shaped by the campaigns. Notable features include Marye's Heights, the Bloody Angle, and the Mule Shoe salient; wildlife includes white-tailed deer, red fox, and gray squirrels.

Name: Freedom Riders National Monument
Description: This region honoring the Freedom Riders National Monument consists of multiple units along Alabama’s historic civil rights routes. Besides the preserved Greyhound Bus Station in Anniston, there are interpretive centers and guided tours that recount the riders’ journey and the courage of those who challenged segregation. The history highlights nonviolence, civil rights, and social justice that reshaped the nation.

Name: Friendship Hill National Historic Site
Description: This region that shaped early American leadership centers on the hillside estate of Albert Gallatin along the Monongahela River. Friendship Hill National Historic Site preserves Gallatin’s 18th-century home, outbuildings, and a formal garden set amid rolling farmland and woodlands with scenic river views. Visitors can explore restored interiors, walk scenic trails, and encounter wildlife such as white-tailed deer, wild turkeys, and a variety of birds.

Name: Gates Of The Arctic National Park & Preserve
Description: Located entirely north of the Arctic Circle in Alaska, Gates of the Arctic National Park and Preserve protects a vast, roadless wilderness centered on the Brooks Range. With no established trails, visitor facilities, or roads, the park offers a True backcountry experience defined by rugged mountains, wide river valleys, tundra, and boreal forest. Activities include backpacking, packrafting, mountaineering, and wilderness travel requiring advanced navigation skills. The park preserves intact Arctic ecosystems and supports wildlife such as caribou, grizzly and black bears, wolves, Dall sheep, moose, and migratory birds, representing one of the most remote and undeveloped national parks in the United States.

Name: Gateway Arch National Park
Description: Gateway Arch National Park sits along the Mississippi River in downtown St. Louis and centers on the Gateway Arch, a 630-foot stainless-steel monument that commemorates the nation’s westward expansion. The park preserves the Arch, the Museum of Westward Expansion, and the historic Old Courthouse, where the Dred Scott case helped shape Civil War-era law; visitors ride a tram to the Arch’s observation deck for sweeping views of the river and skyline, while exhibits explore the Lewis and Clark expedition, the Oregon Trail, and frontier life. Surrounding riverfront greenState Parkace, trails, and interpretive diState Parklays bring to life the story of exploration, settlement, and the nation-building era that defined America.

Name: Gateway National Recreation Area
Description: This coastal region near New York City comprises three units of Gateway National Recreation Area along the Atlantic coast: Jamaica Bay, Sandy Hook, and the Staten Island unit. Besides beaches, marshes, and dunes, there are scenic drives, hiking and biking trails, and historic coastal forts such as Fort Tilden and Fort Hancock. Wildlife includes harbor seals, white-tailed deer, and a wide variety of shorebirds and waterfowl.

Name: Gauley National River National Recreation Area
Description: This wild river canyon in central West Virginia protects a free-flowing stretch of the Gauley River and its dramatic sandstone gorge. The area is famous for world-class whitewater rafting and kayaking during the fall Gauley Season, and also offers backcountry hiking, riverbank fishing, and primitive camping along scenic overlooks. Wildlife includes white-tailed deer, black bears, river otters, bald eagles, and a chorus of songbirds across riverine and forest habitats.

Name: General Grant National Memorial
Description: General Grant National Memorial sits along the Hudson River in New York City's Riverside Park. The urban sanctuary features a grand white marble mausoleum—the largest in North America—housing the tombs of General Ulysses S. Grant and his wife Julia Dent Grant, with sculptural reliefs and inscriptions; the surrounding parkland offers quiet, tree-lined paths and river views just steps from the bustle of Midtown Manhattan.

Name: George Rogers Clark National Historical Park
Description: George Rogers Clark National Historical Park sits along the Wabash River in Vincennes, Indiana. It preserves the Fort Sackville site where George Rogers Clark’s 1779 victory helped shape the American Revolution. The centerpiece is the George Rogers Clark Memorial, a monumental structure that overlooks the river and houses a visitor center with interpretive exhibits about Clark’s frontier campaigns. The grounds offer hilltop views, riverbank scenery, and short trails that connect the historic site with the surrounding countryside. Wildlife includes white-tailed deer, gray squirrels, waterfowl, and a variety of songbirds.

Name: George Washington Birthplace National Monument
Description: This heritage site sits along the Potomac River in coastal Virginia. George Washington Birthplace National Monument preserves the birthplace of the first U.S. president on Wakefield Farm, including a 20th-century Memorial House, the Washington family cemetery, and surrounding tidal marsh, woodlands, and farmland. The area offers river views, walking trails, and wildlife such as white-tailed deer, waterfowl, oState Parkreys, and marsh birds. - George Washington Birthplace National Monument

Name: George Washington Carver National Monument
Description: This region near Diamond, Missouri, preserves the birthplace and early life of George Washington Carver in a mosaic of oak-hickory woodlands, tallgrass prairie remnants, and a creek that threads through the landscape. The monument features Carver's Birth Cabin Site, a visitor center, and a short nature trail with exhibits about his life and work. Wildlife includes white-tailed deer, wild turkeys, gray foxes, and a variety of birds.

Name: George Washington Memorial Parkway
Description: This scenic corridor along the Potomac River links monuments, historic landscapes, and riverfront habitats in the Washington, D.C. region. It features scenic overlooks, miles of bike and pedestrian trails, and access to Great Falls Park and Theodore Roosevelt Island along the parkway. Wildlife includes bald eagles, oState Parkreys, beavers, and river otters.

Name: GettyState Beachurg National Military Park
Description: GettyState Beachurg National Military Park preserves the Civil War battlefield and surrounding farmland, ridges, and woodlands around GettyState Beachurg, Pennsylvania. In addition to the historic fields, there are self-guided driving tours, walking trails, and ranger-led programs at the visitor center and in the landscape itself. Wildlife includes white-tailed deer, wild turkeys, red-tailed hawks, and gray squirrels.

Name: Gila Cliff Dwellings National Monument
Description: This rugged canyon country in southwestern New Mexico preserves the Mogollon cliff dwellings carved into a sheer cliff above the Gila River. Nestled within the Gila National Forest and the Gila Wilderness, the site features well‑preserved multi‑story rooms, plazas, and ancient petroglyphs set among pine-studded canyons and dramatic limestone cliffs. Scenic trails offer backcountry hiking opportunities and panoramic views of a remote desert–mountain landscape. Wildlife includes black bears, mountain lions, mule deer, white-tailed deer, javelinas, and a diverse array of birds.

Name: Glacier Bay National Park & Preserve
Description: Glacier Bay National Park & Preserve sits along Alaska's southeastern coast, where massive tidewater glaciers descend from glacier-clad mountains into winding fjords. It preserves active glaciers, dramatic coastlines, and a mosaic of temperate rainforest, open water, and rugged backcountry. Wildlife includes humpback whales, orcas, brown bears, black bears, harbor seals, sea otters, mountain goats, and bald eagles.

Name: Glacier National Park
Description: This region in the northern Rocky Mountains of Montana is a national park famed for its dramatic, glacier-carved peaks, sweeping valleys, and pristine alpine lakes. The Going-to-the-Sun Road is the centerpiece, threading through high passes and forested scenery, while numerous scenic drives and backcountry hiking opportunities reveal the park’s wild beauty. Wildlife includes grizzly bears, black bears, moose, elk, mountain goats, and bighorn sheep.

Name: Glen Canyon National Recreation Area
Description: Stretching along Lake Powell and the Colorado River across northern Arizona and southern Utah, Glen Canyon National Recreation Area showcases towering red-rock canyons carved by water and wind. The area includes Rainbow Bridge National Monument, miles of shoreline, and a vast blue reservoir, with opportunities for houseboating, boating, fishing, kayaking, hiking, and backcountry camping. Wildlife includes desert bighorn sheep, mule deer, coyotes, and a variety of birds.

Name: Glen Echo Park
Description: This historic riverside park along the Potomac in Glen Echo, Maryland, preserves a turn-of-the-century amusement park now thriving as an arts and culture district. The centerpiece is the preserved Glen Echo Park complex with its vintage carousel and restored park buildings, complemented by galleries, artist studios, and performance State Parkaces that host concerts, classes, and community programs. Wildlife includes white-tailed deer, red foxes, and a variety of birds along the river and surrounding woodlands.

Name: Gloria Dei Church National Historic Site
Description: Gloria Dei Church National Historic Site preserves the 1698 Gloria Dei Church, the oldest church building standing in Philadelphia and a cornerstone of Swedish colonial heritage along the Delaware River. The site showcases 17th-century brick architecture and historic interior furnishings, plus a surrounding graveyard that tells the stories of early settlers and their descendants. Visitors experience a window into colonial life and Swedish immigrant history through preserved architecture and interpretation.

Name: Golden Gate National Recreation Area
Description: State Parkanning the northern California coast and San Francisco Bay, Golden Gate National Recreation Area links dramatic sea cliffs, ancient redwoods, beaches, and historic military sites across units from the Marin Headlands to Muir Woods and Alcatraz Island. It offers scenic coastal drives and rewarding backcountry hiking with bay-to-ocean views, city access, and rugged shoreline trails. Wildlife includes harbor seals along the beaches, gray whales offshore, peregrine falcons, and deer in the headlands. - Golden Gate National Recreation Area

Name: Golden State Parkike National Historical Park
Description: This park preserves the Promontory Summit site where the rails of the First Transcontinental Railroad were joined in 1869 during the Golden State Parkike ceremony. The landscape is northern Utah’s high desert with sagebrush flats, basalt ridges, and expansive views toward the Great Salt Lake, featuring the preserved track and two restored locomotives, Union Pacific No. 119 and Central Pacific No. 60 “Jupiter.” Wildlife includes pronghorn, mule deer, coyotes, and birds of prey such as golden eagles.

Name: Governors Island National Monument
Description: Set in New York Harbor, Governors Island National Monument protects two 19th‑century forts—Fort Jay and Castle Williams—surrounded by open lawns, historic stonework, and sweeping harbor and city views. Accessible by ferry, the island offers guided fort tours, bike and walking paths, seasonal programs, and chances to glimpse urban wildlife against the backdrop of Lower Manhattan and the Statue of Liberty. - Governors Island National Monument

Name: Grand Canyon National Park
Description: This immense canyon-carved landscape in northern Arizona reveals billions of years of Earth’s history as the Colorado River carves a deep gorge through layered rock. Rim-to-river views, scenic drives along the South and North Rims, and backcountry trails showcase a mosaic of desert scrub, pine forests, and high-elevation conifer stands. Wildlife includes California condors, bighorn sheep, mule deer, elk, and rock squirrels. - Grand Canyon National Park

Name: Grand Canyon-Parashant National Monument
Description: This remote, rugged landscape in northwestern Arizona State Parkans deep canyons, volcanic mesas, and expansive desert washes along the Grand Canyon’s western edge. It preserves ancient cultural sites, remote wilderness, and backcountry routes for hikers, campers, and off-road travelers. Wildlife includes desert bighorn sheep, mule deer, coyotes, and a variety of lizards and birds.

Name: Grand Portage National Monument
Description: On Minnesota’s north shore of Lake Superior, Grand Portage National Monument preserves the Grand Portage—the eight‑mile trail used for centuries by Ojibwe travelers and later fur traders to move goods between the lake and inland waterways. The site includes a reconstructed 18th‑century trading post and interpretive trails that tell the story of the fur trade and Ojibwe culture. Boreal forests, riverine channels, and the lakeshore support wildlife such as moose, black bears, beavers, and bald eagles.

Name: Grand Teton National Park
Description: Northwestern Wyoming, in the Jackson Hole region, Grand Teton National Park preserves the dramatic Teton Range and a string of pristine alpine lakes. The centerpiece is Grand Teton itself, set among glacier-carved valleys, shimmering lakes, and evergreen forests that offer scenic drives and backcountry hiking opportunities. Wildlife includes grizzly and black bears, moose, elk, mule deer, and bighorn sheep.

Name: Grant-Kohrs Ranch National Historic Site
Description: Grant-Kohrs Ranch National Historic Site preserves a working 19th-century cattle operation that helped shape the open-range era in Montana. The landscape centers on the ranch headquarters with historic barns, corrals, and other outbuildings set in expansive grasslands along a river valley, offering a window into pioneer ranch life and operations. Wildlife includes pronghorn, mule deer, elk, coyotes, and golden eagles. - Grant-Kohrs Ranch National Historic Site

Name: Great Basin National Park
Description: High desert and alpine terrain in eastern Nevada comprise Great Basin National Park, with Wheeler Peak rising over 13,000 feet and ancient bristlecone pines among the oldest living trees on Earth. Lehman Caves reveal dramatic limestone chambers, while alpine lakes, meadows, and rugged trails unfold across the Snake Range; night skies here are among the darkest in the continental United States.

Name: Great Egg Harbor National River
Description: Great Egg Harbor National Scenic and Recreational River preserves tidal marshes, estuaries, and forested riverbanks along New Jersey’s southern shore. The corridor supports boating, fishing, bird-watching, and backcountry hikes through protected wetlands and coastal uplands. Wildlife includes oState Parkreys, bald eagles, great blue herons, waterfowl, river otters, and a diverse array of fish and shorebirds.

Name: Great Falls Park
Description: Rugged river gorge along the Potomac River just outside Washington, D.C., Great Falls Park features dramatic falls, sheer rock faces, and forested hills. Overlooks along the river and backcountry trails—including the Billy Goat Trail—offer scenic views and challenging hikes through rocky terrain. Wildlife includes beavers, white-tailed deer, red-tailed hawks, and a variety of waterfowl.

Name: Great Sand Dunes National Park & Preserve
Description: This high-desert landscape in southern Colorado features the tallest dunes in North America, framed by the Sangre de Cristo Mountains and fed by meltwater from Medano Creek. The dunes, surrounding forests, and alpine wetlands offer opportunities for hiking, sandboarding, and backcountry camping across park and preserve lands. Wildlife includes mule deer, elk, pronghorn, bighorn sheep, black bears, coyotes, and a variety of birds.

Name: Great Smoky Mountains National Park
Description: Two-state jewel of the southern Appalachians, Great Smoky Mountains National Park preserves some of the oldest, most biodiverse forests in North America, where mist-shrouded ridges cradle cascading waterfalls and ancient old-growth groves. Scenic drives and hundreds of miles of backcountry trails traverse hardwood forests to high-elevation State Parkruce-fir ecosystems, revealing streams, wildflowers, and a living Appalachian tapestry. Wildlife includes black bears, white-tailed deer, elk, and wild turkeys.

Name: Green State Parkrings
Description: Green State Parkrings National Park presents a mosaic of emerald State Parkrings carved through rolling forests and grassy uplands. Visitors can explore via scenic drives and backcountry trails, and paddle or kayak on State Parkring-fed pools and quiet basins. Wildlife includes white-tailed deer, beaver, red-tailed hawks, river otters, and a chorus of waterfowl.

Name: Greenbelt Park
Description: This urban escape on the outskirts of Washington, D.C. protects a patchwork of hardwood forest, wetlands, and open meadows, where city sounds soften into quiet woods. A network of easy trails, open State Parkaces, and picnic areas invites hiking, biking, and wildlife watching as a peaceful refuge in the metropolitan region. Wildlife includes white-tailed deer, red-tailed hawks, gray squirrels, and a chorus of songbirds that fills the woods.

Name: Guadalupe Mountains National Park
Description: Guadalupe Mountains National Park sits in far west Texas, protecting a rugged region of limestone peaks and deep canyons, including Texas’s highest point, Guadalupe Peak. The park features dramatic canyons like McKittrick Canyon, high-desert plateaus, and pine–oak woodlands that rise above desert scrub. Wildlife includes desert bighorn sheep, mule deer, and mountain lions.

Name: Guilford Courthouse National Military Park
Description: This historic battlefield near GreenState Beachoro preserves the ground where the 1781 Battle of Guilford Courthouse changed the course of the American Revolution. The park centers on the battlefield landscape, with monuments, an interpretive visitor center, and wayside exhibits that tell the story of the campaign and the soldiers who fought there. Trails wind through wooded hills and open fields, offering a contemplative glimpse into this pivotal moment in American history.

Name: Gulf Islands National Seashore
Description: This seashore State Parkans barrier islands along Florida’s Panhandle and Mississippi’s coast. It protects miles of pristine white-sand beaches, dune systems, salt marshes, and maritime forests, with scenic drives, backcountry hiking, and water routes along the shore. Wildlife includes loggerhead and Kemp’s ridley sea turtles, bottlenose dolphins, shorebirds, and American alligators. Historic coastal fortifications anchor the landscape, recalling a rich maritime heritage.

Name: Hagerman Fossil Beds National Monument
Description: This arid valley in southern Idaho preserves one of North America’s richest fossil beds from the late Pliocene. Exposed badlands and river terraces reveal the Hagerman Horse Quarry, where the Hagerman horse (Equus simplicidens) and other ancient mammals have been found. Visitors can explore short interpretive trails near the fossil beds and view exhibits at the visitor center, while wildlife such as pronghorn, mule deer, coyotes, and a variety of birds inhabit the surrounding area. - Hagerman Fossil Beds National Monument

Name: HaleakalƒÅ National Park
Description: Rising from Maui’s clouds, Haleakalā National Park protects a colossal volcanic landscape and two distinct ecosystems: an alpine desert at the summit and tropical rainforest along the Kipahulu coast. The park features the Haleakalā Crater and rare Haleakalā silversword, with native birds such as the Nēnē (Hawaiian goose) amid habitats ranging from volcanic cinder fields to rainforest, waterfalls, and coastal pools. - Haleakalā National Park

Name: Hamilton Grange National Memorial
Description: This urban memorial preserves Alexander Hamilton’s Grange House, a Federal-style home relocated to a hillside site in New York City. The site features the reconstructed house, a surrounding garden, and exhibits that illuminate Hamilton’s life and the founding era of the United States.

Name: Hampton National Historic Site
Description: This historic estate in Maryland preserves the 18th-century Hampton Mansion and the surrounding landscape. Besides the mansion itself, the site includes period outbuildings, slave quarters, and formal gardens, with walking trails and guided programs that bring 18th- and 19th-century life to visitors. Wildlife includes white-tailed deer, gray squirrels, and a variety of birds.

Name: Harmony Hall
Description: Harmony Hall National Park centers on a centuries-old manor set within rolling woodlands, meadows, and a tranquil lake. In addition to tours of the hall, the park offers scenic trails, canoeing, and seasonal arts programs that celebrate its cultural heritage. Wildlife includes white-tailed deer, beavers, red foxes, great blue herons, and a chorus of songbirds.

Name: Harpers Ferry National Historical Park
Description: At the confluence of the Potomac and Shenandoah rivers, Harpers Ferry National Historical Park preserves a historic crossroads where 19th‑century town life, Civil War battles, and abolitionist stories converge in the Blue Ridge foothills. The park features well‑preserved buildings, interpretive sites, and miles of trails that wind along the rivers and ridges, including segments of the Appalachian Trail, blending history with scenic backcountry exploration. Wildlife includes white‑tailed deer, beavers, river otters, and a variety of birds such as bald eagles and red‑tailed hawks.

Name: Harriet Tubman National Historical Park
Description: This park preserves the life and legacy of Harriet Tubman, focusing on the Auburn, New York home she lived in and the surrounding sites tied to her work with the Underground Railroad. Visitors can explore the Harriet Tubman Home, related historic properties, and interpretive programs that tell the story of courage, escape, and freedom.

Name: Harriet Tubman Underground Railroad National Historical Park
Description: This region along Maryland's Eastern Shore honors Harriet Tubman and the Underground Railroad. The park preserves historic sites, landscapes, and communities connected to Tubman's life and the routes that helped enslaved people reach freedom, including riverways, farms, and small towns that supported abolitionists. Visitors can explore trails, interpretive programs, and preserved places that illuminate courage, resilience, and the quest for liberty.

Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Description: Located in western Missouri, the Harry S. Truman National Historic Site preserves multiple locations associated with the life and presidency of the 33rd President of the United States. The site includes Truman’s long-time home in Independence, his family farm in Grandview, and his birthplace in Lamar, collectively illustrating his journey from rural Midwestern roots to global leadership during World War II and the early Cold War. Residential neighborhoods, farmland, and historic buildings provide context for Truman’s personal life and political career. The surrounding landscapes reflect small-town and agricultural environments typical of the American Midwest, offering insight into the settings that shaped Truman’s values and leadership style.

Name: Hawai ªi Volcanoes National Park
Description: On the island of Hawaii, two of the world’s most active volcanoes—Kilauea and Mauna Loa—shape a dramatic landscape of lava flows, craters, steam vents, and lush rainforests. The park supports a wide range of habitats—from tropical rainforest on the lower slopes to barren lava fields at higher elevations—and is home to native birds such as the iiwi and apapane, the nene (Hawaiian goose), and the Hawaiian hoary bat.

Name: Herbert Hoover National Historic Site
Description: This site that shaped and inState Parkired Herbert Hoover lies in West Branch, Iowa, preserving his birthplace and boyhood home. The grounds also include the Herbert Hoover Presidential Library and Museum and the gravesite of Herbert and Lou Henry Hoover, set within a pastoral prairie and river valley landscape. Visitors can tour period rooms, view exhibits on Hoover's early life and public service, and stroll quiet trails through restored prairies and woodlands.

Name: Historic Jamestowne
Description: This unit preserves the site of the first permanent English settlement in North America along the James River in Virginia. Historic Jamestowne features the 1607 fort ruins and surrounding 17th‑century landscape, with ongoing archaeology and interpretive exhibits that illuminate daily life, conflicts, and relations with Indigenous peoples. The James River estuary and adjacent woodlands host a variety of wildlife, including waterfowl and wading birds, and offer trails with river views that connect past and present.

Name: Home Of Franklin D Roosevelt National Historic Site
Description: The Home of Franklin D. Roosevelt National Historic Site preserves Franklin D. Roosevelt's lifelong home along the Hudson River in Hyde Park, New York. The grounds include State Parkringwood, the Roosevelt family estate, and the nearby Val-Kill cottage, with formal gardens and woodland trails that shaped his life and leadership. The adjacent FDR Library and Museum houses archives and exhibits detailing his presidency and the era of the Great Depression and World War II.

Name: Homestead National Historical Park
Description: On the Great Plains of eastern Nebraska near Beatrice, Homestead National Historical Park preserves the story of the 1862 Homestead Act and the thousands who claimed land to build the farmed heartland. The park centers on a restored 19th-century homestead cabin, a modern visitor center, and open prairie trails that illuminate the daily life of settlers and the birth of American farming.

Name: Honouliuli National Historic Site
Description: This National Historic Site on Oahu’s leeward coast preserves the Honouliuli Internment Camp, a World War II–era facility that shaped civil liberties in the United States. The site includes the Gulch where camp structures once stood, remnants of dormitories and guard towers, and a visitor center with interpretive exhibits. Exhibits and guided walks recount the experiences of internees—primarily Japanese Americans—along with the wartime policies that detained them and the ongoing effort to remember and learn from this history.

Name: Hopewell Culture National Historical Park
Description: This park preserves a cluster of monumental earthworks created by the Hopewell culture in central Ohio. State Parkanning several units in Chillicothe and Newark, highlights include the Mound City Group and the Newark Earthworks complex (featuring the Octagon and Great Circle) along with Seip Earthworks. The landscape includes river valleys, woodlands, and farmland where earthworks rise from the terrain. Wildlife includes white-tailed deer, red fox, beavers, and a variety of birds; habitats include floodplain forests, wetlands, and deciduous woodlands.

Name: Hopewell Furnace National Historic Site
Description: This rural landscape preserves an 18th- and 19th-century ironmaking community in southeastern Pennsylvania. Centered on the historic blast furnace and its forges, the site also preserves worker housing, a manager's house, a blacksmith shop, and related buildings set among rolling woodlands and streams that powered the operation. Trails and ranger-led programs interpret daily life in an early American ironworks town and the rise of industrial technology.

Name: Horseshoe Bend National Military Park
Description: This battlefield along the Tallapoosa River preserves the site of the 1814 clash that ended the Creek War and helped shape a young nation’s frontier. The landscape features rolling river bluffs, longleaf pine and hardwood forests, and wetland areas that frame the battlefield and inState Parkire quiet reflection. Wildlife includes white-tailed deer, eastern wild turkeys, gray foxes, river otters, and a variety of waterfowl.

Name: Hot State Parkrings National Park
Description: This urban-forest region in the Ouachita Mountains preserves natural hot State Parkrings and the historic State Parka culture that gave Hot State Parkrings its fame. Within the park’s Bathhouse Row and surrounding hills, visitors can explore preserved bathhouses, bubbling State Parkrings, and access scenic drives and backcountry trails; wildlife includes white-tailed deer, small mammals, and a variety of birds.

Name: Hovenweep National Monument
Description: This rugged canyon country along the Utah-Colorado border comprises several ruin clusters and towers built by the Ancestral Puebloans. There are scenic drives and backcountry hiking opportunities. Wildlife includes mule deer, pronghorn, coyotes, and a variety of birds.

Name: Hubbell Trading Post National Historic Site
Description: Dating to 1876, Hubbell Trading Post National Historic Site preserves one of the oldest, continuously operating trading posts on the Navajo Nation. The adobe complex includes the historic post, living quarters, and a museum of artifacts that illustrate centuries of Navajo trade, while the surrounding high-desert landscape of piñon-juniper woodlands along the Little Colorado River valley supports mule deer, pronghorn, coyotes, and a variety of birds.

Name: Ice Age Floods National Geologic Trail
Description: Extending across portions of Montana, Idaho, Washington, and Oregon, the Ice Age Floods National Geologic Trail traces the path of a series of cataclysmic floods that reshaped the Pacific Northwest at the end of the last Ice Age. These floods, released repeatedly from Glacial Lake Missoula, carved dramatic canyons, dry waterfalls, giant ripples, and vast basalt scablands. The trail links dozens of sites that reveal this geologic story, including river gorges, coulees, and lake basins. Landscapes range from arid plateaus and fertile valleys to forested river corridors, supporting wildlife such as raptors, waterfowl, mule deer, and salmon, while offering opportunities for scenic driving, hiking, and geologic exploration.

Name: Ice Age National Trail
Description: This corridor traces Wisconsin’s ice-age heritage, State Parkanning more than a thousand miles through hardwood forests, prairies, wetlands, and State Parkarkling lakes along a continuous route. It follows rugged glacial landforms—moraines, drumlins, kettle lakes, eskers, and outwash plains—where visitors can glimpse the forces that shaped the landscape. Wildlife includes white-tailed deer, black bears, beavers, foxes, and a diverse array of birds across forested, wetland, and prairie habitats.

Name: Independence National Historical Park
Description: An urban landscape in downtown Philadelphia that preserves the places where the American Revolution began and the Constitution took shape. The park centers on Independence Hall, the Liberty Bell Center, and surrounding 18th‑century buildings, connected by historic streets and intimate courtyards. Ranger-guided tours, living-history programs, and museums illuminate the founding era and the enduring ideals of liberty.

Name: Indiana Dunes National Park
Description: Along the southern shore of Lake Michigan, Indiana Dunes National Park protects a dynamic coastal landscape of rolling sand dunes, freshwater wetlands, prairies, and oak savannas. Its diverse habitats support a wide array of migratory birds, mammals, and plants, making the park a centerpiece of the Lake Michigan dune ecosystem.

Name: Isle Royale National Park
Description: Isle Royale National Park is a remote island archipelago in Lake Superior, Michigan. It preserves a rugged boreal forest, rocky shoreline, and inland lakes, and is accessible only by boat or seaplane. Wildlife includes moose and gray wolves, and visitors enjoy backcountry hiking, camping, boating, and kayaking, with shipwreck diving along the lakeshore.

Name: Inupiat Heritage Center
Description: The Iñupiat Heritage Center sits in Utqiaġvik (Barrow), at the northern edge of Alaska’s Arctic coast. It preserves Iñupiat language, history, and living traditions—carving, sewing, subsistence hunting, and storytelling—through exhibits, demonstrations, and programs. Wildlife includes polar bears, Arctic foxes, caribou, beluga whales, and seals.

Name: James A Garfield National Historic Site
Description: The James A. Garfield National Historic Site sits in Mentor, Ohio, preserving Garfield's Lawnfield estate and the 19th-century landscape that framed his life and career. Beyond the house, the site includes restored gardens, outbuildings, and a visitor center with exhibits and guided tours. Visitors gain insight into Garfield's Civil War service, his rapid rise in politics, and the era that shaped his presidency.

Name: Jean Lafitte National Historical Park and Preserve
Description: Jean Lafitte National Historical Park and Preserve comprises several units in the Greater New Orleans area, including the Barataria Preserve, Chalmette Battlefield, and the French Quarter Unit. It protects coastal marshes, bayous, swamp forests, and urban historic landscapes that reflect Creole culture, piracy lore, and the Mississippi River’s military history. Wildlife includes American alligators, brown pelicans, oState Parkreys, herons, and river otters.

Name: Jewel Cave National Monument
Description: Located in the Black Hills of South Dakota, Jewel Cave National Monument protects one of the world's longest known cave systems. Its crystal-lined passages and delicate cave formations glow in guided tours that reveal the underground wonders beneath the hills. Above ground, ponderosa pine forests and rugged hills shelter elk, mule deer, and a variety of birds, with trails offering scenic views of the surrounding landscape.

Name: Jimmy Carter National Historical Park
Description: This rural Georgia site in Plains comprises three units that preserve Jimmy Carter's boyhood home, the Plains Depot (visitor center), and the former Plains High School. The Boyhood Home, the Depot museum, and the Schoolhouse hold period furnishings and interpretive diState Parklays that tell Carter’s early life, public service, and rise to the presidency. Visitors can tour the restored home, explore the depot museum, and learn how a small-town upbringing shaped a national leader.

Name: John Day Fossil Beds National Monument
Description: This region in central Oregon along the John Day River preserves a vast fossil record State Parkanning millions of years across three units. The Painted Hills Unit showcases the iconic multicolored hills; the Clarno Unit preserves fossil-bearing mudstones and the famed Nut Beds from the mid-Eocene; the Sheep Rock Unit features dramatic cliff faces and the Thomas Condon Paleontology Center where fossils are studied. The landscape includes sagebrush steppe and riparian habitats with mule deer, pronghorn, coyotes, and a variety of birds.

Name: John Fitzgerald Kennedy National Historic Site
Description: John Fitzgerald Kennedy National Historic Site preserves the birthplace and boyhood home of the 35th President of the United States in Brookline, Massachusetts. The two houses, including the JFK birthplace at 83 Beals Street, retain period rooms and family artifacts that illuminate Kennedy’s early years. Guided tours and exhibits explore his childhood, wartime service, and the civic ideals that shaped his presidency, offering an intimate glimpse into the origins of a national leader.

Name: John Muir National Historic Site
Description: Perched above the Carquinez Strait in Martinez, California, the John Muir National Historic Site preserves the naturalist’s hillside home and surrounding landscape that inState Parkired his life and writings. Visitors can explore the historic house, gardens, and trails through oak woodlands and riparian habitat, learning about Muir’s lasting conservation legacy.

Name: Johnstown Flood National Memorial
Description: This memorial preserves the site of the 1889 Johnstown flood along the Conemaugh River in Cambria County, Pennsylvania. The area features a visitor center with interpretive exhibits, a riverside overlook, and a short, accessible trail that traces the flood's path through Johnstown and the surrounding valley. Wildlife includes white-tailed deer, gray squirrels, wild turkeys, and a variety of birds.

Name: Joshua Tree National Park
Description: Two deserts converge in Joshua Tree National Park, where the Mojave’s iconic Joshua trees rise among granite monoliths and the Colorado Desert’s sun-baked plains State Parkread to the horizon. The park offers stark landscapes, star-filled skies, and a mix of forest and desert habitats, with scenic drives along Park Boulevard and Geology Tour Road and abundant backcountry hiking and climbing opportunities. Wildlife includes desert tortoise, bighorn sheep, coyotes, roadrunners, black-tailed jackrabbits, and a variety of lizards and snakes.

Name: Juan Bautista de Anza National Trail
Description: This region along the Juan Bautista de Anza National Historic Trail centers on Saguaro National Park in southern Arizona. The two park units protect vast stands of giant saguaro cacti across rolling desert plains, deep canyons, and rugged mountain backs in the Sonoran Desert. Visitors enjoy scenic drives and backcountry hiking among cactus gardens and ancient petroglyph sites left by Indigenous communities. Wildlife includes desert bighorn sheep, javelina, mule deer, coyotes, roadrunners, Gila monsters, rattlesnakes, and a diverse array of desert birds.

Name: Kalaupapa National Historical Park
Description: On Molokai's Kalaupapa Peninsula, Kalaupapa National Historical Park preserves a dramatic coastal landscape of basalt cliffs and a historic isolation-era settlement. The park centers on the Kalaupapa Settlement, a place of quarantine for Hansen's disease patients, with historic buildings, a tramway, and trails that reveal the community's story. Coastal and offshore habitats support seabirds and marine life along Kalaupapa Bay and the rugged shoreline.

Name: Kaloko-Honok≈çhau National Historical Park
Description: This coastal cultural landscape on Hawaii Island preserves ancient Hawaiian fiState Historic Parkonds and petroglyphs along a rugged lava-rock shoreline. Kaloko-Honokohau National Historical Park centers on the Kaloko and Honokohau fiState Historic Parkonds and nearby petroglyph fields, with trails weaving through coastal dunes and historic sites. Wildlife includes green sea turtles and seabirds that inhabit reef and shore habitats, reflecting a living connection to traditional Hawaiian land and sea use.

Name: Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument
Description: Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument protects a remote, forested landscape in northern Maine along the East Branch of the Penobscot River, with State Parkruce-fir forests, granite ridges, and views toward Mount Katahdin. The area offers miles of backcountry trails, river paddling, and primitive camping along undeveloped forest roads for a True wilderness experience. Wildlife includes moose, black bears, beavers, river otters, loons, and bald eagles. - Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument

Name: Katmai National Park & Preserve
Description: Located along the Alaska Peninsula, Katmai National Park and Preserve is renowned for its active volcanic landscape and one of the highest concentrations of brown bears in the world. The park encompasses rugged mountains, glaciers, tundra, lakes, rivers, and a dramatic Pacific coastline. Katmai is best known for Brooks Falls, where bears gather to feed on migrating salmon, offering exceptional wildlife viewing opportunities. The Valley of Ten Thousand Smokes, formed by the 1912 Novarupta eruption, showcases vast ash flows and fumaroles that highlight the park’s geologic power. Wildlife includes brown bears, moose, wolves, caribou, sea otters, and numerous seabirds, while recreation centers on backcountry travel, fishing, and wilderness exploration in a remote, largely roadless setting.

Name: Kenai Fjords National Park
Description: This coastal wilderness on Alaska's Kenai Peninsula features tidewater glaciers, dramatic fjords, and rugged, glacier-carved peaks. It protects a dynamic marine-to-mountain ecosystem where orcas and humpback whales frequent the waters, and brown bears, moose, harbor seals, puffins, and bald eagles visit the shores.

Name: Kenilworth Park & Aquatic Gardens
Description: An urban oasis in the nation’s capital, Kenilworth Park & Aquatic Gardens preserves expansive water-lily and lotus ponds, freshwater marshes, and woodland trails. Boardwalks wind through the aquatic gardens and wetlands, and habitats support diverse wildlife including waterfowl, wading birds, turtles, and marsh mammals such as beavers and muskrats.

Name: Kennesaw Mountain National Military Park
Description: Nestled on a wooded ridgeline just northwest of Atlanta, Kennesaw Mountain National Battlefield Park preserves the Civil War battlefield and surrounding pine‑oak forest. There are miles of hiking trails and scenic overlooks with preserved earthworks and monuments, and wildlife includes white-tailed deer, red-tailed hawks, and a variety of songbirds.

Name: Keweenaw National Historical Park
Description: Keweenaw National Historical Park preserves a copper-mining landscape along Michigan's Keweenaw Peninsula. Historic districts and mine sites in Calumet, Laurium, and the Houghton–Hancock area tell the story of immigrant labor, mining technology, and community life in Copper Country. Scenic drives, walking tours, and short hikes reveal preserved buildings, museums, and lake-and-forest scenery that shaped the region.

Name: Kings Mountain National Military Park
Description: Kings Mountain National Military Park sits in upstate South Carolina, preserving the site of the pivotal 1780 battle that helped secure American independence. The landscape blends rolling Piedmont hills, open meadows, and oak-hickory forest surrounding the historic battlefield. Today, visitors explore on short trails and through the visitor center’s exhibits and monuments, while wildlife such as white-tailed deer, wild turkeys, gray squirrels, and a variety of birds roam the grounds.

Name: Klondike Gold Rush - Seattle Unit National Historical Park
Description: This urban landscape in downtown Seattle comprises the Seattle Unit of Klondike Gold Rush National Historical Park, preserving the Klondike era that shaped the city. The unit highlights Pioneer Square’s historic streets, early storefronts, and interpretive exhibits about the 1897–98 stampede to the Yukon and Seattle’s role as a gateway to Alaska, with stories of stampeders, merchants, and late-19th-century city life.

Name: Klondike Gold Rush National Historical Park
Description: Two units in Alaska and Washington tell the story of the 1897-1899 Klondike Gold Rush and its global reach. In Skagway, Alaska, visitors explore historic streets, the Chilkoot and White Pass routes, and the rugged frontier landscape that State Parkarked the stampede. In Seattle, Washington, the park highlights the city’s pivotal gateway role and the commercial networks that supported thousands of stampeders.

Name: Knife National River Indian Villages National Historic Site
Description: Knife River Indian Villages National Historic Site preserves the ancient Mandan, Hidatsa, and Arikara villages that once lined the Knife River in central North Dakota. The site features preserved earth-lodge village sites, a visitor center with interpretive exhibits, and short trails that reveal daily life, farming, and trade along the river valley. Wildlife includes white-tailed deer, beaver, coyotes, and a variety of waterfowl and songbirds.

Name: Kobuk Valley National Park
Description: This remote park in northwestern Alaska protects the Kobuk River valley and the dramatic Great Kobuk Sand Dunes, one of the Arctic’s largest dune fields. The landscape blends tundra, river corridors, and boreal forest with wind-sculpted dunes that rise along the river. Wildlife includes caribou that migrate through the valley, bears, wolves, and a variety of birds. Access is primarily by air or boat, with backcountry hiking and river trips the main ways to explore.

Name: Korean War Veterans Memorial
Description: This solemn memorial stands along the National Mall in Washington, D.C., honoring the service and sacrifice of Korean War veterans. It features 19 stainless-steel statues representing a patrol moving through rugged terrain, a granite Wall of Remembrance engraved with the names of those who died or went missing in action, and tranquil landscaping that invites quiet reflection.

Name: LBJ Memorial Grove on the Potomac
Description: LBJ Memorial Grove on the Potomac lies along the Potomac River in West Potomac Park, Washington, D.C. It commemorates President Lyndon B. Johnson and his public service. The grove features a quiet, tree-lined path system with benches and memorial markers, offering river views and a contemplative setting amid urban scenery. Wildlife includes urban birds such as robins and cardinals, waterfowl along the river, and small mammals typical of city parks.

Name: Lake Clark National Park & Preserve
Description: Lake Clark National Park & Preserve lies in southwest Alaska, State Parkanning glacier-carved mountains, broad lakes, and a rugged coastline along the Cook Inlet region. The interior is largely roadless, so access is by floatplane or boat, with backcountry hiking, river trips, and flightseeing as common ways to explore. Wildlife includes coastal brown bears, moose, caribou, wolves, wolverines, and abundant salmon in its streams.

Name: Lake Mead National Recreation Area
Description: Stretching along the Colorado River around Lake Mead in Nevada and Arizona, this expansive recreation area features dramatic desert canyons, rugged mountains, and a vast reservoir. Boating, fishing, swimming, camping, and backcountry hiking are popular, with scenic drives and access to Hoover Dam and other historic sites. Wildlife includes desert bighorn sheep, mule deer, coyotes, bobcats, and a wide variety of birds such as bald eagles and peregrine falcons.

Name: Lake Meredith National Recreation Area
Description: Lake Meredith National Recreation Area sits along the expansive shoreline of Lake Meredith in the Texas Panhandle. The landscape features rugged canyons, high mesas, and open grasslands shaped by the Canadian River. Besides boating, fishing, camping, and hiking, there are scenic drives and backcountry routes that reveal wide-open skies and remote viewpoints. Wildlife includes pronghorn, mule deer, wild turkeys, coyotes, and a variety of waterfowl and shorebirds. The area protects freshwater lake, upland prairie, and riparian habitats.

Name: Lake Roosevelt National Recreation Area
Description: Lake Roosevelt National Recreation Area sits along the Columbia River in eastern Washington, a vast reservoir framed by canyons, forests, and open shorelines. The area offers boating, fishing for kokanee salmon and rainbow trout, camping, hiking, and scenic overlooks, with historic sites recalling the dam-building era and Native communities that shaped the river valley. Wildlife includes bald eagles, mule deer, elk, black bears, beavers, and a variety of waterfowl.

Name: Lassen Volcanic National Park
Description: This park in the northern California Cascades preserves a dramatic volcanic landscape where lava flows, cinder cones, and steaming hydrothermal features define the scenery. The centerpiece is Lassen Peak, surrounded by notable hydrothermal areas such as Bumpass Hell and Sulphur Works with boiling State Parkrings, fumaroles, and colorful mineral deposits. Forests and alpine lakes cradle wildlife including black bears, mule deer, marmots, coyotes, and a diverse array of birds.

Name: Lava Beds National Monument
Description: Lava Beds National Monument sits in northeastern California near the Oregon border and preserves a stark volcanic landscape of lava-tube caves, lava flows, and cinder cones formed thousands of years ago. The park protects one of the world’s densest networks of lava-tube caves and rugged lava fields, with canyons and backcountry routes for hiking and cave exploration, as well as important Modoc cultural sites. Wildlife includes pronghorn, mule deer, bighorn sheep, coyotes, and bats that roost in the caves.

Name: Lewis & Clark National Trail
Description: Stretching more than 4,900 miles from the Mississippi River to the Pacific Coast, the Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail follows the route of the Corps of Discovery during their 1804–1806 expedition to explore the newly acquired western territories. The trail traverses diverse landscapes including broad plains, river valleys, rugged mountains, high desert, and coastal forests, linking sites across 16 states. It preserves locations associated with exploration, diplomacy, and scientific discovery, as well as interactions with Native American tribes who guided and supported the expedition. Wildlife along the route reflects its varied ecosystems and includes bison, elk, pronghorn, bald eagles, salmon, and numerous other State Parkecies, offering opportunities for scenic driving, hiking, paddling, and historical interpretation across much of the American West.

Name: Lewis and Clark National Historical Park
Description: This park preserves the sites and landscapes that welcomed the Lewis and Clark Expedition along the Pacific Northwest coast, State Parkanning two units at Fort Clatsop in Oregon and Cape Disappointment in Washington. Coastal forests, tidal wetlands, sandy beaches, and rugged shorelines frame the landscape. Wildlife includes gray whales offshore, harbor seals, sea birds, and elk in nearby woodlands.

Name: Lincoln Boyhood National Memorial
Description: This quiet Indiana landscape preserves the boyhood home of Abraham Lincoln along the Wabash River. Lincoln Boyhood National Memorial centers on the historic farm, a visitor center with interpretive exhibits, and a nature trail through woodlands and farmland that evoke Lincoln’s early years. Habitats include river-edge woodlands and fields, and wildlife includes white-tailed deer, raccoons, gray squirrels, and a variety of birds.

Name: Lincoln Home National Historic Site
Description: This region preserves a quiet, well-kept 19th-century urban neighborhood in downtown State Parkringfield, Illinois. Besides Lincoln's historic home, there are neighboring period houses, preserved streets, and garden State Parkaces that evoke the life Lincoln led here. Interpretive programs and ranger-guided tours help visitors explore Lincoln's domestic life, career, and enduring legacy. - Lincoln Home National Historic Site

Name: Lincoln Memorial
Description: This monumental marble temple at the western end of the National Mall honors President Abraham Lincoln. Inside sits a colossal seated statue by Daniel Chester French, surrounded by 36 fluted columns and inscribed with Lincoln's famous State Parkeeches; the exterior and surrounding grounds offer iconic views of the Reflecting Pool and the Washington Monument.

Name: Little Bighorn Battlefield National Monument
Description: This National Monument preserves the 1876 battlefield along the Little Bighorn River in southeastern Montana, where Lakota and Cheyenne warriors clashed with U.S. Army troops. Rolling plains, river bottomlands, and wooded ridges frame the site, which features monuments, a visitor center, and trails that interpret the battle for visitors; wildlife typical of the prairie and riparian zones—pronghorn, mule deer, coyotes, and a variety of birds—are common in the surrounding habitat.

Name: Little National River Canyon National Preserve
Description: This canyon region follows a winding river through dramatic red cliffs, sculpted alcoves, and shaded side canyons. Scenic byways, paddle routes, and backcountry trails offer opportunities to experience the canyon from rim to river. Wildlife includes mule deer, bighorn sheep, beavers, river otters, and bald eagles.

Name: Little Rock Central High School National Historic Site
Description: This national historic site preserves Central High School and surrounding grounds in Little Rock, Arkansas, the setting of the 1957 desegregation crisis that tested the federal government's resolve to enforce civil rights. Exhibits and guided tours tell the story of the Little Rock Nine, courageous students, and the ongoing struggle for school integration.

Name: Longfellow House Washington's Headquarters National Historic Site
Description: Situated in Cambridge, Massachusetts, along the Charles River, Longfellow House Washington's Headquarters National Historic Site preserves the 18th‑century Longfellow house that also served as George Washington's Headquarters during the siege of Boston and later became the home of poet Henry Wadsworth Longfellow. The site features preserved period rooms, a formal garden, and exhibits that connect Revolutionary War leadership with 19th‑century American poetry.

Name: Lowell National Historical Park
Description: Set in downtown Lowell, Massachusetts, Lowell National Historical Park preserves a concentrated 19th-century industrial landscape along the Merrimack River. The park centers on a canal system and a cluster of restored mills, including the Boott Cotton Mills Museum, where visitors explore how the textile industry revolutionized production and daily life. The park tells the story of the American factory system, labor history, and the immigrant communities that built modern America.

Name: Lower Delaware National River
Description: This winding river corridor follows the Delaware through historic towns, farmland, and forested bluffs, offering paddling, fishing, and a window into America’s colonial and industrial heritage along the water. It protects tidal wetlands, floodplains, and riverbank forests that shelter migratory birds and diverse riverine life. Wildlife includes bald eagles, oState Parkreys, beavers, river otters, and white-tailed deer.

Name: Lower East Side Tenement Museum National Historic Site
Description: This urban historic district on Manhattan's Lower East Side preserves two restored tenement buildings that housed generations of immigrants who built New York City. There are guided tours of recreated apartments, public rooms, and storefronts, plus rotating exhibitions that illuminate daily life, work, and community across the late 19th and early 20th centuries. The site tells the stories of families from Jewish, Italian, Irish, German, and other immigrant backgrounds, highlighting resilience, culture, and the immigrant journey in America.

Name: Lyndon B Johnson National Historical Park
Description: This region that honors President Lyndon B. Johnson consists of two units in the Texas Hill Country. The Boyhood Home unit in Johnson City preserves Johnson’s family home, school, and surrounding farmstead, offering a window into his early years. The Ranch unit near Stonewall preserves the expansive LBJ Ranch, once known as the Texas White House, with working cattle lands, historic structures, and sweeping views of the rolling prairie. Scenic drives and backcountry trails reveal the landscape that shaped a president, while wildlife such as white-tailed deer, roadrunners, and a variety of birds roam the countryside.

Name: Maggie L Walker National Historic Site
Description: This urban historic site in Richmond, Virginia preserves the home and business of Maggie L. Walker, a pioneering African American entrepreneur and civil rights leader who became the United States’ first female Black bank president. Located in the Jackson Ward neighborhood, the site features a restored early 20th-century residence, Walker’s office, period furnishings, and exhibits that illuminate her leadership, banking career, and the community she helped empower.

Name: Maine Acadian Culture
Description: This region that preserves Maine Acadian Culture consists of a park of three units along the Downeast coast and inland waterways. Besides preserved Acadian fishing villages and historic cultural sites, there are scenic drives and backcountry hiking opportunities through pine forests, tidal marshes, and rocky shores. Wildlife includes moose, black bears, white-tailed deer, beavers, harbor seals, and bald eagles.

Name: Mammoth Cave National Park
Description: This region preserves the world's longest known cave system beneath the rolling hills of central Kentucky. Beyond the cave corridors, surface forests, karst landscapes, and the Green River valley offer hiking, canoeing, and scenic overlooks near cave entrances. Wildlife includes bats, white-tailed deer, beavers, and other cave- and forest-dwelling State Parkecies.

Name: Manassas National Military Park
Description: This region near Manassas, Virginia, preserves two major Civil War battlefield units marking the First and Second Battles of Bull Run. The landscapes include rolling farmland, woodlands, creeks, and open meadows where earthworks, trenches, and artillery positions still define the campaigns. Auto tours and a network of walking trails connect two visitor centers that interpret the fighting, soldiers, and civilian experiences of 1861–1865. Memorials and living-history programs bring to life the people whose actions shaped the course of the war.

Name: Manhattan Project National Historical Park
Description: Manhattan Project National Historical Park State Parkans three units in Washington, New Mexico, and Tennessee. It protects Hanford’s B Reactor and other plutonium-production facilities along the Columbia River, the Los Alamos Laboratory complex and surrounding town where bomb design and wartime science occurred, and Oak Ridge’s early uranium-enrichment facilities and the X-10 Graphite Reactor. The park preserves the people, places, and technologies that launched the nuclear age, with historic sites, museums, tours, and interpretive programs that tell the WWII-era story of science, war, and peace.

Name: Manzanar National Historic Site
Description: Manzanar National Historic Site sits in the Owens Valley of eastern California, preserving the World War II Japanese American internment camp at Manzanar. The site centers on the original living areas, guard towers, the cemetery, and the Jeannette Rankin Visitors Center, with exhibits that tell the stories of those interned and the broader history of civil liberties during wartime. The surrounding high-desert landscape features sagebrush flats and pinyon‑juniper woodlands with distant views of the Sierra Nevada; wildlife includes mule deer, jackrabbits, coyotes, and a variety of raptors.

Name: Marsh - Billings - Rockefeller National Historical Park
Description: Nestled in Vermont's Green Mountains, Marsh-Billings-Rockefeller National Historical Park preserves the historic Marsh and Billings estates and the landscape that helped State Parkawn the American conservation movement. The park features a 19th-century mansion, restored farm buildings, formal and informal gardens, and miles of woodland and meadow trails that illustrate sustainable farming and forest management. Guided tours and exhibits tell how private landownership and philanthropic leadership shaped national conservation policy.

Name: Martin Luther King, Jr. Memorial
Description: This memorial honoring civil rights leader Martin Luther King Jr. sits along the National Mall in Washington, D.C. The centerpiece is a 30-foot granite statue of King rising from the Stone of Hope, with a wall of his quotes lining the path for reflection. The surrounding landscape includes reflecting pools and open lawns framed by other monuments, offering a contemplative setting in the heart of the capital.

Name: Martin Luther King, Jr. National Historical Park
Description: This urban historic district in Atlanta, Georgia, preserves the landmarks that shaped Martin Luther King Jr.’s life and the Civil Rights Movement. The Martin Luther King Jr. National Historical Park comprises the Birth Home, Ebenezer Baptist Church, and the King Center campus, including the tombs of MLK and Coretta Scott King and exhibits on nonviolent social change. Visitors can explore the Auburn Avenue area by foot, take guided tours or ranger-led programs, and reflect on King’s enduring legacy of justice, equality, and peaceful protest.

Name: Martin Van Buren National Historic Site
Description: This region that shaped President Martin Van Buren centers on Lindenwald, the well-preserved 19th-century home and farm in Kinderhook, New York. The surrounding Hudson Valley countryside features rolling farmland, woodlands, and historic villages that echo early American life and political leadership. Wildlife includes white-tailed deer, red-tailed hawks, and a variety of songbirds.

Name: Mary McLeod Bethune Council House National Historic Site
Description: An urban historic site in downtown Washington, D.C., Mary McLeod Bethune Council House National Historic Site preserves the townhouse where Bethune lived, organized, and mentored generations of Black women leaders in the early 20th century. Exhibits and programs illuminate her lifelong work in education, civil rights, and leadership development, and the founding of the National Council of Negro Women.

Name: Medgar and Myrlie Evers Home National Monument
Description: Located in Jackson, Mississippi, Medgar and Myrlie Evers Home National Monument preserves the modest residence where civil rights leader Medgar Evers lived with his wife, Myrlie Evers, from 1951 until his assassination in 1963, and the surrounding neighborhood that bore witness to the modern Civil Rights Movement. The restored home honors Evers’s work with the NAACP and his efforts to secure voting rights and justice for African Americans, offering visitors a tangible link to a pivotal chapter in American history.

Name: Mesa Verde National Park
Description: Located in the southwestern Colorado high desert, Mesa Verde National Park preserves thousands of Ancestral Puebloan archaeological sites carved into cliff faces and perched on broad mesas. Famed cliff dwellings such as Cliff Palace, Square Tower, and Balcony House illustrate a sophisticated culture built into the sandstone alcoves amid deep canyons and expansive plateaus. Habitats range from pinyon-juniper woodlands and ponderosa pine forests to sagebrush grasslands, supporting mule deer, coyotes, and a rich variety of birds.

Name: Mill State Parkrings Battlefield National Monument
Description: This Civil War battlefield site in central Kentucky preserves Mill State Parkrings Battlefield National Monument. Besides the battlefield itself, there is a visitor center with exhibits and interpretive trails through rolling farmland and woodlands. Wildlife includes white-tailed deer, wild turkeys, red foxes, and a variety of songbirds.

Name: Minidoka National Historic Site
Description: This arid landscape along the Snake River Plain preserves the Minidoka War Relocation Center, a World War II internment camp where Japanese Americans were detained. The site features the footprints of barracks, mess halls, guard towers, and irrigation canals, with a visitor center and interpretive trails that recount the experiences of incarcerees and the broader wartime context. Sagebrush-steppe habitat surrounds the area, supporting wildlife such as pronghorn, mule deer, red-tailed hawks, and coyotes.

Name: Minute Man National Historical Park
Description: Minute Man National Historical Park preserves a historic landscape along the Battle Road through Concord, Lexington, and Lincoln, Massachusetts, where the opening battles of the American Revolution began. The park highlights Lexington Green, the Old North Bridge at Concord, and surrounding colonial farms, stone walls, and battlefield sites such as Hartwell Tavern and The Wayside along its preserved trails. Visitors can walk the Battle Road, participate in living-history events, and reflect on 18th-century life amid woodlands, meadows, and river corridors that helped forge the United States.

Name: Minuteman Missile National Historic Site
Description: Two remote plains in western South Dakota carry a pivotal chapter of the Cold War. Minuteman Missile National Historic Site protects an intact missile alert facility and two underground launch facilities, offering tours that reveal how the United States maintained strategic deterrence during the missile age. The rolling prairie hosts wildlife such as pronghorn, coyotes, and prairie dogs among sagebrush and tall grass under expansive skies.

Name: Mississippi National River & Recreation Area
Description: The Mississippi National River and Recreation Area runs along a 72-mile stretch of the Mississippi River in Minnesota, linking the Twin Cities with river towns and wild river valleys. From urban riverfronts to forested bluffs and backcountry trails, it preserves a living landscape of parks, historic sites, locks and dams, and opportunities for hiking, biking, paddling, and sightseeing. Wildlife includes bald eagles, oState Parkreys, river otters, beavers, and a variety of migratory waterfowl.

Name: Missouri National Recreational National River
Description: Two long, undeveloped reaches of the Missouri River in Nebraska and South Dakota preserve a braided-river landscape with sandbars, backwaters, and floodplain forests. The area offers canoeing and kayaking, fishing, birdwatching, and short hikes along scenic shorelines and historic river-town remnants.

Name: Mojave National Preserve
Description: This vast preserve protects a mosaic of Mojave Desert landscapes in southern California, State Parkanning rolling sand dunes, rugged badlands, granite ridges, and Joshua tree woodlands. Highlights include the towering Kelso Dunes, the expansive Cima Dome Joshua tree forest, and dramatic lava beds and volcanic cones, with scenic drives and backcountry hiking opportunities. Wildlife includes desert tortoise, bighorn sheep, kit fox, and roadrunners.

Name: Monocacy National Military Park
Description: Monocacy National Military Park preserves a pivotal Civil War battlefield along the Monocacy River in Maryland, where Union and Confederate forces clashed on July 9, 1864. The rolling farmland and woodlands feature preserved earthworks, historic farmsteads, and a visitor center with exhibits, living history programs, and driving and walking tours. Wildlife includes white-tailed deer, red fox, gray squirrels, and a variety of birds.

Name: Montezuma Castle National Monument
Description: This arid valley in central Arizona preserves one of the best-preserved Sinagua cliff dwellings along with an ancient irrigation complex. Montezuma Castle National Monument includes the cliff dwelling at Montezuma Castle and Montezuma Well, a natural limestone sinkhole with an enduring irrigation network. Desert wildlife includes mule deer, coyotes, jackrabbits, and a variety of birds.

Name: Moores Creek National Military Park
Description: This coastal North Carolina battlefield preserves the site of the 1776 Battle of Moores Creek Bridge, a pivotal Patriot victory in the American Revolution. The park centers on the preserved 18th‑century wooden bridge and the surrounding battlefield landscape, with a visitor center and a short self-guided loop that traces the marshy banks and open fields where troops fought. Salt marsh and maritime forest habitats host wading birds and other coastal wildlife.

Name: Mormon Pioneer National Trail
Description: Extending roughly 1,300 miles from the Missouri River to the Salt Lake Valley, the Mormon Pioneer National Historic Trail follows the route used by members of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints during their mid-19th-century migration west. The trail crosses plains, river valleys, rolling hills, deserts, and mountain passes, tracing a journey of religious freedom and settlement. Along the route are wagon ruts, river crossings, campsites, and landmarks that illustrate the challenges faced by thousands of emigrants traveling by wagon and handcart. Landscapes range from tallgrass prairie to high-elevation basins and alpine terrain, supporting wildlife such as pronghorn, mule deer, bison, coyotes, and migratory birds, while offering opportunities for historical exploration, hiking, and scenic driving across the American West.

Name: Morristown National Historical Park
Description: This historic landscape preserves the Revolutionary War winter encampments and the headquarters that helped shape the nation’s founding. Within Morristown National Historical Park, Washington’s Headquarters at the Ford Mansion anchors the site, with the expansive Jockey Hollow encampment, historic farmsteads, and woodland trails illustrating 18th‑century life. Wildlife includes white-tailed deer, foxes, and a variety of birds, and the park offers interpretive programs, guided tours, and living-history demonstrations.

Name: Mount Rainier National Park
Description: Mount Rainier National Park sits in the Cascade Range of Washington state, protecting an iconic 14,411-foot active stratovolcano. Glaciers crown the summit and sculpt the landscape, while lush old-growth forests, subalpine meadows, and alpine tundra State Parkan the park’s diverse habitats, with scenic drives and backcountry hiking opportunities. Wildlife includes black bears, mountain goats, elk, marmots, and pikas.

Name: Mount Rushmore National Memorial
Description: Carved into the granite face of the Black Hills near Keystone, Mount Rushmore National Memorial features the 60-foot‑tall likenesses of George Washington, Thomas Jefferson, Theodore Roosevelt, and Abraham Lincoln. The site sits among pine-filled hills with the Sculptor’s Studio, a visitor center, and the Presidential Trail offering close-up views and sweeping panoramas of the surrounding landscape. Wildlife in the area includes mule deer, pronghorn, and a variety of birds.

Name: Muir Woods National Monument
Description: This coastal redwood sanctuary just north of San Francisco protects an ancient grove of coastal redwoods, moss-draped canyons, and tranquil creeks. In Muir Woods National Monument, towering trees rise over fern-filled understories along accessible trails and wooden boardwalks that reveal the forest’s timeless beauty. Habitats include old-growth coastal redwood forest, riparian corridors along streams, and sheltered ravines within a protected woodland setting.
