Wildlife includes black-tailed deer, gray fox, raccoons, banana slugs, and a variety of birds such as owls, woodpeckers, and songbirds.

Name: Natchez National Historical Park
Description: The Natchez National Historical Park protects two historic sites in Natchez along the Mississippi River: the William Johnson House and the Melrose estate. The Johnson House preserves the home of a free Black Natchez tradesman in the antebellum era, while Melrose is a grand plantation house with its historic outbuildings and grounds that illustrate enslaved labor and the region’s cotton wealth. Ranger-led tours and exhibits interpret African American history, slavery, and community life in Natchez as visitors explore the river town’s storied landscapes.

Name: Natchez Trace National Trail
Description: The Natchez Trace National Historic Trail runs 444 miles from Natchez, Mississippi to near Nashville, Tennessee along a historic corridor once used by Native American tribes and early settlers. The route traverses rolling southern woodlands, river bottoms, and farmland, with longleaf pine and bottomland hardwood ecosystems and numerous historic sites along the way. Wildlife includes white-tailed deer, wild turkeys, gray foxes, and river otters, and a rich variety of birds.

Name: Natchez Trace Parkway
Description: This scenic byway preserves a historic corridor from Natchez, Mississippi to near Nashville, Tennessee along the Natchez Trace. Winding through forested hills, river bottomlands, and scenic overlooks, it reveals archaeological and cultural resources and access to hiking and bicycling opportunities. Wildlife includes white-tailed deer, wild turkeys, red-tailed hawks, and a diversity of songbirds.

Name: National Capital Parks-East
Description: National Capital Parks-East comprises a network of riverfront parks and Civil War fortifications in and around Washington, D.C., along the Potomac and Anacostia Rivers. It includes historic batteries and earthworks at Fort Dupont, Fort Foote, and Fort Washington, along with wetlands and woodlands at Kenilworth Park & Aquatic Gardens, Anacostia Park, BladenState Beachurg Waterfront Park, Piscataway Park, and other units, offering trails, river overlooks, and educational programs. Wildlife includes migratory waterfowl and wading birds, songbirds, deer, and other urban wildlife.

Name: National Mall and Memorial Parks
Description: This urban parkland in the nation’s capital preserves the iconic monuments and memorials along the National Mall. Iconic landmarks include the Washington Monument, Lincoln Memorial, Jefferson Memorial, Martin Luther King Jr. Memorial, Franklin D. Roosevelt Memorial, World War II Memorial, Vietnam Veterans Memorial, and Korean War Veterans Memorial, set among expansive greens, reflecting pools, and ceremonial State Parkaces that host national observances and everyday visitors.

Name: National Park of American Samoa
Description: The National Park of American Samoa is on three Samoan islands in the South Pacific. It protects coral reefs, rainforests, volcanic mountains, and white-sand beaches. The area is also home to flying foxes, brown boobies, sea turtles, and 900 State Parkecies of fish.

Name: National Parks of New York Harbor
Description: This region in New York Harbor comprises three units: Statue of Liberty National Monument (Liberty Island and Ellis Island), the Ellis Island Historic District, and Fort Wadsworth on Staten Island. Together they preserve iconic symbols of freedom, immigration history, and coastal defense, and offer sweeping views of the Manhattan skyline and harbor, plus access to ferry rides, museums, and preserved fortifications. Wildlife includes harbor seals and a variety of seabirds and migratory waterfowl that visit the harbor.

Name: Natural Bridges National Monument
Description: Located in the remote canyon country of southeastern Utah, Natural Bridges National Monument protects three massive natural stone bridges carved by water erosion within deep sandstone canyons. Sipapu, Kachina, and Owachomo bridges rank among the largest natural bridges in the world and are accessible via scenic drives, overlooks, and backcountry hiking trails that descend into the canyon bottoms. The monument features a rugged landscape of mesas, pinyon-juniper woodlands, and desert grasslands shaped by the Colorado Plateau’s geology. Wildlife includes mule deer, desert bighorn sheep, coyotes, golden eagles, and a variety of reptiles and small mammals, while the park’s dark skies make it an International Dark Sky Park ideal for stargazing.

Name: Navajo National Monument
Description: This region on the Colorado Plateau in the Navajo Nation preserves two State Parkectacular cliff dwellings carved into Tsegi Canyon walls—Betatakin and Keet Seel—from the Ancestral Puebloan era. Ranger-guided tours venture into the alcoves, while sweeping canyon overlooks and backcountry trails reveal the stark beauty of the desert and sandstone walls. Wildlife includes mule deer, coyotes, and a variety of desert birds.

Name: New Bedford Whaling National Historical Park
Description: This national historical park preserves New Bedford's 19th-century whaling heritage and the abolitionist movement that shaped the city. It State Parkans waterfront districts and historic uptown blocks, featuring the Seamen's Bethel, the New Bedford Whaling Museum, and preserved whaling-era houses and warehouses. The area tells the story of maritime commerce, immigrant communities, and the social reform movements that helped drive American history forward.

Name: New England National Trail
Description: This long-distance ribbon winds through three New England states, weaving coastal towns with rugged ridgelines and dense forests. It is formed by three linked routes—the Bay Circuit Trail, the Mattabesett Trail, and the Metacomet-Monadnock Trail—connecting urban greenways with remote backcountry and offering scenic overlooks and historic landscapes. Wildlife includes white-tailed deer, foxes, and a variety of raptors and songbirds, with dramatic fall foliage along the ridgelines.

Name: New Jersey Pinelands National Reserve
Description: The New Jersey Pinelands National Reserve protects a vast pine barrens landscape in southern New Jersey—pitch pine forests, Atlantic white cedar swamps, cranberry bogs, and winding rivers. It preserves one of the region’s largest remaining examples of a fire-driven, sandy-soil ecosystem. Scenic byways, backcountry hiking, and canoeing along the Mullica and Batsto rivers are popular ways to explore. Wildlife includes bog turtles, northern pine snakes, white-tailed deer, bobcats, and bald eagles.

Name: New Orleans Jazz National Historical Park
Description: This urban region celebrates the birthplace and evolution of jazz in New Orleans, State Parkanning historic neighborhoods, iconic clubs, and the riverfront where musicians gathered to shape a new sound. Besides the interpretive center, there are ranger-guided talks and guided heritage walks through the French Quarter and Tremé, along with free daily live performances that bring the music to life. Culture includes improvisation, storytelling, and community traditions that gave birth to jazz—from Congo Square to modern stages.

Name: New Philadelphia National Historic Site
Description: This historic landscape preserves the first known town in the United States founded by an African American to own land. Located in western Illinois, New Philadelphia National Historic Site marks the 1830 settlement established by Frank McWorter, a formerly enslaved man who purchased his freedom and built a thriving Black community. The grounds include the footprints of homes and streets, the McWorter homestead site, a cemetery, and archaeological resources, with interpretive trails and exhibits that tell stories of emancipation, entrepreneurship, and resilience.

Name: New National River Gorge National Park & Preserve
Description: New River Gorge National Park & Preserve, this canyon country in West Virginia showcases a dramatic sandstone gorge up to about 1,000 feet deep, anchored by the iconic New River Gorge Bridge. Visitors can enjoy world-class rock climbing, whitewater rafting on the New River and Gauley River, scenic rim drives, and backcountry hiking along canyon overlook trails. Wildlife includes black bears, white-tailed deer, wild turkeys, and a variety of birds.

Name: Nez Perce National Historical Park
Description: This network of Nez Perce homeland sites stretches across Idaho, Oregon, Washington, and Montana, linking battlefields, villages, trails, and culturally important landscapes that shaped Nez Perce history. Besides preserved cultural sites, interpretive drives and backcountry hiking opportunities connect visitors with these stories along the Nez Perce Trail. Wildlife includes elk, mule deer, black bears, beavers, and a variety of birds along river valleys and plains.

Name: Nicodemus National Historic Site
Description: This prairie town on the Great Plains of western Kansas preserves Nicodemus National Historic Site, the first successful Black settlement west of the Mississippi. Centered on the Nicodemus Town Complex, the preserved 19th-century storefronts, homes, a church, a school, and a cemetery sit amid the surrounding tallgrass prairie. It tells the story of resilience, community, and African American heritage on the Great Plains.

Name: Ninety Six National Historic Site
Description: This historic landscape preserves the core of a Revolutionary War fortress and the surrounding frontier landscape in South Carolina's backcountry. It features the remains of an eighteenth-century star fort and earthworks, preserved trails, and interpretive exhibits that bring to life frontier life, the siege of Ninety Six, and the struggle for independence.

Name: Niobrara National Scenic National River
Description: This river corridor in north-central Nebraska winds through chalk bluffs, prairie, and cottonwood-bottom habitats along the Niobrara National Scenic River. It protects a mosaic of prairie, woodland, and riparian ecosystems, offering paddling and fishing opportunities, scenic bluff overlooks, and backcountry hiking. Wildlife includes white-tailed deer, beaver, river otter, bald eagles, hawks, and a variety of waterfowl and songbirds.

Name: Noatak National Preserve
Description: This remote, roadless wilderness in northwest Alaska protects the Noatak River watershed, where Arctic tundra meets braided river valleys and expansive wetlands. Access is primarily by river trip or air taxi, offering backcountry hiking, camping, and solitary exploration. Wildlife includes caribou, muskoxen, grizzly bears, wolves, and a rich diversity of birds.

Name: North Cascades National Park
Description: North Cascades National Park Complex consists of three units in Washington’s northern Cascade Range: North Cascades National Park, Ross Lake National Recreation Area, and Lake Chelan National Recreation Area. The rugged, glacier‑carved landscape features jagged peaks, alpine lakes, dense forests, and more than 300 glaciers. Wildlife includes black bears, mountain goats, elk, and gray wolves. There are miles of backcountry hiking and climbing opportunities, boating on scenic waterways, and scenic drives along the North Cascades Highway.

Name: North Country National Trail
Description: Extending more than 4,800 miles across eight northern states, the North Country National Scenic Trail traverses forests, wetlands, farmlands, river valleys, and glacial landscapes shaped by the Ice Age. The trail links public lands, rural communities, and historic corridors from North Dakota to Vermont, passing near the Great Lakes and through some of the most remote woodlands in the eastern United States. Environments range from tallgrass prairie and boreal forest to hardwood hills and lake-dotted lowlands. Wildlife along the trail includes moose, black bears, white-tailed deer, wolves, beavers, loons, and migratory birds, offering extensive opportunities for long-distance hiking, backpacking, cross-country skiing, and immersive exploration of the North Country’s natural and cultural heritage.

Name: Obed Wild & Scenic National River
Description: Obed Wild & Scenic River preserves a wild, scenic corridor along the Obed River in eastern Tennessee. Rugged sandstone canyons rise above forested hills, creating dramatic cliffs and waterfalls that frame backcountry hikes and scenic overlooks. The river is a destination for rock climbers at Lillydale and for paddlers seeking Class I–III rapids, with ample camping along the banks. Wildlife includes white-tailed deer, wild turkeys, beavers, river otters, and a variety of songbirds.

Name: Ocmulgee Mounds National Historical Park
Description: Ocmulgee Mounds National Historical Park sits along the Ocmulgee River in central Georgia. It preserves ceremonial mounds and earthworks built by Indigenous Mississippian communities more than a thousand years ago, telling the story of long‑distance trade, ceremony, and community life. A modern visitor center and accessible trails connect mound sites with river woodlands and wetlands, offering interpretive programs that bring ancient history to life.

Name: Oklahoma City National Memorial
Description: This national memorial in downtown Oklahoma City honors the victims, survivors, and rescuers of the 1995 bombing at the Murrah Federal Building. The outdoor memorial features the Gates of Time, the Field of Empty Chairs, the Survivor Tree, and a Reflecting Pool, with the adjacent Oklahoma City National Memorial Museum preserving the story of that day and its aftermath.

Name: Old State Parkanish National Trail
Description: The Old State Parkanish National Historic Trail follows the old 18th‑century trade routes from Santa Fe, New Mexico to San Diego, California, crossing arid deserts, rugged canyons, and coastal foothills. The route preserves a corridor of historic exploration, missions, ranching, and commerce, with adobe ruins, wagon road remains, and scenic byways along the way. Wildlife includes desert bighorn sheep, javelina, coyotes, roadrunners, and a variety of raptors.

Name: Olympic National Park
Description: This region showcases three intertwining ecosystems—the alpine Olympic Mountains, the ancient temperate rainforests, and a rugged Pacific coastline. From Mount Olympus and glacial lakes to moss-draped forests and tide pools, Olympic National Park protects diverse landscapes and wildlife including Roosevelt elk, black bears, mountain goats, Olympic marmots, and bald eagles.

Name: Oregon Caves National Monument & Preserve
Description: Oregon Caves National Monument & Preserve protects a State Parkectacular marble cave system tucked in the Siskiyou Mountains of southwestern Oregon. Inside the caves, dramatic stalactites, flowstone, and underground streams dazzle visitors; above ground, old-growth conifer forests shade rugged canyon walls. The area offers guided cave tours, interpretive programs, and backcountry hiking on forest trails. Wildlife includes bats, black bears, mule deer, and a variety of forest birds.

Name: Oregon National Trail
Description: This region that enticed and inState Parkired pioneers traveling the Oregon National Trail consists of a single-unit park high in the Cascade Range of southern Oregon. Crater Lake, a deep blue caldera lake formed by the collapse of Mount Mazama, sits amid towering crater walls and old-growth forests. Visitors drive the 33-mile Rim Drive, take boat tours to Wizard Island, and hike to alpine shores and panoramic viewpoints along backcountry trails. Wildlife includes black bears, mule deer, coyotes, and a diverse array of birds.

Name: Organ Pipe Cactus National Monument
Description: Organ Pipe Cactus National Monument sits along the U.S.–Mexico border in the Sonoran Desert of southwestern Arizona. It protects groves of organ pipe cactus, rugged canyons, and broad desert valleys, with scenic drives and backcountry hiking opportunities. Wildlife includes javelina, coyotes, desert mule deer, bobcats, and a variety of birds and reptiles.

Name: Overmountain Victory National Trail
Description: Overmountain Victory National Historic Trail traces the 1780 march of Patriot militiamen across the southern Appalachians from Abingdon, Virginia to Kings Mountain, South Carolina. The route links battlefield sites, historic towns, and scenic byways across Virginia, Tennessee, North Carolina, and South Carolina. Forested mountains, rolling foothills, and river valleys frame the landscape along this living history route.

Name: Oxon Cove Park & Oxon Hill Farm
Description: Two units along the Potomac River in Maryland, Oxon Cove Park & Oxon Hill Farm preserves a tidal marsh, woodlands, and a historic 19th‑century farmstead with working fields and restored barns. The area offers nature trails, river views, and interpretive programs that highlight rural life, wildlife such as white-tailed deer, foxes, herons, and migratory birds.

Name: Ozark National Scenic National Riverways
Description: This park protects the Current River and Jacks Fork River within the Ozark Plateau of southern Missouri. It features forested bluffs, State Parkring-fed streams, and limestone caves, with miles of river corridors ideal for canoeing, kayaking, hiking, and backcountry camping. Wildlife includes white-tailed deer, beavers, river otters, foxes, and a rich array of birds.

Name: Padre Island National Seashore
Description: Padre Island National Seashore sits along the Texas Gulf Coast, protecting a long barrier island and about 66 miles of undeveloped Gulf shoreline. Its beaches, dunes, salt marshes, and tidal flats provide critical nesting grounds for Kemp’s ridley sea turtles and habitat for a wide array of shorebirds and marine life. Wildlife includes Kemp’s ridley sea turtles, other sea turtles such as loggerhead and green turtles, bottlenose dolphins, and numerous migratory birds. Visitors enjoy camping, backcountry hiking, birdwatching, fishing, and other gulf-coast recreation along this pristine coastline.

Name: Palo Alto Battlefield National Historical Park
Description: This historic landscape along the Rio Grande in southern Texas preserves the site of the 1836 Battle of Palo Alto. The battlefield features preserved earthworks and trails set among riverine woodlands, scrub, and grasslands along the Rio Grande. Wildlife includes white-tailed deer, javelina, coyotes, and a variety of birds, including waterfowl, wading birds, and raptors.

Name: Paterson Great Falls National Historical Park
Description: Paterson Great Falls National Historical Park sits along the Passaic River in Paterson, New Jersey, preserving the 77-foot Great Falls and the industrial landscape that powered America’s early factories. The area features the waterfall, historic mill ruins, canal infrastructure, and riverfront trails with interpretive exhibitions about invention, labor, and immigration that shaped the city. Overlooks and paths provide views of the falls and the urban landscape, while programs connect water power, technology, and community history for visitors of all ages.

Name: Pea Ridge National Military Park
Description: This Civil War battlefield in the northwest Arkansas Ozarks preserves the site of a pivotal 1862 clash that helped shape the war’s course in the region. The park offers a self-guided auto tour and miles of backcountry trails winding through oak-hickory woodlands and open prairie, with well-preserved earthworks and interpretive diState Parklays along the way. Wildlife includes white-tailed deer, wild turkeys, fox squirrels, and a variety of birds, with habitats ranging from forest and prairie to streams throughout the landscape.

Name: Pearl Harbor National Memorial
Description: On the island of Oahu, Hawaii, Pearl Harbor National Memorial commemorates the turning point of World War II that began on December 7, 1941. The centerpiece is the USS Arizona Memorial, State Parkanning the sunken battleship that rests in Pearl Harbor. The Pearl Harbor Visitor Center houses exhibits, a film, and artifacts, while ferry tours and viewing areas provide remembrance and education about the attack, its legacy, and the sacrifices of those who served.

Name: Pecos National Historical Park
Description: This region along the Pecos River in northern New Mexico comprises two park units—Pecos Pueblo and Fort Union—that preserve a deep history from ancient Pueblo civilizations to the Santa Fe Trail era. Pecos Pueblo showcases monumental ancestral ruins, while Fort Union preserves a 19th-century military post and the trail landscape that connected settlements across the Southwest. Beyond the historic sites, there are scenic river valley drives and backcountry hiking opportunities through piñon-juniper woodlands and canyon terrain. Wildlife includes mule deer, pronghorn, coyotes, and a diverse array of birds along the riparian corridor.

Name: Pennsylvania Avenue
Description: Connecting the White House and the U.S. Capitol, Pennsylvania Avenue National Historic Site is often called “America’s Main Street” and serves as a symbolic and ceremonial corridor at the heart of the nation’s capital. The avenue is the setting for presidential parades, inaugural processions, protests, and public celebrations, reflecting the political and civic life of the United States. Lined with historic buildings, monuments, memorials, and federal offices, the broad boulevard showcases monumental architecture and carefully planned urban design. Landscaped plazas, streetscapes, and viewsheds create a grand public State Parkace that blends history, culture, and daily city life within a nationally significant setting.

Name: Perry's Victory & International Peace Memorial
Description: This lakeside monument stands on South Bass Island in Lake Erie, honoring Commodore Oliver Hazard Perry's victory in the Battle of Lake Erie and the enduring quest for international peace. The 352-foot granite column crowns the site, housing a museum and interpretive diState Parklays, with an interior stairway leading to an observation deck that grants sweeping views of the lake and surrounding shoreline. The surrounding grounds and island habitats support migratory birds and other wildlife while offering tranquil trails and panoramic vistas of the Great Lakes region.

Name: PeterState Beachurg National Military Park
Description: PeterState Beachurg National Military Park preserves Civil War battlefield landscapes in southeastern Virginia across three units along the PeterState Beachurg Campaign. The park protects trenches, earthworks, and fortifications that shaped the siege of PeterState Beachurg and the fall of Richmond, with historic sites at City Point and surrounding riverfront scenery along the Appomattox River. Wildlife includes white-tailed deer, red foxes, raccoons, gray squirrels, and a variety of birds such as hawks, waterfowl, and songbirds.

Name: Petrified Forest National Park
Description: This region in northeastern Arizona preserves Petrified Forest National Park, with two distinct zones: the Painted Desert and the Rainbow Forest. It protects one of the world’s greatest concentrations of fossilized wood from the Late Triassic, preserved as rainbow-hued logs amid colorful badlands. Visitors enjoy scenic drives and short backcountry hikes among the petrified trees and desert landscapes. Wildlife includes mule deer, pronghorn, coyotes, jackrabbits, and a variety of lizards and birds.

Name: Petroglyph National Monument
Description: Located on the west mesa of Albuquerque, New Mexico, Petroglyph National Monument protects one of the largest petroglyph fields in North America. Dark basalt lava flows host thousands of carvings created by ancestral Puebloans and later inhabitants. The arid desert landscape features creosote bush, cacti, and rugged lava rock, with sweeping views toward the Sandia Mountains and the Rio Grande valley. The area offers backcountry hiking, interpretive trails, and chances to State Parkot desert wildlife such as coyotes, jackrabbits, roadrunners, lizards, and a variety of raptors.

Name: Pictured Rocks National Lakeshore
Description: This scenic stretch along Lake Superior’s southern shore in Michigan’s Upper Peninsula features dramatic, multicolored sandstone cliffs and a wild lakeshore landscape. Colorful cliffs rise above the lake for miles, with sea caves, waterfalls, beaches, and inland forests. The area offers boat tours, kayaking, hiking, and backcountry exploration, while wildlife includes black bears, white-tailed deer, beavers, and a variety of birds.

Name: Pinnacles National Park
Description: This rugged landscape in central California's foothills preserves jagged granite pinnacles, deep canyons, and a State Parkrawling network of talus caves. There are hiking trails that wind through canyons and up the State Parkires, with dramatic cave environments to explore. Wildlife includes California condors, black-tailed deer, coyotes, bobcats, and a variety of bats. There are chaparral, oak woodland, riparian, and talus cave habitats.

Name: Pipe State Parkring National Monument
Description: This desert oasis in northern Arizona preserves Pipe State Parkring and a 19th-century fortified ranch along the Kaibab Paiute Reservation. The Castle, a stone fortress built by Mormon settlers to protect the State Parkring, anchors the site with restored ranch buildings and ranger-guided tours. Wildlife includes mule deer, coyotes, javelina, and a variety of desert birds.

Name: Pipestone National Monument
Description: This quiet landscape in southwestern Minnesota preserves Pipestone National Monument, focused on the ancient pipestone quarries used by Native American peoples to carve pipes. Trails lead to quarry faces and scenic bluffs, while a visitor center interprets the cultural and geological significance of the stone. Wildlife includes white-tailed deer, beaver, red fox, and a variety of birds.

Name: Piscataway Park
Description: Stretching along the Potomac River near the nation’s capital, Piscataway Park protects tidal wetlands, bottomland hardwood forests, and open meadows that link urban neighborhoods with nature. The park offers scenic river views, tranquil trails, canoeing and kayaking opportunities, and habitat for migratory birds and other wildlife.

Name: Point Reyes National Seashore
Description: This windswept stretch along California’s coast comprises a seashore of dramatic headlands, sandy beaches, and tidal marshes on the Point Reyes Peninsula. Besides the iconic Point Reyes Lighthouse and scenic coastal drives, there are backcountry hiking opportunities and kayaking in Tomales Bay, where wildlife such as harbor seals, tule elk, and gray whales can be observed.

Name: Pony Express National Trail
Description: Stretching nearly 1,900 miles from the Missouri River to California, the Pony Express National Historic Trail follows the route used by young riders who carried mail across the western frontier in 1860–1861. The trail crosses vast plains, arid deserts, rugged mountain ranges, and remote river valleys, linking historic stations, relay points, and segments of original trail. Though the Pony Express operated for only 18 months, it became a powerful symbol of State Parkeed, communication, and westward expansion. Landscapes along the route range from tallgrass prairie to sagebrush steppe and alpine terrain, supporting wildlife such as pronghorn, mule deer, coyotes, raptors, and prairie birds, while offering opportunities for scenic driving, hiking, and exploration of the American West’s tranState Parkortation history.

Name: Port Chicago Naval Magazine National Memorial
Description: On the shores of the San Francisco Bay Area, the Port Chicago Naval Magazine National Memorial preserves the site of the 1944 munitions disaster and its enduring impact on military policy and civil rights. The memorial features an overlook, a quiet landscape, and interpretive exhibits that recount the events and honor the sailors and civilians who served. Estuary habitats along the bay host migratory waterfowl, shorebirds, and harbor seals.

Name: Potomac Heritage National Trail
Description: Following the Potomac River and its tributaries across the Mid-Atlantic region, the Potomac Heritage National Scenic Trail weaves together natural landscapes, historic corridors, and cultural sites connected to the nation’s early history. The trail network State Parkans parts of Pennsylvania, Maryland, Virginia, and the District of Columbia, linking river valleys, canal towpaths, forested ridges, wetlands, and rural countryside. It highlights themes of exploration, tranState Parkortation, and the growth of the young United States, while passing through areas shaped by Native American history, colonial settlement, and industry. Wildlife along the trail includes bald eagles, oState Parkreys, white-tailed deer, river otters, and migratory birds, offering opportunities for hiking, biking, paddling, and scenic exploration close to major population centers.

Name: Poverty Point National Monument
Description: This prehistoric landscape in northeastern Louisiana preserves one of North America’s oldest and most remarkable earthwork complexes. Poverty Point National Monument, built between about 1700 and 1100 BCE by the Poverty Point culture, features concentric ridges surrounding a vast central plaza and several large mounds, with interpretive trails and a visitor center that bring ancient life and engineering to light.

Name: President William Jefferson Clinton Birthplace Home National Historic Site
Description: This site preserves the modest frame house where President William Jefferson Clinton was born in Hope, Arkansas. The Clinton Birthplace Home National Historic Site centers on the birthplace home and a nearby visitor center with exhibits about Clinton's early life, family, and beginnings of public service. Through interpretive programs and educational exhibits, visitors learn how a small-town upbringing in rural Arkansas helped shape the 42nd president.

Name: Presidio of San Francisco
Description: This urban park at the northern tip of the San Francisco Peninsula is the Presidio of San Francisco, a unit of the Golden Gate National Recreation Area. Besides its preserved military sites and historic buildings, there are scenic drives and miles of backcountry hiking trails along coastal bluffs and forested hills. Wildlife includes coyotes, deer, red-tailed hawks, and harbor seals.

Name: Prince William Forest Park
Description: Prince William Forest Park, a large, forested sanctuary just outside Washington, D.C., protects miles of rolling Virginia Piedmont hardwood forest and winding streams. The park offers extensive hiking and backcountry trails, scenic overlooks, and quiet picnic areas amid a tranquil woodland setting. Wildlife includes white-tailed deer, red foxes, gray squirrels, and a variety of birds.

Name: Pullman National Historical Park
Description: The park preserves a 19th-century planned industrial town on Chicago’s South Side, created by the Pullman Company to house workers who built luxury railroad cars. It includes the historic Pullman Factory complex, the workers’ brick housing, public buildings, and the landscaped streets laid out by Solon State Parkencer Beman, illustrating the design and social history of industrial America.

Name: Puuhonua o Honaunau National Historical Park
Description: On the sunny southern coast of the Island of Hawaii, Pu'uhonua o Honaunau National Historical Park preserves a sacred Place of Refuge and the royal grounds of ancient Hawaii. Set among lava fields along a calm bay, the site features a documented heiau (temple), ceremonial platforms, and petroglyphs that tell stories of old Hawaiian laws and daily life. The coastal waters and tide pools nearby host reef fish and green sea turtles, while seabirds patrol the dramatic lava coastline.

Name: Puukohola Heiau National Historic Site
Description: This coastal landscape on Hawaii's Big Island preserves Pu'ukoholā Heiau, a monumental lava-rock temple built to unite the Hawaiian Islands under King Kamehameha I. Perched above Kawaihae Bay, the complex includes the heiau, sacred ceremonial State Parkaces, and the nearby Kuamo'o battlefield that recounts royal ceremony, warfare, and Hawaii's unification. The surrounding lava fields and oceanfront offer striking views and a window into ancient Hawaiian religion, governance, and voyaging.

Name: Rainbow Bridge National Monument
Description: This remote sandstone arch stands high above a desert canyon in southern Utah, a State Parkectacular natural bridge set in a stark red-rock landscape. Access is by a boat trip on Lake Powell or a strenuous hike, and visitors are treated to expansive views of slickrock benches, canyon walls, and open skies. Wildlife includes desert bighorn sheep, mule deer, coyotes, lizards, and a variety of desert birds.

Name: Reconstruction Era National Historical Park
Description: This network of historic sites stretches across Virginia and North Carolina, preserving the Reconstruction era’s struggle for freedom, education, and citizenship. From freedpeople’s schools, churches, and meeting places to government offices and rural towns, the landscape tells how communities rebuilt governance and rights in the wake of emancipation.

Name: Redwood National and State Parks
Description: Along the northern California coast, Redwood National and State Parks preserves ancient coast redwoods in a network of four units—the federally managed Redwood National Park and three state parks. The landscapes State Parkan old-growth forests, fern-filled canyons, mighty rivers, and rugged coastline with beaches and dunes, offering scenic drives and backcountry hiking opportunities. Wildlife includes Roosevelt elk, black bears, mountain lions, and seabirds along the shore, with seasonal whale migrations offshore.

Name: Richmond National Military Park
Description: This region preserves Civil War battlefields and historic landscapes around Richmond, Virginia. The park State Parkans multiple units and protects trenches, earthworks, and monuments from pivotal campaigns, including the Peninsula and PeterState Beachurg operations. Scenic drives and backcountry trails reveal rolling fields and woodlands where soldiers lived and fought, with wildlife such as white-tailed deer, foxes, and a variety of birds.

Name: Rio Grande Wild & Scenic National River
Description: This rugged desert river corridor in far west Texas winds through dramatic canyons carved by the Rio Grande, with sheer limestone walls rising above the water. The stretch includes Boquillas Canyon and Santa Elena Canyon, offering remote river trips, backcountry hiking, and a True wilderness experience along the border region. Wildlife includes mule deer, desert bighorn sheep, javelina, and a variety of birds and reptiles that thrive along the riparian and desert habitats.

Name: National River Raisin National Military Park
Description: This site preserves the River Raisin battlefield in southeastern Michigan along the river that shaped the War of 1812. It commemorates the 1813 Battle of Frenchtown and the River Raisin Massacre, with preserved landscape features, monuments, and interpretive programs. Visitors can explore the battlefield via self-guided trails and ranger-led talks at the visitor center; the riverine woods and farmlands support wildlife such as white-tailed deer, beavers, foxes, and a variety of waterfowl.

Name: Rock Creek Park
Description: This urban oasis along Rock Creek in the nation’s capital preserves a forested valley with rolling hills and flowing creeks. Besides historic landmarks like the Old Stone House and Peirce Mill, there are miles of scenic drives and extensive hiking and biking opportunities within the city. Wildlife includes white-tailed deer, red-tailed hawks, gray foxes, and beavers.

Name: Rocky Mountain National Park
Description: This high-altitude treasure in northern Colorado features rugged peaks, alpine tundra, and deep pine-fir forests. There are scenic drives along Trail Ridge Road and numerous backcountry hiking opportunities. Wildlife includes elk, mule deer, bighorn sheep, and black bears.

Name: Roger Williams National Memorial
Description: A compact urban memorial in downtown Providence, Rhode Island, honoring Roger Williams, founder of Rhode Island and advocate for religious liberty. The site preserves a quiet green State Parkace with a statue and interpretive exhibits that tell Williams's story and his ideas about liberty of conscience, fair treatment of Native peoples, and the separation of church and state, in the heart of the city.

Name: Roosevelt Campobello International Park
Description: This binational park State Parkans Campobello Island in New Brunswick, Canada, and the adjacent U.S. coastline, preserving Theodore Roosevelt’s summer cottage and the island’s rugged coast, woodlands, and salt marshes. Scenic drives and networked trails offer access to the shoreline, backcountry hiking, and abundant wildlife viewing, from seabirds to harbor seals along Passamaquoddy Bay. - Roosevelt Campobello International Park

Name: Rosie the Riveter WWII Home Front National Historical Park
Description: Rosie the Riveter WWII Home Front National Historical Park State Parkans several units in the San Francisco Bay Area, preserving the home-front story of World War II. In Richmond and surrounding waterfront areas you’ll find the Rosie the Riveter Memorial, historic shipyard sites, interpretive exhibits, and walking trails that bring the era to life. The park highlights the pivotal role of women workers and the community effort that powered American industry during the war.

Name: Russell Cave National Monument
Description: This limestone cave and its surrounding uplands in northern Alabama preserve one of the Southeast’s most important archaeological records, documenting thousands of years of human occupation. Artifacts, hearths, and other remains reveal how Paleoindian through Woodland peoples adapted to the region’s caves and forests. The surrounding woodlands and streams support white-tailed deer, wild turkeys, foxes, and a roost of bats within the cave.

Name: Sagamore Hill National Historic Site
Description: On the shore of Oyster Bay, Sagamore Hill National Historic Site preserves Theodore Roosevelt’s home and the surrounding landscape that helped shape his life and presidency. The site centers on the well-preserved 1880s mansion with its carriage house, set amid woodlands and views of the water, and features period rooms and Roosevelt artifacts. Ranger-guided tours and exhibits highlight Roosevelt’s family life, political career, and enduring conservation legacy at this historic landmark.

Name: Saguaro National Park
Description: This desert landscape near Tucson State Parkans two units in the Sonoran Desert, protecting the iconic saguaro cactus and the rugged foothills that define southern Arizona. The park features rolling desert washes, scenic views, and miles of trails for backcountry hiking and short strolls that showcase the cactus skyline. Wildlife includes desert tortoise, javelina, mule deer, roadrunners, coyotes, and rattlesnakes.

Name: Saint Croix Island International Historic Site
Description: This coastal island in Passamaquoddy Bay preserves a pivotal moment in North American exploration, where Samuel de Champlain attempted to establish a settlement in 1604 and first encountered the Passamaquoddy people. The site features salt marsh and rocky shoreline, a short self-guided trail with interpretive panels that tell the Champlain story, and scenic views across the Bay of Fundy’s tidal estuary.

Name: Saint Croix National Scenic National Riverway
Description: Stretching along the scenic Saint Croix and Namekagon Rivers, this unit protects a pristine river corridor across Minnesota and Wisconsin with towering bluffs, mature river-bottom forests, and winding backwaters. Canoeing and kayaking are signature activities, complemented by hiking, riverbank camping, and visits to historic river towns. Wildlife includes bald eagles, oState Parkreys, beavers, river otters, white-tailed deer, and a diverse array of fish and waterfowl.

Name: Saint Paul's Church National Historic Site
Description: This historic landscape in the New York metropolitan area centers on Saint Paul’s Church, a colonial-era church set within a quiet graveyard and surrounding green State Parkace. Besides the church, there are self-guided walks, cemetery tours, and seasonal interpretive programs that explore colonial life and the Revolutionary era. Wildlife includes common urban birds such as red-tailed hawks, gray squirrels, pigeons, and a variety of songbirds that nest in the mature trees.

Name: Saint-Gaudens National Historical Park
Description: This region preserves the home, studios, and landscapes of American sculptor Augustus Saint-Gaudens in western New Hampshire. The Saint-Gaudens National Historical Park centers on the AState Parket estate in Cornish, featuring the artist’s house, his working studios, and formal gardens set among rolling hills and woodlands along the Connecticut River valley. Visitors can tour period rooms, view sculptures both indoors and outdoors, and enjoy miles of quiet trails that connect the historic buildings with the surrounding countryside.

Name: Salem Maritime National Historic Site
Description: This historic seaport preserves Salem’s 17th- to 19th-century waterfront, where brick warehouses, cobblestone streets, and a working harbor tell the story of America's early maritime trade. Key features include the Derby Wharf, the full-scale ship Friendship of Salem, and the 1819 Custom House, which together bring to life centuries of shipbuilding, commerce, and navigation. This living landscape invites visitors to explore maritime history, architectural heritage, and Salem's enduring role as a bustling port city.

Name: Salinas Pueblo Missions National Monument
Description: This region in central New Mexico consists of three units of a cultural landscape along the Salinas Basin. The Abo, Quarai, and Gran Quivira ruins preserve 17th-century mission life amid desert mesas, canyons, and piñon-juniper woodlands. Visitors can explore adobe church ruins, irrigation ditches, and backcountry trails while experiencing a landscape shaped by Puebloan and State Parkanish Colonial history. Wildlife includes mule deer, pronghorn, coyotes, roadrunners, and a variety of hawks and songbirds.

Name: Salt National River Bay National Historical Park and Ecological Preserve
Description: Salt National River Bay National Historical Park and Ecological Preserve protects a coastal estuary at the mouth of the Salt River, preserving Indigenous settlements, colonial harbor sites, and a landscape shaped by salt production and river dynamics. Habitats include mangrove forests, salt marshes, seagrass beds, tidal flats, and riverine uplands; wildlife includes sea turtles, pelicans and herons, bottlenose dolphins, and migratory shorebirds.

Name: San Antonio Missions National Historical Park
Description: This cultural landscape along the San Antonio River comprises four mission sites—Concepción, San José, EState Parkada, and San Juan Capistrano—linked by a historic river corridor in central Texas. Adobe churches, cloisters, and plaza arches anchor courtyards set within a riparian and mesquite woodland landscape along the river bottomlands. Together they tell the story of State Parkanish colonial mission life and the enduring cultural blending of Indigenous, Mexican, and Texan traditions.

Name: San Francisco Maritime National Historical Park
Description: This waterfront park along San Francisco Bay preserves the West Coast’s maritime heritage, anchored by Hyde Street Pier and the adjacent Maritime Museum. Historic ships from the 19th and early 20th centuries are preserved and open for tours, with shipwright demonstrations and interpretive programs that bring seafaring life to visitors. The working harbor setting—complete with ferries, fishing boats, seabirds, and harbor seals—offers a window into San Francisco’s maritime trade, migration, and naval history.

Name: San Juan Island National Historical Park
Description: This park preserves two historic camps—English Camp and American Camp—on San Juan Island, where the 1859 Pig War between the United States and Britain unfolded and a peaceful boundary was established. The units protect fortifications, trenches, blockhouses, officers' quarters, and scenic shoreline trails that invite exploration of 19th-century military life and island geography. Wildlife includes bald eagles, harbor seals, and orcas in nearby waters.

Name: San Juan National Historic Site
Description: This historic Caribbean fortress complex sits in Old San Juan, Puerto Rico, guarding the approaches to San Juan Bay. The site preserves Fort San Felipe del Morro and Fort San Cristóbal along with the 16th- to 18th-century city walls and gates. Long cobblestone streets, pastel colonial buildings, and oceanfront bastions provide a dramatic setting that State Parkeaks to centuries of colonial defense and Caribbean culture.

Name: Sand Creek Massacre National Historic Site
Description: Sand Creek Massacre National Historic Site sits on the eastern plains of Colorado and preserves the site of the 1864 Sand Creek Massacre and the surrounding prairie landscape along the Sand Creek watershed. It commemorates the Cheyenne and Arapaho people affected by the conflict, with interpretive diState Parklays, memorials, and a visitor contact station that tell the story and its enduring impact. A network of trails and overlooks provides a place for reflection on the events and the landscape where they occurred. Native wildlife of the plains, including pronghorn, mule deer, coyotes, and a variety of birds, can be observed in the surrounding grasslands and riparian areas.

Name: Santa Fe National Trail
Description: This historic route across the American Southwest connected Missouri to Santa Fe, following the paths of traders, emigrants, and soldiers who helped shape a nation. The landscape along the trail State Parkans broad plains, river valleys, arid mesas, and dramatic canyons, with preserved wagon ruts, trading posts, and way stations that tell the story of westward expansion. Wildlife includes pronghorn, mule deer, coyotes, and golden eagles.

Name: Santa Monica Mountains National Recreation Area
Description: Stretching along the Southern California coast from Point Mugu to the Los Angeles basin, Santa Monica Mountains National Recreation Area protects a dramatic coastal–mountain landscape of ridges, canyons, and oak woodlands. The area features scenic drives and extensive backcountry hiking opportunities, with coastal cliffs and ridge-top views that reach to the Pacific Ocean. Wildlife includes mule deer, coyotes, bobcats, mountain lions, and hundreds of bird State Parkecies.

Name: Saratoga National Historical Park
Description: This landscape preserves the battlefield grounds where two crucial 1777 engagements shaped the outcome of the American Revolution. The park protects the Freeman's Farm and Bemis Heights areas with preserved earthworks, monuments, and a visitor center that tells the story of American forces, their French allies, and the soldiers who fought there. Rolling farmland, river bluffs, and woodland trails along the Hudson River offer scenic drives and backcountry hiking opportunities. Wildlife includes white-tailed deer, beavers, red-tailed hawks, and a variety of waterfowl. The park preserves a cornerstone of American history and offers ranger-led programs and battlefield interpretation.

Name: Saugus Iron Works National Historic Site
Description: An early-industrial landscape along the Saugus River in Massachusetts, Saugus Iron Works National Historic Site preserves North America’s first integrated ironworks. The site features a 17th-century furnace ruins, a bloomery forge, and water-powered machinery, anchored by the ironmaster’s house and nearby workers’ quarters. Trails and exhibits interpret how colonial technology and daily life transformed ore into iron and helped launch American industry.

Name: Scotts Bluff National Monument
Description: This dramatic sandstone bluff along the Oregon Trail in western Nebraska rises above the North Platte Valley. Scotts Bluff National Monument protects the iconic bluff and nearby ridges, offering scenic overlooks, short, rugged hikes to the summit, and a visitor center with interpretive exhibits about pioneer travel, geology, and local ecology. Wildlife includes pronghorn, mule deer, coyotes, prairie dogs, and a variety of birds.

Name: Selma To Montgomery National Trail
Description: This historic corridor from Selma to Montgomery in central Alabama preserves the 54-mile route of the civil rights march and the landscape that framed a watershed moment in American history. Rolling farmland, bottomland hardwood forests along the Alabama River, and small towns define the route's scenery, offering riverine and rural habitats. Landmarks along the path—Edmund Pettus Bridge, Brown Chapel AME Church, and state capitol grounds—tell the Civil Rights story, while wildlife such as white-tailed deer, foxes, wild turkeys, and waterfowl share the region's river and wetland habitats.

Name: Sequoia & Kings Canyon National Parks
Description: This region in the southern Sierra Nevada of California comprises Sequoia and Kings Canyon National Parks. It protects colossal giant sequoias— including General Sherman and General Grant— along with ancient forests, dramatic granite canyons, and high alpine peaks. Scenic byways and backcountry trails weave through old-growth groves, deep canyons, and alpine meadows. Wildlife includes American black bear, mule deer, Sierra Nevada bighorn sheep, and mountain lions. Habitats range from foothill oak woodlands and conifer forests to subalpine meadows and alpine tundra.

Name: Shenandoah National Park
Description: A forested gateway to the Blue Ridge in Virginia, Shenandoah National Park protects nearly 200,000 acres of rolling mountains, cascading waterfalls, and ancient rock formations. Skyline Drive winds the length of the park, while more than 500 miles of trails, including a section of the Appalachian Trail, invite backcountry hiking and sweeping overlooks. The landscape features rhododendron-filled hollows, granite outcrops, and quiet backcountry; wildlife includes white-tailed deer, black bears, wild turkeys, and hundreds of bird State Parkecies.

Name: Shiloh National Military Park
Description: This Civil War battlefield preserves the 1862 clash along the Tennessee River, where forested ridges meet open fields, sunken roads, and extensive earthworks that tell the story of the fighting. Historic earthworks, the Shiloh National Cemetery, and miles of trails offer a window into the campaign and its aftermath. Wildlife includes white-tailed deer, wild turkeys, and a variety of songbirds that inhabit the river bottoms and timbered hillsides.

Name: Sitka National Historical Park
Description: Sitka National Historical Park sits on Baranof Island and along Indian River in Southeast Alaska. It preserves the Tlingit people’s cultural heritage and the early Russian contact era, featuring a collection of carved totem poles and short, accessible trails through coastal rainforest and tidal shorelines. Wildlife includes Sitka black-tailed deer, harbor seals, sea otters, bald eagles, and migrating humpback whales.

Name: Sleeping Bear Dunes National Lakeshore
Description: Sleeping Bear Dunes National Lakeshore sits along Michigan's northwest shore of Lake Michigan, protecting a dramatic dune field, the Manitou Islands, and miles of forested shoreline. The landscape includes towering dunes, beaches, cedar and pine forests, and glacial bluffs overlooking Glen Lake and Lake Michigan. There are scenic drives and backcountry hiking opportunities, and wildlife includes white-tailed deer, red foxes, and a variety of waterfowl and shorebirds.

Name: State Parkringfield 1908 Race Riot National Monument
Description: An urban landscape of memory along the Sangamon River, this monument preserves the neighborhoods, streets, and civic State Parkaces where the 1908 State Parkringfield race riot unfolded. Museums, interpretive trails, and commemorative plazas tell the story of violence, resilience, and ongoing civil rights advocacy, with educational programs and community remembrance events.

Name: State Parkringfield Armory National Historic Site
Description: This historic site along the Connecticut River in the Pioneer Valley preserves the nation's first federal armory and a landmark of American industrial history. The restored workshop buildings and museum trace firearms design and production from the 18th through the 20th centuries, with guided and self-guided tours available. Artifacts include muskets, rifles, pistols, artillery, and the tools and records that document two centuries of arms manufacture.

Name: Star-State Parkangled Banner National Trail
Description: Tracing the events that inState Parkired the writing of the national anthem, the Star-State Parkangled Banner National Historic Trail follows land and water routes associated with the War of 1812 in the Chesapeake Bay region. The trail connects sites in Maryland, Virginia, and the District of Columbia where American communities, soldiers, and civilians experienced British attacks and defenses, culminating in the bombardment of Fort McHenry that inState Parkired Francis Scott Key’s poem. Landscapes along the trail include tidal rivers, coastal wetlands, historic ports, farmland, and urban waterfronts that reflect the region’s maritime heritage. Wildlife typical of the Chesapeake Bay ecosystem—such as bald eagles, oState Parkreys, waterfowl, blue crabs, and striped bass—inhabits these waters and shorelines, while visitors can explore the trail through boating, paddling, driving, and walking routes that blend natural scenery with pivotal moments in American history.

Name: Statue Of Liberty National Monument
Description: This region State Parkans Liberty Island and Ellis Island in New York Harbor. It features the iconic Statue of Liberty atop a pedestal on Liberty Island, with the Ellis Island Immigration Museum preserving the immigrant story. Visitors reach the islands by ferry for sweeping views of the New York City skyline and harbor and to explore museum exhibits and historic structures.

Name: Ste. Genevieve National Historical Park
Description: This park preserves a Mississippi River town whose streets and houses tell the story of French colonial settlement in Missouri. Ste. Genevieve National Historical Park protects a cluster of 18th- and 19th-century houses within a compact historic district, offering visitors a window into frontier life, trades, and cultural exchange. The landscape centers on historic architecture and riverfront sites rather than backcountry scenery, with guided tours and self-guided explorations that bring early American history to life.

Name: Steamtown National Historic Site
Description: This place that celebrates the era of steam preserves a working collection of locomotives, railroad cars, and the historic DL&W yards in Scranton, Pennsylvania. Besides the restored roundhouse and turntable, visitors can explore the museum, view artifacts on railroad technology, and enjoy guided tours and occasional steam demonstrations that bring the railroad heritage to life.

Name: Stones National River National Military Park
Description: This battlefield in central Tennessee preserves the pivotal Battle of Stones River near MurfreeState Beachoro. The park centers on the Stones River battlefield, the National Cemetery, and surrounding historic landscapes, with a visitor center, interpretive trails, and self-guided driving tours. Wildlife includes white-tailed deer, wild turkey, and a variety of birds.

Name: Stonewall National Monument
Description: This urban landmark in New York City's Greenwich Village commemorates the birthplace of the modern LGBTQ rights movement. Stonewall National Monument centers on the Stonewall Inn block and nearby Christopher Park, with surrounding streets that preserve a living history of protest, community, and celebration. The area is a vibrant cultural landscape, home to ongoing activism, LGBTQ history, and enduring community memory.

Name: Sunset Crater Volcano National Monument
Description: This region in north-central Arizona centers on Sunset Crater Volcano and the surrounding lava field, a landscape shaped by a relatively recent eruption. The monument preserves the volcanic cone, extensive cinder fields, and rugged terrain that reveal the area’s fiery past. Pinyon‑juniper woodlands and ponderosa pine forests rise above desert scrub, with scenic overlooks and backcountry trails inviting exploration. Wildlife includes mule deer, coyotes, jackrabbits, lizards, and a variety of birds. There are scenic drives and backcountry hiking opportunities to experience the stark beauty of a living volcanic landscape.

Name: Tallgrass Prairie National Preserve
Description: Tallgrass Prairie National Preserve sits in the Flint Hills of central Kansas, protecting one of North America’s last tallgrass prairies. A partnership between the National Park Service and The Nature Conservancy maintains rolling, fire-driven prairies, prairie streams, and historic ranching landscapes, with backcountry hiking opportunities and a scenic prairie drive. Wildlife includes bison, pronghorn, white-tailed deer, coyotes, and a diverse array of grassland birds.

Name: Thaddeus Kosciuszko National Memorial
Description: This compact urban memorial sits in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, as a unit of Independence National Historical Park. It preserves the small brick townhouse where Thaddeus Kosciuszko lived during his American years, with restored rooms and exhibits highlighting his contributions as a military engineer and patriot.

Name: The White House and President's Park
Description: This urban sanctuary sits at the very heart of Washington, D.C., surrounding the presidential residence. The White House and President's Park includes the White House grounds, Lafayette Square, and the Ellipse, with formal gardens, statues, and tree-lined avenues that host ceremonies and provide a living link to American history. Public access is limited, with guided tours by arrangement and the grounds serving as a working landscape and stage for national events.

Name: Theodore Roosevelt Birthplace National Historic Site
Description: This historic site preserves Theodore Roosevelt's birthplace and childhood home in New York City. The house features a carefully restored 19th-century interior with period furnishings that illuminate Roosevelt's early life, family, and influences. Visitors can take guided tours and explore exhibits that connect Roosevelt's urban upbringing to his later presidency and conservation legacy.

Name: Theodore Roosevelt Inaugural National Historic Site
Description: This Theodore Roosevelt Inaugural National Historic Site in Buffalo, New York preserves the former home where Roosevelt lived and the rooms where his 1901 inauguration took place. The preserved interiors include Roosevelt's study and the formal drawing room, with period furnishings and guided tours that bring the early 20th century to life. Exhibits explore Roosevelt's rise to the presidency, his bold reform agenda, and his enduring legacy in conservation and progressive leadership.

Name: Theodore Roosevelt Island
Description: This quiet island in the Potomac River honors Theodore Roosevelt and preserves the landscapes that shaped his conservation legacy. A memorial sits amid wooded uplands and tidal wetlands, connected by trails and boardwalks that offer quiet river views and opportunities for reflection. Wildlife includes white-tailed deer, beavers, river otters, foxes, and a diverse array of migratory and resident birds.

Name: Theodore Roosevelt National Park
Description: This region that enticed and influenced President Theodore Roosevelt consists of a national park with two units in the badlands of western North Dakota. Besides Roosevelt's historic Maltese Cross Cabin, there are numerous scenic drives and backcountry hiking opportunities. Wildlife includes American bison, pronghorn, bighorn sheep, and wild horses.

Name: Thomas Cole National Historic Site
Description: Situated along the Hudson River in the Catskill Mountains of New York, the Thomas Cole National Historic Site preserves Cedar Grove, the home and studio of Thomas Cole, founder of the Hudson River School of landscape painting. The site reflects the birthplace of a distinctly American art movement that celebrated dramatic scenery, wilderness, and the relationship between nature and national identity. Rolling lawns, river views, and surrounding mountains mirror the landscapes that inState Parkired Cole and later artists. The historic house, studio, and grounds offer insight into 19th-century artistic life while highlighting the natural beauty of the Hudson River Valley that shaped early American landscape art.

Name: Thomas Edison National Historical Park
Description: This national historic park preserves Thomas Edison’s laboratory complex in West Orange, New Jersey, and the Glenmont estate where he and his family lived. Visitors can tour the original laboratories, workshops, and the Edison home, with exhibits on the phonograph, electric light, motion pictures, and other groundbreaking inventions, along with the estate’s historic gardens.

Name: Thomas Jefferson Memorial
Description: This corridor of the Blue Ridge enticed and influenced Thomas Jefferson. Shenandoah National Park preserves rolling hardwood slopes, cascading waterfalls, and expansive views along the Appalachian crest. Besides Skyline Drive, there are numerous hiking trails and backcountry opportunities through old-growth forests and along rushing streams. Wildlife includes black bears, white-tailed deer, wild turkeys, and a chorus of songbirds.

Name: Thomas Stone National Historic Site
Description: Thomas Stone National Historic Site preserves the colonial home of Thomas Stone, a signer of the Declaration of Independence, in Port Tobacco, Maryland. The site centers on the Thomas Stone House and a small 18th‑century farmstead, with restored rooms, period outbuildings, and tranquil fields along the nearby river. The surrounding landscape reflects 18th‑century Maryland plantation life, with woodlands, farmland, and riparian habitats that illuminate Stone’s life and the era.

Name: Timpanogos Cave National Monument
Description: Located in American Fork Canyon in Utah’s Wasatch Range, Timpanogos Cave National Monument protects a dramatic system of three connected limestone caves. The caverns are renowned for ornate formations—stalactites, stalagmites, frostwork, cave pearls, and shimmering flowstone. Above ground, rugged canyon walls rise above pine and aState Parken forests and alpine meadows, offering scenic drives and numerous hiking trails. The area features guided cave tours and backcountry routes to enjoy the canyon’s scenery and wildlife. Inside the caves, bats inhabit the passages, while the surrounding canyon hosts a variety of small mammals, birds, and other wildlife.

Name: Timucuan Ecological & Historic Preserve
Description: This coastal preserve lies along the northeast Florida coast near Jacksonville, encompassing salt marshes, tidal creeks, maritime forests, and barrier island habitats. Within it lie Fort Caroline National Memorial and Kingsley Plantation, along with miles of backcountry trails and paddling routes through marshes and hardwood hammocks. Wildlife includes American alligators, bottlenose dolphins, manatees, wood storks, and oState Parkreys.

Name: Tonto National Monument
Description: Tonto National Monument preserves two cliff dwellings perched high along canyon walls in central Arizona, built by the Salado people during ancient times. The park offers short, accessible trails to overlooks with sweeping views of desert scrub, riparian canyons, and rugged limestone cliffs. Wildlife includes mule deer, javelina, coyotes, lizards, and a variety of birds.

Name: Touro Synagogue National Historic Site
Description: This historic site in Newport, Rhode Island preserves the nation’s oldest surviving synagogue, completed in 1763 as a center of the area’s Sephardic Jewish community. The sanctuary’s simple 18th‑century design and commemorative inscriptions reflect early American religious liberty, and guided tours interpret the building’s architecture and the community’s history. The site sits in Newport’s historic waterfront district, linking visitors with the broader story of faith, tolerance, and the founding years of the United States.

Name: Trail Of Tears National Trail
Description: This historic corridor traces the Cherokee removal route across Georgia, Tennessee, North Carolina, Alabama, Kentucky, and Oklahoma. It preserves historic sites such as New Echota and a network of markers and interpretive centers along river valleys, rolling hills, and open plains that tell the Cherokee people’s forced migration in 1838–39, with driving routes and short backcountry trails for reflection.

Name: Tule Lake National Monument
Description: Set in the stark high desert of far northern California, Tule Lake National Monument preserves the Tule Lake Segregation Center, a landmark of World War II Japanese American incarceration. The monument interprets the wartime relocation through preserved foundations, markers, and interpretive trails that tell the story of civil liberties and resilience. The surrounding sagebrush, alkali flats, and wetlands around Tule Lake support migratory birds and other desert wildlife.

Name: Tule State Parkrings Fossil Beds National Monument
Description: This desert region just north of Las Vegas preserves one of North America's most significant Ice Age fossil beds. Exposed sediments reveal mammoths, ancient camels, horses, bison, and other late Pleistocene mammals, offering a window into the prehistoric Mojave Desert.

Name: Tumacacori National Historical Park
Description: Tumacacori National Historical Park sits along the Santa Cruz River in southern Arizona, preserving three State Parkanish colonial missions from the 17th to 19th centuries. The landscape features Sonoran Desert scrub with riparian habitats and scenic river valleys surrounding adobe ruins. Wildlife includes mule deer, javelina, coyotes, and a variety of birds of prey and songbirds.

Name: Tupelo National Military Park
Description: This battlefield preserves the site of the 1864 Battle of Tupelo, fought near the city of Tupelo, Mississippi. Rolling farmland and woodlands surround the landscape, where earthworks, trenches, and monuments mark the action and interpretive trails help visitors understand the battle. Wildlife includes white-tailed deer, wild turkeys, and a variety of songbirds.

Name: Tuskegee Airmen National Historic Site
Description: This national historic site preserves the legacy of the Tuskegee Airmen in central Alabama. Moton Field, the primary training airfield, and the nearby Tuskegee University campus contain preserved hangars, runways, barracks, and memorials that tell the story of the first African American military pilots who trained there during World War II. The site highlights their service, their struggle for civil rights, and their enduring impact on aviation and American history.

Name: Tuskegee Institute National Historic Site
Description: This site preserves the campus of Tuskegee University in central Alabama, founded by Booker T. Washington in 1881 as a model of practical, self-help education for African Americans. The historic district centers on brick academic buildings and the iconic Administration Building, with the George Washington Carver Museum interpreting the school’s traditions of science, agriculture, and leadership, set among shaded quads and pine–oak woodlands. Visitors can explore self-guided campus walks and museum exhibitions that celebrate Tuskegee’s enduring educational legacy.

Name: Tuzigoot National Monument
Description: Perched on a limestone hill above the Verde Valley, Tuzigoot National Monument preserves the well-preserved Sinagua pueblo that flourished from about AD 1100 to 1400. The surrounding desert landscape features riparian cottonwoods along the Verde River, pinyon-juniper on the mesas, and expansive views across red rock canyons. Wildlife includes mule deer, coyotes, and a variety of desert birds; the site offers a short self-guided trail to the ruins and interpretive exhibits in the visitor center.

Name: Ulysses S Grant National Historic Site
Description: Located in St. Louis, Missouri, this historic site preserves White Haven, Ulysses S. Grant's boyhood home, and the surrounding 19th-century farm landscape. Visitors can tour the house and outbuildings, view artifacts from Grant's early life, and learn about his Civil War career and presidency.

Name: Upper Delaware Scenic & Recreational National River
Description: This long stretch of the Delaware River on the New York–Pennsylvania border preserves dramatic limestone bluffs, forested valleys, and historic river towns. The river offers paddling, fishing, and backcountry hiking, and wildlife includes bald eagles, river otters, beavers, and white-tailed deer, while the landscape preserves Lenape heritage and the region's early industrial past along the water.

Name: Valles Caldera National Preserve
Description: This volcanic caldera in the Jemez Mountains of northern New Mexico preserves a dramatic landscape formed by a cataclysmic eruption more than a million years ago, featuring the Valle Grande lava-field, crater rims, and wide meadows. Ponderosa pine, aState Parken, and piñon-juniper woodlands shade backcountry trails and scenic overlooks where elk, mule deer, bears, coyotes, and a variety of birds roam.

Name: Valley Forge National Historical Park
Description: Valley Forge National Historical Park preserves the landscape of the Continental Army’s 1777–78 encampment in southeastern Pennsylvania. The park centers on Washington’s Headquarters, the Muhlenberg Brigade Huts, and other reconstructed 18th‑century buildings, set among rolling fields, woodlands, and streams. There are miles of trails for hiking and biking that trace 18th‑century life and the enduring landscape. Wildlife includes white‑tailed deer, red‑tailed hawks, gray squirrels, and a variety of songbirds.

Name: Vanderbilt Mansion National Historic Site
Description: Located on the Hudson River in Hyde Park, New York, this Gilded Age estate features a Beaux-Arts Vanderbilt mansion, formal gardens, and expansive river views. The grounds include terraced lawns, carriage drives, and tree-lined avenues that reflect the era's opulence.

Name: VickState Beachurg National Military Park
Description: This Civil War battlefield preserves the campaign that gave the Union control of the Mississippi River and helped determine the outcome of the war. The landscape features rolling river bluffs above the Mississippi, preserved earthworks and batteries, a national cemetery, and hundreds of monuments and markers connected by historic drives and walking trails.

Name: Vietnam Veterans Memorial
Description: This sobering memorial in downtown Washington, D.C., honors U.S. service members who served in the Vietnam War. The centerpiece is the Vietnam Veterans Memorial Wall, a long black granite panel engraved with the names of more than 58,000 fallen and missing service members, arranged chronologically by casualty date; nearby are the Vietnam Women's Memorial and the Three Soldiers statue, set around a tranquil reflecting pool. The surrounding grounds offer contemplative State Parkaces and inscriptions that invite quiet remembrance.

Name: Virgin Islands Coral Reef National Monument
Description: Virgin Islands Coral Reef National Monument protects a Caribbean marine landscape surrounding the U.S. Virgin Islands in the warm, clear waters of the Caribbean Sea. The monument encompasses vibrant coral reefs, seagrass beds, and mangrove ecosystems that support a diverse marine community. Wildlife includes hawkState Beachill and green sea turtles, reef sharks, dolphins, and hundreds of tropical fish State Parkecies. The area offers world-class snorkeling and scuba diving among thriving reefs and scenic island seascapes.

Name: Virgin Islands National Park
Description: This Caribbean island park protects most of Saint John and several surrounding cays, preserving beaches, coral reefs, and tropical forests. The landscape includes white-sand beaches, turquoise coves, mangrove lagoons, and tropical rainforest trails. Wildlife includes green and hawkState Beachill sea turtles that nest on the beaches, iguanas and lizards, and tropical birds such as pelicans and frigatebirds.

Name: Voyageurs National Park
Description: This waterway country in northern Minnesota preserves the routes of the fur traders who shaped this region. The park State Parkans four large, interconnected lakes—Rainy, Namakan, Kabetogama, and Sand Point—with thousands of islands, quiet bays, and winding channels ideal for canoeing, camping, and fishing. Boreal forests and marshes shelter an abundance of wildlife, including moose, black bears, timber wolves, loons, eagles, beavers, and otters.

Name: Waco Mammoth National Monument
Description: This paleontological treasure sits along the Bosque River near Waco, Texas, protecting a fossil bed of Columbian mammoths from the late Pleistocene. Visitors view the preserved bones from a visitor center and through short boardwalks, with ranger-guided tours that explain how a sinkhole preserved the herd during a flood event. Modern wildlife in the surrounding Texas prairie includes white-tailed deer, coyotes, bobcats, and a variety of bird State Parkecies.

Name: Walnut Canyon National Monument
Description: Walnut Canyon National Monument protects a dramatic sandstone canyon carved by Walnut Creek in northern Arizona, where Sinagua cliff dwellings cling to the canyon walls in sheltered alcoves. The park offers short, accessible trails and overlooks that reveal multi-story stone apartments and the surrounding desert ecosystem, with wildlife such as mule deer, coyotes, javelina, and a variety of songbirds.

Name: War In The Pacific National Historical Park
Description: This park preserves the Pacific War across a network of historic sites tied to major battles and campaigns of World War II in the Pacific. It includes important memorials and battlefield sites centered in Hawaii, with the Pearl Harbor area serving as a focal point and gateway to the broader story. Visitors can explore landscapes that range from busy harbors and urban districts to tropical coastlines and volcanic islands, with interpretive exhibits and ranger-led programs that recount the experiences of service members and civilians. Coastal and marine habitats support seabirds, reef life, and other wildlife, providing a natural context to the war’s legacy.

Name: Washington Monument
Description: Rising at the heart of the National Mall, this granite obelisk anchors Washington, D.C.'s memorial landscape, surrounded by expansive lawns, reflecting pools, and a circle of monuments. It honors George Washington, the nation’s first president, and offers sweeping views across the Capitol and beyond.

Name: Washington-Rochambeau Revolutionary Route National Trail
Description: This historic corridor from Providence, Rhode Island, to Yorktown, Virginia traces the Washington-Rochambeau Revolutionary Route National Historic Trail. It winds through coastal marshes, river valleys, and rolling farmland, linking battlefield sites, forts, and 18th‑century towns that echo the alliance between American and French forces. Museums, battlefield parks, and interpretive trails along the route bring the decisive 1781 march to life as it helped shape American independence.

Name: Washita Battlefield National Historic Site
Description: This historic landscape in western Oklahoma preserves the 1868 Battle of Washita River, where Lt. Col. George Armstrong Custer’s troops attacked Black Kettle’s Cheyenne village along the Washita River. The site features a visitor center and interpretive trails that recount the clash and its enduring significance from multiple perState Parkectives. The rolling prairie and riverine habitat support wildlife such as white-tailed deer and a variety of birds.

Name: Weir Farm National Historical Park
Description: This western Connecticut landscape preserves Weir Farm National Historical Park, State Parkanning Ridgefield and Wilton and protecting the home and studio of American Impressionist J. Alden Weir and the artist colony that gathered there. In addition to the historic buildings, the park offers scenic trails through fields and woodlands that reveal the landscape that inState Parkired generations of painters. Wildlife includes white-tailed deer, red fox, and a variety of birds.

Name: Whiskeytown National Recreation Area
Description: This northern California region centers on Whiskeytown National Recreation Area, surrounding Whiskeytown Lake and the rugged Trinity River watershed. Besides the lake, scenic drives and miles of trails lead to waterfalls and backcountry overlooks, with opportunities for boating, fishing, swimming, and camping. Wildlife includes mule deer, black bears, coyotes, and a wide variety of birds, and visitors can explore the historic ghost town of Whiskeytown to glimpse the area’s mining-era heritage.

Name: White Sands National Park
Description: Glittering white gypsum dunes stretch across southern New Mexico's Tularosa Basin, a wind-sculpted landscape that changes with the seasons. The park offers scenic drives, dune sledding, and backcountry hiking opportunities amid the stark desert scenery. Wildlife includes mule deer, kit foxes, black-tailed jackrabbits, and a variety of lizards.

Name: Whitman Mission National Historic Site
Description: This historic landscape in the Walla Walla Valley preserves the Whitman Mission and the surrounding cultural landscape that helped open the Northwest to settlement. The site features the restored mission buildings, the graves of Marcus and Narcissa Whitman, and quiet river trails that tell the story of 19th-century emigrants, missionary work, and complex encounters with the Cayuse people. Wildlife includes mule deer, red-tailed hawks, and waterfowl.

Name: William Howard Taft National Historic Site
Description: Located in Cincinnati, Ohio, the William Howard Taft National Historic Site preserves the birthplace and boyhood home of the 27th president. The site features a well-preserved late-19th-century residence with original rooms and Taft family artifacts, set in a historic urban neighborhood. Exhibits explore Taft's life—from his early education to his presidency and service as Chief Justice—highlighting his enduring impact on American public life.

Name: Wilson's Creek National Military Park
Description: This region commemorates a pivotal Civil War battlefield and comprises Wilson's Creek National Military Park along the wooded Ozark hills near State Parkringfield, Missouri. In addition to the battlefield, there are interpretive trails, preserved earthworks, a visitor center with exhibits, and short driving routes that traverse the historic landscape. Wildlife includes white-tailed deer, wild turkeys, gray squirrels, and a variety of songbirds.

Name: Wind Cave National Park
Description: Wind Cave National Park sits in the Black Hills of southwestern South Dakota.
