It protects one of the world’s longest caves, famous for its intricate boxwork formations and a surface landscape of rolling prairie with ponderosa pine forests. Wildlife includes American bison, elk, prairie dogs, and mule deer.

Name: Wing Luke Museum Affiliated Area
Description: This Wing Luke Museum Affiliated Area centers on Olympic National Park in Washington. The park State Parkans a mosaic of landscapes—from temperate rainforest and glacier-carved mountains to a rugged Pacific coastline. Habitats include old-growth forests, alpine meadows, estuaries, and tide pools. Wildlife includes Roosevelt elk, black bears, mountain goats, harbor seals, and bald eagles. Cultural threads weave Coast Salish heritage with the histories of Asian immigrant communities in the region, and Wing Luke Museum partners with the park to tell these stories through programs and interpretation.

Name: Wolf Trap National Park for the Performing Arts
Description: This national park for the performing arts sits on rolling woodlands and meadows just outside Washington, D.C., in northern Virginia. The centerpiece is a renowned performing arts campus with the outdoor Filene Center and The Barns at Wolf Trap, hosting a full range of concerts and performances throughout the year. Trails wind through meadows and woodlands along Wolf Trap Creek, offering wildlife viewing and a peaceful natural setting.

Name: Women's Rights National Historical Park
Description: This region in upstate New York that State Parkarked the modern women’s rights movement consists of a park of three units in Seneca Falls and Waterloo. Besides the Elizabeth Cady Stanton House, the Wesleyan Chapel, and the M'Clintock House, there are interpretive exhibits, guided tours, and walking tours through the historic streets that witnessed the movement’s beginnings.

Name: World War I Memorial
Description: This memorial landscape honors the First World War with a rolling, commemorative terrain anchored by a monumental World War I Memorial on a hilltop. The park preserves preserved trenches and shell-crater fields, a museum and visitor center filled with wartime artifacts, and quiet plazas for reflection. Scenic drives meander through rural countryside, while backcountry trails weave among woodlands and open meadows. Wildlife includes white-tailed deer, red foxes, gray squirrels, and a variety of waterfowl and songbirds.

Name: World War II Memorial
Description: Located on the National Mall in Washington, D.C., the World War II Memorial honors the 16 million Americans who served in the armed forces and the millions more who supported the war effort at home during World War II. The memorial features a grand plaza with a central fountain, flanked by 56 pillars representing U.S. states and territories, and arches symbolizing victory in the Atlantic and Pacific theaters. Bas-relief panels depict scenes of military service and home-front contributions, illustrating the global scope and human cost of the war. The open-air setting, framed by reflecting pools and views of national monuments, creates a solemn State Parkace for remembrance and reflection at the heart of the nation’s capital.

Name: Wrangell - St Elias National Park & Preserve
Description: This vast Alaska landscape, a national park and preserve, protects glacier‑carved peaks, a vast icefield, and remote river valleys across the Wrangell and St. Elias mountain ranges. It features the Bagley Icefield, the active volcano Mount Wrangell, and the historic Kennecott Mines near McCarthy, with opportunities for backcountry trekking, glacier travel, and scenic Nabesna Road drives. Wildlife includes grizzly bears, moose, caribou, Dall sheep, wolves, and wolverines.

Name: Wright Brothers National Memorial
Description: On the Outer Banks near Kill Devil Hills, this park preserves the site of the first powered flight by the Wright brothers in 1903. A 60-foot granite memorial crowns the hill, with a life-size reproduction of the 1903 Wright Flyer and a museum with historical exhibits. The windswept dunes and Atlantic shoreline host shorebirds, seabirds, and seasonal sea turtles.

Name: Wupatki National Monument
Description: A high-desert plateau in northern Arizona near Flagstaff preserves a network of ancient pueblos built by the Ancestral Puebloans on red rock amid lava fields. The centerpiece, Wupatki Pueblo, is a multi-story, 100-room site linked with nearby ruins such as Wukoki; the landscape offers expansive desert views, scenic drives, and backcountry hiking. Wildlife includes pronghorn, mule deer, coyotes, black-tailed jackrabbits, roadrunners, lizards, and a variety of birds.

Name: Yellowstone National Park
Description: This vast park State Parkans three states—Wyoming, Montana, and Idaho—and protects a dynamic volcanic landscape of geysers, hot State Parkrings, mud pots, and dramatic canyons. From Old Faithful to a world of geothermal wonders, there are boardwalks, trails, and backcountry routes amid mountains, lakes, and forests. Wildlife includes American bison, gray wolves, grizzly bears, elk, and moose.

Name: Yorktown Battlefield
Description: This historic site preserves the pivotal 1781 siege that helped secure American independence, located along the York River in southeastern Virginia. The landscape features tidal marshes, riverfronts, and open fields that reflect the coastal environment and battlefield terrain. Wildlife includes white-tailed deer, foxes, raccoons, and a variety of migratory waterfowl.

Name: Yosemite National Park
Description: This iconic park in California's Sierra Nevada features dramatic granite cliffs, glacially carved valleys, and ancient giant sequoias. Famed for Yosemite Valley, it is home to El Capitan, Half Dome, Yosemite Falls, and Bridalveil Fall, with sweeping meadows, alpine lakes, and backcountry trails. Wildlife includes black bears, mule deer, coyotes, bobcats, and mountain lions.

Name: Yucca House National Monument
Description: This remote desert landscape preserves a compact cluster of Ancestral Puebloan great houses set in a sunbaked valley among yucca and piñon. The ruins reveal multi-story masonry, room blocks, and kivas, offering a window into ancient daily life and communal living. Facilities are State Parkarse and backcountry routes invite quiet exploration under vast desert skies.

Name: Yukon - Charley National Rivers National Preserve
Description: This remote Alaska wilderness protects the Yukon River corridor and the Charley River watershed, with braided channels, towering canyons, and vast boreal forests. Backcountry boating, hiking, and seasonal fishing reveal a landscape carved by glaciers and permafrost, where long river journeys connect people with wildness. Wildlife includes grizzly bears, moose, caribou, wolves, beavers, and salmon and trout that run in the rivers.

Name: Zion National Park
Description: Zion National Park sits in southwestern Utah, where the Virgin River has carved dramatic canyons through towering Navajo sandstone. The park features iconic hikes like Angels Landing and The Narrows, scenic drives, and backcountry exploration amid red rock cliffs, with wildlife including mule deer, desert bighorn sheep, and a variety of birds.

Name: Admiral William Standley State Recreation Area
Description: This coastal region along the state's shore comprises the Admiral William Standley State Recreation Area, a mosaic of rugged headlands, salt marshes, and forested uplands. Besides its naval-historical ties and dramatic coastal views, there are scenic drives and backcountry hiking opportunities. Wildlife includes harbor seals, river otters, bald eagles, ospreys, and mule deer.

Name: Ahjumawi Lava Springs State Park
Description: This remote region of northern California invites exploration of a volcanic landscape where lava-tube caves meet spring-fed waterways. Ahjumawi Lava Springs State Park preserves a vast mosaic of basalt lava flows, crystal-clear springs, and tidal and freshwater channels weaving among forested shorelines. Access is by boat, with canoe or kayak adventures through the park's network of shallow creeks and small islets. Wildlife includes river otters, beavers, bald eagles, ospreys, great blue herons, deer, and a diverse array of fish and amphibians.

Name: Albany State Marine Reserve
Description: Albany State Marine Reserve, this nearshore sanctuary lies along the northern San Francisco Bay shoreline at Albany, protecting a mosaic of rocky intertidal shores, kelp-dominated shallows, and eelgrass beds. The reserve sustains a rich community of juvenile fish and invertebrates, with tide pools and shallow subtidal habitats supporting a variety of life. Wildlife includes harbor seals hauled out on rocks, seabirds such as cormorants and pelicans, and a diverse array of fish and invertebrates. Visitors can enjoy wildlife viewing from the shoreline and bluff overlooks, with opportunities for tidepool exploration and calm kayaking in protected waters.

Name: Anderson Marsh State Historic Park
Description: This marshland along Cache Creek in Lake County, California preserves a culturally significant wetland and a Native American archaeological site with interpretive trails and a boardwalk through riparian forests and oak woodlands. Wildlife includes beavers, river otters, mule deer, raptors, and a variety of waterfowl.

Name: Andrew Molera State Park
Description: This rugged stretch of California’s Central Coast preserves a wild slice of Big Sur along the Pacific, from rolling coastal meadows to dramatic bluffs and a mile-long beach where the Big Sur River meets the sea. Molera Beach, coastal trails, and a network of backcountry paths offer opportunities for hiking through oak woodlands, river canyons, and open grasslands with sweeping ocean views. Wildlife includes black-tailed deer, coyotes, gray foxes, and a variety of shorebirds, with harbor seals and occasional whales seen offshore. The park also preserves a piece of ranching history, including Molera Ranch dairy buildings and the historic Creamery.

Name: Angel Island State Park
Description: This island park sits in San Francisco Bay, offering sweeping views of the city skyline, the Golden Gate Bridge, and the Marin Headlands. Rolling hills, grassy meadows, and stands of oak and pine cloak the island, with rugged shoreline and beaches providing scenic coastal habitats. The site also preserves the Angel Island Immigration Station and historic batteries, while miles of trails invite hiking and biking and wildlife includes birds and small mammals.

Name: Trione Annadel State Park
Description: This tucked-in corner of Sonoma County features oak woodlands, rolling grasslands, and Lake Ilsanjo at the center. It offers miles of multi-use trails for hiking, mountain biking, and horseback riding through seasonal wildflowers and diverse habitats. Wildlife includes deer, coyotes, foxes, and a variety of birds.

Name: Ano Nuevo State Park
Description: This rugged stretch of the central California coast comprises Ano Nuevo State Park, with dramatic sea cliffs, expansive beaches, and rolling dunes. Trails wind through coastal scrub and pine forests, offering sweeping ocean vistas and opportunities to observe wildlife along the shoreline. Wildlife includes northern elephant seals, harbor seals, sea otters, and a variety of seabirds.

Name: Antelope Valley CA Poppy State Natural Reserve
Description: In the high desert of California's Antelope Valley, spring rains awaken carpets of California poppies and other wildflowers across the landscape. Rolling grasslands, sage scrub, and arid washes frame expansive views of the surrounding mountains, with scenic overlooks, short trails, and seasonal displays. Wildlife includes pronghorn, black-tailed jackrabbits, coyotes, lizards, and a variety of birds drawn to the bloom.

Name: Antelope Valley Indian Museum
Description: This hillside state historic park in the Antelope Valley preserves a rich collection of Native American artifacts illustrating desert cultures of California and the Great Basin. The Antelope Valley Indian Museum’s stone-and-earth galleries are built into the hillside, housing baskets, pottery, tools, beadwork, and ceremonial regalia from many tribes. The surrounding high desert landscape offers quiet drives and short trails with views across the valley, where creosote, sage, and yucca endure in the arid climate. Wildlife in the area includes coyotes, jackrabbits, lizards, and a variety of desert birds.

Name: Anza-Borrego Desert State Park
Description: This expansive southern California desert region comprises Anza-Borrego Desert State Park, the largest state park in California, with a landscape of rugged canyons, wind-sculpted badlands, and palm oases. There are scenic drives and backcountry hiking opportunities across its vast stretches, including the Borrego Palm Oasis and other desert oases. Wildlife includes desert bighorn sheep, mule deer, coyotes, mountain lions, and a variety of lizards, rattlesnakes, and birds.

Name: Armstrong Redwoods State Natural Reserve
Description: Ancient coast redwoods form a living cathedral within Armstrong Redwoods State Natural Reserve, where towering trunks rise over fern-filled clearings and moss-draped branches create a cool, tranquil forest. The reserve protects old-growth groves and winding trails along creeks and shaded canyons, offering serene backcountry experiences for hikers and nature lovers. Wildlife includes black-tailed deer, gray fox, and a chorus of woodpeckers and songbirds that call the redwood forest home.

Name: Arthur B Ripley Desert State Park
Description: This sun-scorched corner of the American Southwest reveals a desert landscape of wind-carved canyons, sandstone fins, dune fields, and salt flats. There are scenic drives and backcountry hiking opportunities that let visitors explore remote washes and overlook vistas. Wildlife includes desert bighorn sheep, kit fox, coyotes, mule deer, and desert tortoise.

Name: Asilomar State Beach
Description: This coastal stretch along the Monterey Peninsula encompasses Asilomar State Beach, a mile of sandy shoreline framed by Monterey pines and rugged bluffs. Besides the beach, there are sheltered coves, rocky points, tide pools, and easy trails that weave through the coastal forest. Wildlife includes harbor seals, pelicans, cormorants, and tidepool life such as sea stars, anemones, and crabs.

Name: Auburn State Recreation Area
Description: Auburn State Recreation Area spans the granite canyons and rolling foothills along the North and Middle Forks of the American River in California. It features oak woodlands, pine forests, and river vistas, with historic mining remnants and miles of backcountry trails for hiking, mountain biking, and horseback riding. Wildlife includes mule deer, coyotes, bobcats, and a variety of birds.

Name: Austin Creek State Recreation Area
Description: Austin Creek State Recreation Area sits in the rolling coastal foothills of Sonoma County along the Russian River corridor, protecting stands of coastal redwoods and oak woodlands, plus rugged canyons and riparian habitats. The area features miles of multi-use trails for hiking, mountain biking, and backcountry exploration, along with primitive campsites and quiet picnic spots. Wildlife includes black-tailed deer, gray fox, bobcats, hawks, and a chorus of songbirds, with seasonal wildflowers coloring the hills in spring.

Name: Azalea State Natural Reserve
Description: This hillside sanctuary in California's northern foothills protects a mosaic of oak woodlands, grasslands, and a carpet of native azaleas that bloom each spring. Trails wind through meadows, along a seasonal creek, and to scenic overlooks with views across the valley. Wildlife includes mule deer, gray fox, and a wide variety of birds and butterflies.

Name: Bale Grist Mill State Historic Park
Description: This 19th-century water-powered grist mill sits in a shaded canyon in California’s wine country. The mill and its accompanying historic buildings feature exhibits and demonstrations that bring pioneer milling life to visitors. Oak woodland and riparian habitat support deer, gray fox, squirrels, and a diverse array of birds along the canyon trail system.

Name: Bean Hollow State Beach
Description: This portion of California's central coast entices visitors with rugged bluffs, tide pools, and sweeping Pacific views. Besides Bean Hollow State Beach, there are scenic drives along Highway 1 and easy bluff-top hiking opportunities. Wildlife includes harbor seals, shorebirds, tidepool invertebrates, and gray whales offshore during migration.

Name: Benbow Lake State Recreation Area
Description: This lakeside recreation area in Humboldt County offers boating and fishing on Benbow Lake, a shaded campground, and trails that wind through redwood and mixed-conifer forests. Day-use areas provide picnicking, swimming, and easy access to gentle trails that reveal riverine habitats and scenic views. Wildlife often observed includes black-tailed deer, river otters, osprey, bald eagles, and a variety of songbirds.

Name: Benicia Capitol State Historic Park
Description: Nestled on Benicia's waterfront along the Carquinez Strait, Benicia Capitol State Historic Park preserves California's first state capitol and the adjacent 19th-century government buildings. It offers period rooms, interpretive exhibits about early statehood and daily life in a growing port town, and opportunities for self-guided or guided tours that bring the Bear Flag era and 1849–1852 politics to life.

Name: Benicia State Recreation Area
Description: Benicia State Recreation Area sits along the Carquinez Strait in the northern San Francisco Bay Area, featuring rolling hills, tidal marshes, and open shoreline. It offers miles of multi-use trails for hiking, biking, and horseback riding, along with picnic areas and bayside viewpoints to watch ships and wildlife. Habitats include tidal marsh, coastal prairie, and riparian woodlands, and wildlife includes harbor seals, pelicans, herons and egrets, deer, and coyotes.

Name: Bethany Reservoir State Recreation Area
Description: Bethany Reservoir State Recreation Area sits along a broad reservoir framed by forested hills and open shoreline, offering boating, fishing, camping, and hiking with scenic viewpoints. Wildlife includes waterfowl, deer, and raptors.

Name: Bidwell Mansion State Historic Park
Description: This region that shaped Chico's history centers on the 19th‑century Bidwell Mansion, a grand Italianate home near downtown Chico. Inside are period rooms, decorative woodwork, and Bidwell family artifacts that tell the story of California settlement, frontier life, and local heritage. The surrounding grounds feature historic gardens and views of the valley, offering guided tours and living-history programs.

Name: Bidwell Sacramento River State Park
Description: Bidwell Sacramento River State Park spans two linked units in northern California: the foothill landscapes of Bidwell Park in Chico and the broad Sacramento River floodplain. The terrain features oak woodland, pine-studded canyons, granite outcrops, and riparian corridors along the river, with miles of trails for hiking, biking, and exploring backcountry scenery. Wildlife includes mule deer, gray fox, beaver, river otter, bald eagles, ospreys, and a variety of waterfowl.

Name: Big Basin Redwoods State Park
Description: Big Basin Redwoods State Park, California’s oldest state park, protects a vast stand of ancient coast redwoods in the Santa Cruz Mountains. The park features towering redwoods, mossy canyons, and cascading creeks with miles of hiking trails through old-growth groves and dramatic scenery. Wildlife includes black-tailed deer, gray fox, bobcats, raccoons, and a variety of birds, making it a premier destination for forest and wildlife viewing.

Name: Bodie State Historic Park
Description: This state historic park preserves a late-19th-century gold-mining town in the eastern Sierra Nevada. Bodie State Historic Park sits on the Bodie Hills above Bodie Creek near Bridgeport, California, and features a rugged main street with hundreds of preserved buildings, mine works, and artifacts that tell the story of frontier mining life. Wildlife in the surrounding high-desert landscape includes mule deer, coyotes, and a variety of birds.

Name: Bolsa Chica State Beach
Description: Bolsa Chica State Beach sits along the Orange County coast, offering miles of sandy shoreline, rolling dunes, and sweeping Pacific views. The adjacent Bolsa Chica Ecological Reserve protects tidal wetlands, salt marshes, and dune habitats, providing critical habitat for migratory and resident birds and other wildlife. Wildlife commonly seen includes shorebirds, pelicans, herons, and osprey, with gray whales and dolphins often visible offshore during migration.

Name: Border Field State Park
Description: Border Field State Park sits at the southern tip of San Diego Bay along the U.S.–Mexico border. It preserves a low-lying coastline of sandy beaches, rolling dunes, and tidal wetlands connected to the nearby Tijuana River Estuary, a productive Pacific ecosystem. The area supports a diverse array of migratory shorebirds, waterfowl, and other coastal wildlife, with expansive views of the border fence and wide open horizons.

Name: Bothe Napa Valley State Park
Description: This park sits in the rolling hills of Napa Valley, protecting oak woodlands, riparian canyons, and a cluster of historic pioneer-era cabins. Trails wind along Napa Creek through shaded groves, connecting picnic areas and a small campground with scenic views of vineyards and valley below. Wildlife includes deer, foxes, raccoons, and a variety of hawks and songbirds.

Name: Brannan Island State Recreation Area
Description: Brannan Island State Recreation Area sits in the California Delta along a network of tidal channels and wetlands. The park offers boat launches, fishing access, picnicking sites, and levee-side trails with expansive Delta views. Wildlife includes waterfowl, shorebirds, and river otters, with tidal marsh, mudflat, and slough habitats supporting life year-round.

Name: Burleigh H Murray Ranch Park Property
Description: Burleigh H. Murray Ranch Park Property preserves a historic coastal ranch landscape along the San Mateo County coast, featuring a late-19th-century ranch house, barns, and rolling pastures set among oak woodlands. There are unpaved trails for hiking and backcountry exploration that wind through grasslands and creek corridors with sweeping views of the Pacific Ocean. Wildlife includes deer, coyotes, red-tailed hawks, and a variety of songbirds.

Name: Burton Creek State Park
Description: Located on the north shore of Lake Tahoe, Burton Creek State Park protects forested ridges, wetlands, and sweeping Sierra views. Trails wind through ponderosa pines and aspen groves, offering hiking, biking, backcountry exploration, and abundant opportunities for wildlife watching.

Name: Butano State Park
Description: Butano State Park sits in the Santa Cruz Mountains near Pescadero on California’s coast, protecting a mosaic of coastal redwood forest, steep canyons, and riparian creeks. Trails wind through ancient redwoods and oak woodlands, offering backcountry hiking and quiet wildlife viewing in an area where deer, gray fox, raccoons, and a variety of songbirds thrive.

Name: Calaveras Big Trees State Park
Description: This Sierra Nevada foothills park protects two ancient groves of giant sequoias—the North Grove and the South Grove. Along with the monumental trees, rolling meadows, granite outcrops, and creeks offer scenic drives and backcountry hiking opportunities. Wildlife includes mule deer, gray fox, and a variety of birds.

Name: California Citrus State Historic Park
Description: California Citrus State Historic Park sits in Riverside, California, preserving the landscape and history shaped by Southern California’s citrus industry. The park features century-old citrus groves, a restored packinghouse, and an interpretive center with exhibits on irrigation, immigration, and early 20th-century farming, with trails weaving through historic orchards and farm infrastructure.

Name: CA Indian Heritage Center State Park
Description: CA Indian Heritage Center State Park spans multiple units across California’s tribal homeland, anchored by the CA Indian Heritage Center that showcases living traditions and history. It preserves ceremonial sites, ancestral villages, and traditional gathering places that tell the stories of dozens of Native nations. The park features oak woodlands, river canyons, and coastal redwood habitats, with ecosystems ranging from riparian corridors to montane forests and wildlife including mule deer, coyotes, river otters, and a diverse chorus of birds.

Name: CA State Capitol Museum Park Property
Description: Nestled in the heart of California's capital, the CA State Capitol Museum Park Property comprises the Capitol Building, surrounding formal gardens, and shaded parkways that link the Capitol complex with the Capitol Museum and public art. The landscape blends historic civic architecture with native and ornamental plantings, expansive lawns, terraced walkways, and reflective water features that host seasonal exhibits and community events. Wildlife includes western gray squirrels, mourning doves, California towhees, red-tailed hawks, and garden lizards, supported by plantings of coast live oak, valley oak, manzanita, and ceanothus.

Name: CA Mining and Mineral Museum
Description: CA Mining and Mineral Museum sits in Mariposa, California, in the heart of Gold Country. It preserves California’s mining heritage and minerals, with displays of gold ore, quartz and other crystals, plus a full suite of historic mining equipment and mining-camp artifacts. Visitors can watch live gold-panning demonstrations and explore a recreated underground tunnel; the surrounding Sierra Nevada foothills offer scenic drives and access to nearby state parks with oak woodlands and river canyons.

Name: CA Railroad Museum Point of Interest
Description: This California landmark preserves the story of railroading across the American West. Located in Sacramento’s Old Sacramento Historic District, the California Railroad Museum houses a broad collection of locomotives, passenger cars, freight cars, and railroad artifacts spanning steam to diesel eras. Inside and in the outdoor yard, visitors can view restored engines, explore interactive exhibits on trackwork, signaling, and operations, and imagine life aboard historic trains.

Name: Cambria State Marine Park
Description: Cambria State Marine Park lies along the central California coast near Cambria, protecting a mosaic of shallow rocky shores, kelp forests, and sheltered bays. Visitors enjoy kayaking, tidepooling, and scenic coastal views along the park’s accessible shoreline. Sea otters, harbor seals, gray whales, dolphins, and a variety of seabirds rely on its nutrient-rich waters, while intertidal communities host crabs, sea stars, and anemones.

Name: Candlestick Point State Recreation Area
Description: Candlestick Point State Recreation Area sits along the windy eastern shore of San Francisco Bay. This urban coastal landscape preserves a mosaic of tidal marshes, salt flats, dunes, and coastal scrub with panoramic views of the city skyline and the Golden Gate Bridge. The park features the Bay Trail for hiking and biking, fishing from the shore, and picnic areas and scenic overlooks. Habitats include tidal flats, salt marsh, and upland scrub that support shorebirds such as western sandpipers and stilts, waterfowl, harbor seals along the shore, and occasional raptors. Visitors can enjoy birdwatching, hiking, biking, fishing, and picnicking amid dramatic water views within easy reach of downtown San Francisco.

Name: Cardiff State Beach
Description: This sun-drenched stretch along the northern San Diego coast features a state beach with cliff-backed shoreline, rolling dunes, and tide pools that host a variety of marine life. Known for its world-class surf breaks at Swami's and easy access to coastal trails, Cardiff State Beach offers a dynamic mix of beach, bluff, and lagoon habitats.

Name: Carlsbad State Beach
Description: This coastline that beckons sun and sea comprises a park of three units along a protective barrier-island chain. Besides preserved dunes and a historic lighthouse, there are scenic coastal trails, kayaking routes, and backcountry hiking opportunities. Wildlife includes gray seals, piping plovers, loggerhead sea turtles, and bottlenose dolphins.

Name: Carmel River State Beach
Description: On California's Central Coast, Carmel River State Beach comprises a long stretch of white-sand beach where the Carmel River meets the Pacific. Besides beach walks, dunes, and scenic coastline, the area protects a tidal estuary and adjacent dune habitats. Wildlife includes shorebirds, harbor seals, and river otters.

Name: Carnegie State Vehicular Recreation Area
Description: Carnegie State Vehicular Recreation Area sits in the rolling foothills of California's Central Valley. It comprises multiple zones with miles of dirt roads, rough trails, and backcountry riding opportunities for OHV enthusiasts. Wildlife includes mule deer, coyotes, jackrabbits, and various birds of prey. - Carnegie State Vehicular Recreation Area

Name: Carpinteria State Beach
Description: Carpinteria State Beach sits along California’s central coast near Santa Barbara, a long, sandy shoreline offering day-use areas and camping. The Carpinteria Bluffs and surrounding dune systems provide scenic trails, tide pools, and access to nearshore waters. Wildlife includes shorebirds, pelicans, harbor seals along the shoreline, and migrating gray whales offshore.

Name: Caspar Headlands State Beach
Description: This dramatic stretch of California coastline features wind-worn headlands, sandy beaches, and cliffside trails that offer sweeping Pacific views. Tide pools along the shore host sea stars, anemones, and small crabs, while offshore gray whales migrate by, and harbor seals and sea lions haul out on rocky ledges. Seabirds—pelicans, cormorants, gulls, and terns—fill the air from dawn to dusk, as coastal sage scrub, dune grasses, and rocky intertidal habitats support a diverse web of life. Scenic drives and backcountry hiking provide opportunities for wildlife viewing, surfing, and sunset photography.

Name: Caspar Headlands State Natural Reserve
Description: Along a rugged stretch of California’s coast, CaState Parkar Headlands State Natural Reserve spans dramatic sea cliffs, windswept bluffs, and secluded coves. The reserve protects a mosaic of coastal sage scrub, oak woodland, dune systems, and rocky intertidal zones, with tidepools teeming with starfish, urchins, and anemones. Wildlife includes gray whales offshore, harbor seals and sea lions hauled out on the rocks, peregrine falcons, ospreys, pelicans, and a variety of shorebirds.

Name: Castaic Lake State Recreation Area
Description: This region around Castaic Lake State Recreation Area fuses water-based recreation with rugged canyon scenery in northern Los Angeles County. The lake offers boating, fishing, and swimming, while miles of trails invite hiking, mountain biking, and horseback riding along shoreline and ridgelines. Habitat includes oak woodlands, chaparral, and riparian zones that support mule deer, coyotes, bobcats, and a diverse array of waterfowl and songbirds.

Name: Castle Crags State Park
Description: Rugged granite spires rise above dense forests along a scenic stretch of northern California's I-5, where Castle Crags State Park protects dramatic crags and canyon views. Trails wind through pine and fir to overlooks and challenging rock routes, offering backcountry hiking, scrambling, and access for climbers. Wildlife includes black-tailed deer, marmots, and a variety of birds that call the canyon home.

Name: Castle Rock State Park
Description: Castle Rock State Park sits in the Santa Cruz Mountains along California's coast, just inland from the San Francisco Bay Area. It features dramatic sandstone rock outcrops, steep canyons, and miles of hiking trails that lead to sweeping ridge-line viewpoints. Habitats include oak woodlands, chaparral, and riparian zones, supporting wildlife such as mule deer, gray foxes, coyotes, hawks, and a variety of songbirds.

Name: Castro Adobe Park Property
Description: Castro Adobe Park Property, this historic park property centers on the Castro Adobe, a preserved 19th-century adobe set in a rolling valley with oak woodlands and a riparian creek. The site features interpretive panels, shaded trails, and seasonal wildflowers that reveal the region’s history and natural beauty. Wildlife includes deer, gray fox, rabbits, and a variety of birds, including hawks and songbirds.

Name: Caswell Memorial State Park
Description: Caswell Memorial State Park sits along the Stanislaus River in California’s Central Valley, preserving a remarkable grove of ancient valley oak woodland. The riparian canyon features shaded trails, river views, and seasonal wildflowers amid a mosaic of oak woodland, cottonwood-willow forest, and wetlands. Wildlife includes deer, gray squirrels, raccoons, and a variety of migratory and resident birds that inhabit the river corridor.

Name: Cayucos State Beach
Description: This stretch of California's Central Coast around Cayucos State Beach features a long sandy shoreline, bluff-backed coastline, and sweeping Pacific views. The area includes dune grasslands, tide pools, and nearby estuarine wetlands along Estero Bay. Wildlife includes harbor seals, brown pelicans, shorebirds, and gray whales during seasonal migrations.

Name: China Camp State Park
Description: This coastal park preserves a historic Chinese fishing village and tidal marsh along San Pablo Bay in Marin County, just north of San Francisco. The site features the preserved China Camp Village, a sandy beach, and miles of trails that traverse coastal bluffs, woodlands, and salt-marsh habitats. Wildlife includes deer, raccoons, foxes, and a variety of water birds such as herons, egrets, pelicans, and shorebirds.

Name: Chino Hills State Park
Description: Chino Hills State Park, an expansive, sun-warmed landscape in Southern California, sits along the northern edge of the Inland Empire, preserving rolling hills of oak woodlands, grasslands, and chaparral with sweeping views of the San Bernardino and Santa Ana mountains. There are miles of trails for hiking, biking, and horseback riding, plus scenic overlooks and backcountry routes for longer treks. Wildlife includes mule deer, coyotes, bobcats, gray foxes, and a variety of birds.

Name: Chumash Painted Cave State Historic Park
Description: Chumash Painted Cave State Historic Park preserves one of California’s finest examples of Indigenous rock art, tucked in the coastal foothills above Santa Barbara. The painted sandstone shelter features vibrant panels created by the Chumash over centuries, depicting ceremonial scenes and local wildlife amid oak woodland and chaparral terrain.

Name: Clay Pit State Vehicular Recreation Area
Description: Clay Pit State Vehicular Recreation Area is a rugged OHV playground in California's foothill country, featuring clay-rich canyons, rolling hills, and rocky outcrops with miles of dirt trails for dirt bikes, ATVs, and side-by-sides. Backcountry riding offers expansive views and remnants of former clay pits, while wildlife includes mule deer, coyotes, bobcats, and a variety of birds of prey.

Name: Clear Lake State Park
Description: This lakeside region along Clear Lake in Northern California features a string of shoreline units surrounding the largest natural freshwater lake entirely within California. Besides serene water vistas, there are scenic drives and backcountry hiking opportunities along wooded bluffs and lakeshore trails. Wildlife includes bald eagles, ospreys, mule deer, river otters, and a wide array of waterfowl.

Name: Colonel Allensworth State Historic Park
Description: Colonel Allensworth State Historic Park preserves the town of Allensworth, founded in 1908 by African American pioneers as a self-governing, self-sustaining community in California’s southern Central Valley. The park centers on a well-preserved town site with restored and relocated 1910s buildings—homes, a school, a church, and stores—set amid the region’s farmland and irrigation canals. Visitors can explore on self-guided tours and interpretive programs, and wander the gentle trails that reveal the town’s history, everyday life, and the area’s agricultural heritage.

Name: Columbia State Historic Park
Description: This living Gold Rush town in California's Sierra Nevada foothills preserves a vivid 19th-century mining community. Columbia State Historic Park centers on a carefully preserved Main Street with wooden storefronts, a courthouse, a blacksmith shop, and opportunities to pan for gold or ride a stagecoach. Wildlife in the surrounding foothills includes mule deer, gray squirrels, coyotes, and a variety of birds.

Name: Colusa Sacramento River State Recreation Area
Description: Colusa Sacramento River State Recreation Area spans two riverfront units along the Sacramento River in northern California. It features broad river channels, backwater sloughs, and riparian woodlands that support a variety of outdoor recreation, including boating, fishing, camping, and levee-side walks. Wildlife includes bald eagles, river otters, beavers, mule deer, sandhill cranes, and numerous ducks and wading birds.

Name: Corona del Mar State Beach
Description: Corona del Mar State Beach sits along the Newport Beach coastline in Southern California. This coastal stretch features broad sandy beaches backed by scenic cliffs, excellent swimming and surfing, and sweeping ocean views. Tide pools dot the rocky coves at low tide, and the area offers easy access for picnicking, walking, and sunset strolls. Habitats include open ocean shoreline, coastal dunes, and rocky intertidal zones. Wildlife includes pelicans, gulls, and other shorebirds; dolphins offshore and, in the tidepools, life such as starfish, crabs, anemones, and small fish.

Name: Crystal Cove State Park
Description: This coastal region along Southern California's Pacific shore drew artists, naturalists, and sun-seekers with its dramatic cliffs, tidepools, and sunlit coves. Crystal Cove State Park preserves offshore canyons, bluff-top vistas, and a historic district of vintage beach cottages, offering scenic coastal hikes and backcountry trails. Wildlife includes harbor seals, California sea lions, gray foxes, bobcats, pelicans, and cormorants, with tidepool inhabitants like anemones and starfish and seasonal whale and dolphin visitors.

Name: Cuyamaca Rancho State Park
Description: This elevated sanctuary in Southern California protects granite peaks, rolling meadows, and a mosaic of pine and oak woodlands in the Cuyamaca Mountains. Highlights include Cuyamaca Peak, Lake Cuyamaca, and miles of backcountry trails weaving through stands of bigcone Douglas-fir, ponderosa pine, Jeffrey pine, and coastlive oak. Wildlife includes mule deer, gray fox, bobcats, and a rich chorus of birds.

Name: DL Bliss State Park
Description: On California’s Lake Tahoe west shore, D. L. Bliss State Park protects a dramatic blend of granite cliffs, pine forests, and crystal-clear lake waters. Scenic overlooks, rocky coves, and sandy beaches frame sweeping views of the lake and surrounding peaks, while mile-long shore trails and longer backcountry routes invite hiking, picnicking, and exploration. Wildlife includes mule deer, ground squirrels, and a variety of songbirds.

Name: Del Norte Coast Redwoods State Park
Description: This coastal redwood landscape along California’s far north coast preserves ancient stands of coast redwoods within Del Norte Coast Redwoods State Park. Towering trees rise above mossy duff, fern-filled canyons, and fog-shrouded streams, with coastal scenery that includes rugged bluffs and river valleys. Wildlife includes black bears, Roosevelt elk, mountain lions, river otters, harbor seals, and a wide array of birds.

Name: Delta Meadows Park Property
Description: Delta Meadows Park Property comprises three connected units along the Delta River and surrounding foothills. Besides preserved historic cabins and interpretive trails, there are scenic byways and backcountry routes that thread through rolling meadows, cottonwood-bottom wetlands, and pine–oak uplands. Wildlife includes white-tailed deer, pronghorn, beavers, river otters, and a broad array of birds of prey, waterfowl, and songbirds.

Name: Dockweiler State Beach
Description: Dockweiler State Beach sits along the Pacific coast in Los Angeles, a long, broad sandy shoreline facing Santa Monica Bay. The park features designated fire rings, picnic areas, restrooms, and miles of paved trails along The Strand for biking and walking, with dramatic sunsets over the ocean. Wildlife includes shorebirds that hunt the tidelands and dolphins offshore, offering a quintessential Southern California coast experience with easy access to urban amenities.

Name: Doheny State Beach
Description: This iconic stretch of Southern California coast near Dana Point preserves Doheny State Beach, a classic beach park with a long sandy shoreline, grassy picnic areas, and easy access to tide pools and nearby bluffs. The park offers day-use beaches, surfing opportunities, and a campground for coastal getaways. Wildlife includes pelicans, terns, and shorebirds along the shore, with gray whales and dolphins visible offshore during migrations. Habitats range from sandy beaches and tidal pools to dune grasses and coastal sage scrub on the surrounding bluffs.

Name: Donner Memorial State Park
Description: This Sierra Nevada foothill landscape near Truckee preserves the story of the Donner Party at Donner Memorial State Park. Donner Lake, granite ridges, and pine forests surround the historic Emigrant Trail and Pioneer Monument, offering hiking, picnicking, and interpretive programs along the shore. Habitats include lakeshore, conifer forest, and meadow, and wildlife includes mule deer, coyotes, and a variety of birds.

Name: McLaughlin Eastshore State Park Sea Shore
Description: McLaughlin Eastshore State Park sits along the eastern shore of San Francisco Bay, weaving tidal marshes, mudflats, salt ponds, and urban shoreline into a continuous habitat and recreational corridor. It features miles of multi-use trails with views of the bay, bridges, and skyline, offering biking, walking, and wildlife watching opportunities. Wildlife includes shorebirds, waterfowl, harbor seals, and other bay-dwelling species that rely on the wetlands for feeding and nesting.

Name: Ed Z'Berg Sugar Pine Point State Park
Description: On the west shore of Lake Tahoe, Sugar Pine Point State Park protects a pine-studded Sierra Nevada landscape along crystal-clear waters. The park features the historic Hellman-Ehrman Mansion and miles of shoreline and backcountry trails that wind through groves of sugar pine, ponderosa pine, and white fir. Wildlife includes black bears, mule deer, coyotes, and a variety of waterfowl and raptors.

Name: El Capitan State Beach
Description: This coastal stretch along California's central coast features dramatic sandstone cliffs, a long sandy beach, and tide pools that come alive at low tide. The area offers beach access, scenic bluff trails, and backcountry coastal explorations, with picnic areas and ample ocean views. Wildlife includes harbor seals hauled out on the rocks, pelicans and other seabirds along the shore, and seasonal visits by gray whales and dolphins offshore, while the intertidal zones harbor anemones, sea stars, crabs, and other marine life.

Name: Emerald Bay State Park
Description: Emerald Bay State Park sits on the southwest shore of Lake Tahoe in the Sierra Nevada, California. It features Emerald Bay, a turquoise inlet framed by granite cliffs, the historic Vikingsholm mansion on the shore, Fannette Island, and scenic trails with panoramic lake views. Wildlife includes black bears, mule deer, ospreys, and bald eagles.

Name: Emeryville Crescent State Marine Reserve
Description: This crescent-shaped tidal marsh along the eastern edge of San Francisco Bay forms Emeryville Crescent State Marine Reserve. It protects salt marsh, eelgrass beds, mudflats, and shallow estuarine channels that support a rich estuarine ecosystem. Wildlife includes harbor seals, river otters, shorebirds, pelicans, and a diversity of fish and invertebrates.

Name: Emma Wood State Beach
Description: This coastal stretch along the Ventura County shore features a long, sandy beach backed by rolling dunes and scenic bluffs. Besides swimming and surfing, visitors enjoy picnicking, fishing from the jetty, and easy beach access along a scenic coastal route. Wildlife includes shorebirds, pelicans, dolphins offshore, and seasonal whale migrations.

Name: Empire Mine State Historic Park
Description: This historic landscape in the Sierra Nevada foothills near Grass Valley preserves one of California's oldest and most productive gold mining complexes. The park features dozens of historic buildings, restored mining structures, and a museum, with guided and self-guided tours that bring the 19th-century mining town to life. Habitats include oak woodlands and meadows that host wildlife such as deer, coyotes, hawks, and numerous songbirds.

Name: Estero Bluffs State Park
Description: Estero Bluffs State Park preserves a rugged stretch of Northern California coastline along the Pacific, just north of Fort Bragg. Cliff-top trails offer sweeping ocean views, windswept grasslands, and access to a sandy beach below. Wildlife includes seabirds and shorebirds, harbor seals, and seasonal gray whale migrations offshore.

Name: Folsom Lake State Recreation Area
Description: Folsom Lake State Recreation Area sits along the foothills east of Sacramento, surrounding the long, man-made Folsom Lake. The landscape blends oak woodlands, grasslands, and granite outcrops with a reservoir that supports boating, fishing, swimming, and a network of trails for hiking and biking. Wildlife includes mule deer, wild turkeys, and a variety of waterfowl and shorebirds that rely on lake shores and wetlands.

Name: Folsom Powerhouse State Historic Park
Description: This historic corridor along the American River preserves Folsom Powerhouse State Historic Park, a landmark among California’s earliest hydroelectric facilities. The site centers on the original powerhouse and a small museum that interprets late-19th-century electrification, the birth of the state’s power grid, and the people who powered progress. Along the river, riparian woodlands and open grasslands frame easy trails and scenic views of the historic machinery and the waterway that helped fuel California’s growth. Wildlife includes mule deer, gray squirrels, raccoons, and a variety of waterfowl and songbirds that frequent the river and shoreline.

Name: Fort Humboldt State Historic Park
Description: This coastal fort preserves a 19th-century U.S. Army outpost perched on the bluff above Humboldt Bay. The park’s restored buildings—officer quarters, barracks, and a magazine—along with a small museum tell the story of frontier military life, while short trails connect the fort to scenic overlooks and coastal and forested terrain. Wildlife includes black-tailed deer, river otters along the shore, harbor seals on rocky beaches, and a variety of raptors and seabirds, with gray whales visible offshore during migration.

Name: Fort Ord Dunes State Park
Description: Fort Ord Dunes State Park protects a wind-sculpted dune coastline along Monterey Bay, where rolling sands meet beaches, grasses, and coastal scrub. The park offers miles of beach and dune trails for hiking and biking, plus backcountry routes with expansive ocean views. Wildlife includes mule deer, coyotes, and a variety of shorebirds such as snowy plover, with seals sometimes visible offshore and raptors patrolling the skies.

Name: Fort Ross State Historic Park
Description: Fort Ross State Historic Park sits along the Sonoma County coast, guarding a windswept shoreline where a 19th-century Russian fort once stood amid Pacific views, pine and oak forests, and rugged headlands. The park offers historic structures to explore, scenic coastal trails, and seaside vantage points for observing the maritime landscape. Wildlife includes harbor seals along the rocky shoreline, gray whales offshore during migration, and deer and a variety of shorebirds that frequent the coast.

Name: Fort Tejon State Historic Park
Description: Fort Tejon State Historic Park sits in the Tejon Pass of California’s southern Sierra Nevada foothills along the I-5 corridor. The park preserves a 19th-century U.S. Army fort, with a museum and restored fortifications, and offers interpretive trails through oak woodland and chaparral. Wildlife includes mule deer, coyotes, bobcats, and a variety of birds such as red-tailed hawks and turkey vultures.

Name: Franks Tract State Recreation Area
Description: This expansive Delta waterway in California’s Central Valley comprises a mosaic of shallow seasonal lakes, tidal sloughs, and leveed channels. Franks Tract State Recreation Area offers boating, fishing, and open-water recreation amid broad horizons and marsh edge habitats. Wildlife includes largemouth bass, striped bass, catfish, and a variety of waterfowl and shorebirds that rely on the delta’s seasonal wetlands.

Name: Fremont Peak State Park
Description: Fremont Peak State Park, perched on the Santa Lucia Range above the Salinas Valley, this ridge-top park offers expansive views of the valley, Monterey Bay, and distant peaks. The landscape blends oak woodlands, pine forests, and open grasslands, with trails that wind along ridgelines and into canyons. It’s renowned for dark skies ideal for stargazing, and wildlife includes mule deer, coyotes, bobcats, hawks, and a variety of songbirds.

Name: Garrapata State Park
Description: This stretch of California's central coast along the Big Sur region preserves a rugged coastline between Carmel-by-the-Sea and Point Sur, with miles of sea cliffs and secluded coves. Garrapata State Park features dramatic bluff trails, Garrapata Creek canyons, and a mosaic of coastal scrub and wildflower meadows that frame sweeping Pacific panoramas. Wildli​fe includes harbor seals hauled out on rocky shores, a variety of seabirds, and seasonal migrations of gray whales and humpbacks offshore.

Name: Gaviota State Park
Description: This stretch of California's central coast protects a rugged coastline where the Pacific meets the Santa Ynez Mountains. Gaviota Peak offers sweeping views of the coastline and Channel Islands, with trails through coastal sage scrub and oak woodlands. Wildlife includes mule deer, gray fox, bobcats, pelicans, and a variety of shorebirds.

Name: George J Hatfield State Recreation Area
Description: George J Hatfield State Recreation Area is a scenic riverside retreat in the Pacific Northwest named in honor of George J Hatfield. The area features mixed forests, wetlands, and open meadows with scenic drives, hiking trails, and access for fishing, boating, and camping. Wildlife includes white-tailed deer, beavers, river otters, bald eagles, ospreys, and a variety of waterfowl and songbirds.

Name: Gray Whale Cove State Beach
Description: This rugged stretch of California’s central coast preserves a sheltered cove with rocky shores, a narrow sandy beach, and dramatic bluff-top views along the Pacific. Gray whales migrate offshore each winter and spring, offering the chance to glimpse whales from vantage points above the cove; seals and seabirds frequent the coastline. Tide pools, coastal scrub, and intertidal habitats support a variety of marine life, while short, family-friendly hikes and easy access along Highway 1 make it a popular spot for a quick coastal visit.

Name: Great Valley Grasslands State Park
Description: Rolling grasslands, riparian corridors, and oak savannas define the Great Valley Grasslands State Park, a patchwork of valley-floor habitats that shift with the seasons. Scenic drives and backcountry hiking opportunities reveal restored ranch lands, prairie pockets, and wetlands that host a variety of wildlife. Wildlife includes pronghorn, mule deer, coyotes, burrowing owls, and migratory waterfowl.

Name: Greenwood State Beach
Description: This windswept coastal stretch features rolling dunes, pine-fringed bluffs, and sheltered coves along a pristine shoreline, offering scenic drives, hikes, and beachcombing opportunities. Habitats include dunes, marshes, rocky intertidal zones, and offshore kelp forests, supporting harbor seals, shorebirds, sea turtles, and a diverse array of fish.

Name: Grizzly Creek Redwoods State Park
Description: This region preserves ancient coast redwoods along the Eel River, with towering trunks, mossy canyons, and a cool, damp understory blanketed in ferns. Trails wind beneath the giants through old-growth groves to river overlooks, offering picnic spots, backcountry hiking, and opportunities to spot black bears, deer, and a chorus of birds.

Name: Grover Hot Springs State Park
Description: Situated in the eastern Sierra Nevada foothills, Grover Hot Springs State Park centers on natural hot springs and two mineral pools set amid pine forests and granite outcrops. The surrounding landscape features rugged peaks, alpine meadows, and the South Fork Carson River, with trails for short strolls or longer backcountry treks. Wildlife includes mule deer, black bears, coyotes, and a variety of birds.

Name: Half Moon Bay State Beach
Description: Half Moon Bay State Beach stretches along four miles of rugged Pacific coastline in San Mateo County, comprising Francis Beach, Dunes Beach, Venice Beach, and Roosevelt Beach. The coastline features expansive sandy shores backed by rolling dunes and coastal bluffs, with picnic areas, easy beach access, and scenic views along Highway 1. Wildlife includes harbor seals hauled out on offshore rocks, migrating gray whales, and a variety of shorebirds that feed in the tidal flats.

Name: Harmony Headlands State Park
Description: This scenic stretch of the Oregon coast encompasses Harmony Headlands State Park, a rugged landscape of wind-swept bluffs, basalt headlands, and sweeping ocean views. From bluff-top overlooks and coastal forest trails to access from tide pools to beaches, the park offers dramatic seascapes and backcountry hiking opportunities. Wildlife includes gray whales offshore during migration, harbor seals hauled out on rocky ledges, a variety of shorebirds, and deer in the upland areas.

Name: Harry A Merlo State Recreation Area
Description: This hillside sanctuary in California's coastal foothills comprises a compact state recreation area featuring oak woodlands, dry-heat chaparral, and riparian canyons along seasonal streams. There are scenic hiking and biking trails, overlook viewpoints, and camping and picnicking opportunities. Wildlife includes mule deer, gray fox, coyotes, bobcats, and a diverse array of birds.

Name: Hearst San Simeon State Historical Monument
Description: This region along the Central California coast that enticed and inspired William Randolph Hearst consists of the Hearst San Simeon State Historical Monument. The crown jewel is Hearst Castle, a lavish hilltop estate with ornate rooms, sweeping terraces, and art collections that overlook the Pacific. Besides the mansion, there are scenic drives along Highway 1 and backcountry hiking opportunities in nearby coastal parks. Wildlife includes elephant seals and harbor seals on the beaches, sea otters offshore, and gray whales migrating along the coast.

Name: Hearst San Simeon State Park
Description: Along California's Central Coast, Hearst San Simeon State Park protects a rugged coastline of sea cliffs, sandy beaches, dunes, and sweeping ocean views. Tide pools and coastal scrub habitats support a variety of wildlife, including elephant seals at Piedras Blancas, harbor seals, sea lions, pelicans, and numerous shorebirds.

Name: Heber Dunes State Vehicular Recreation Area
Description: Heber Dunes State Vehicular Recreation Area sits in Utah’s high-desert Wasatch region near Heber City, offering expansive sand dunes and miles of off-highway vehicle trails. The area combines dune fields with sagebrush scrub, edge pinyon-juniper woodlands, and nearby riparian zones that support backcountry exploration. Wildlife includes mule deer, pronghorn, coyotes, jackrabbits, and a variety of raptors and songbirds.

Name: Hendy Woods State Park
Description: This quiet stand of ancient coast redwoods in northern California preserves a gallery of towering trees, moss-draped logs, and fern-filled creeks that invite slow, contemplative exploration. Hendy Woods State Park features shaded, family-friendly trails, gentle creekside slopes, and a mosaic of woodland habitats where light and fog create shifting steel-gray greens.

Name: Henry Cowell Redwoods State Park
Description: This California state park in the Santa Cruz Mountains protects a venerable stand of coast redwoods along the San Lorenzo River. Besides the towering trees, there are fern-filled canyons, creekside groves, and a network of trails—from easy loops to longer hikes through the forest and along the river. Habitats include old-growth redwood forest, riparian woodland, and oak savanna, and wildlife includes black-tailed deer, gray fox, squirrels, and a variety of birds.

Name: Henry W Coe State Park
Description: This vast backcountry park in California’s Diablo Range spans rolling ridges, deep canyons, and oak woodland canopies. Besides backcountry hiking and primitive camping, there are remote trails and sweeping views that reward solitary exploration. Wildlife includes black-tailed deer, mountain lions, bobcats, coyotes, gray foxes, and a diverse array of birds.

Name: Hollister Hills State Vehicular Recreation Area
Description: Rolling hills and oak woodlands in California's Central Coast foothills offer miles of designated dirt-bike and ATV trails that weave through grassy meadows, sandy washes, and rocky outcrops. In addition to motorized recreation, the area provides scenic overlooks and limited backcountry hiking opportunities amid blue oak woodland and chaparral.

Name: Humboldt Lagoons State Park
Description: This stretch of the northern California coast protects three lagoons—Big Lagoon, Stone Lagoon, and Freshwater Lagoon—framed by dunes, tidal marshes, and coastal forest. Visitors can hike backcountry trails, explore beaches, and paddle or kayak in the lagoons. Wildlife includes waterfowl, shorebirds, harbor seals, and other coastal creatures.

Name: Humboldt Redwoods State Park
Description: This ancient forest in northern California's Humboldt County preserves one of the world's largest contiguous stands of old-growth coast redwoods along the Eel River. Humboldt Redwoods State Park features the Avenue of the Giants, a scenic drive through towering trees, plus backcountry hiking that winds through Rockefeller Forest, Founders Grove, and fern-filled canyons. Wildlife includes black bears, deer, and a variety of birds, and the Eel River supports runs of salmon and steelhead.

Name: Hungry Valley State Vehicular Recreation Area
Description: Within the northern Mojave Desert of California, Hungry Valley State Vehicular Recreation Area encompasses a vast desert landscape of rolling dunes, scrub, and granite outcrops carved by wind and rain. Besides miles of OHV trails for dirt bikes, ATVs, and 4x4s, the area offers scenic drives and backcountry exploration opportunities, along with primitive camping under clear desert skies. Wildlife includes coyotes, jackrabbits, lizards, rattlesnakes, and a variety of raptors.

Name: Huntington State Beach
Description: Huntington State Beach spans a broad sandy coastline along the Southern California coast. Besides swimming and surfing, the beach features a popular boardwalk and the iconic Huntington Beach Pier, with a dog-friendly section for visitors and their companions. Nearby Bolsa Chica Ecological Reserve protects tidal flats and coastal wetlands that host migratory shorebirds and other wildlife, while offshore waters are home to dolphins and other marine life.

Name: Indian Grinding Rock State Historic Park
Description: Indian Grinding Rock State Historic Park, this state historic park sits in the Sierra Nevada foothills of Amador County, protecting a sacred Miwok grinding rock and a small museum devoted to Miwok culture. The surrounding landscape features oak woodlands, granite outcrops, and grassy meadows with interpretive trails and a replica Miwok village. Wildlife includes mule deer, gray fox, ground squirrels, and a variety of songbirds.

Name: Indio Hills Palms Park Property
Description: This desert sanctuary in southern California comprises three units in the Indio Hills, anchored by palm groves, irrigated washes, and rugged canyons that offer scenic drives and backcountry hiking. Wildlife includes desert bighorn sheep, coyotes, javelina, kit foxes, roadrunners, and a variety of raptors.

Name: Jack London State Historic Park
Description: This historic landscape in Sonoma Valley preserves Jack London’s Beauty Ranch and the dramatic Wolf House ruins, with the House of Happy Walls museum nearby. Rolling oak woodlands, grassy meadows, and expansive views over vineyards and surrounding hills set the scene for London’s ranching legacy. Wildlife includes white-tailed deer, gray foxes, hawks, and a variety of songbirds.

Name: Jedediah Smith Redwoods State Park
Description: Along California’s rugged north coast, Jedediah Smith Redwoods State Park protects one of the finest remaining stands of old-growth coast redwood forest along the Smith River. Towering, moss-draped trees, fern-filled understories, and steep river canyons provide dramatic scenery for hiking and scenic drives, including the popular Howland Hill Road and trails around Stout Grove and the Boy Scout Tree. Wildlife includes black-tailed deer, black bears, river otters, and a rich variety of birdlife.

Name: John B Dewitt Redwoods State Natural Reserve
Description: This coastal sanctuary along the northern California coast protects an ancient grove of coast redwoods within the John B Dewitt Redwoods State Natural Reserve. Along scenic trails, visitors pass towering trunks, moss-draped limbs, and fern-filled understories with streams weaving through the forest. Habitats include coastal redwood forest, riparian woodlands, and oak woodland, supporting black-tailed deer, gray fox, bobcats, northern spotted owls, banana slugs, and a chorus of forest birds.

Name: John Little State Natural Reserve
Description: Nestled in rolling hills, river corridors, and mixed woodlands, John Little State Natural Reserve protects a diverse landscape shaped by wetlands, prairies, and forested benches. Scenic drives and backcountry hiking opportunities invite exploration of secluded viewpoints and hidden valleys. Wildlife includes white-tailed deer, black bear, coyotes, beavers, and a rich assemblage of birds from hawks to warblers.

Name: Jug Handle State Natural Reserve
Description: This northern California coast reserve protects a mosaic of habitats—from dramatic sea cliffs and dune fields to forested uplands along the Pacific. Jug Handle State Natural Reserve offers scenic overlooks, coastal trails, and backcountry hiking opportunities, with tidepool exploration along the shoreline and access to diverse coastal ecosystems. Wildlife includes black-tailed deer, gray fox, bobcats, peregrine falcons, and a variety of shorebirds and marine life such as harbor seals.

Name: Julia Pfeiffer Burns State Park
Description: This rugged stretch of California's Central Coast preserves dramatic sea cliffs, redwood canyons, and the park's centerpiece, McWay Falls, an 80-foot waterfall that tumbles onto a sandy beach in a sheltered cove. There are short, scenic trails and viewpoints along the coast offering spectacular ocean vistas. Wildlife includes gray whales offshore during migration, sea otters, harbor seals, and a variety of seabirds.

Name: Kenneth Hahn State Recreation Area
Description: Kenneth Hahn State Recreation Area sits atop the hills of Los Angeles, offering sweeping views of the basin and distant coastline. Trail networks wind through oak woodlands and coastal sage scrub, with picnic areas, gardens, and interpretive signs along the way. Wildlife includes red-tailed hawks, quail, lizards, and other urban-adapted species, reflecting Southern California’s native habitats in the heart of a metropolitan area.

Name: Kings Beach State Recreation Area
Description: This lakeside region along Lake Tahoe's north shore in California comprises Kings Beach State Recreation Area. Kings Beach State Recreation Area features a long sandy beach, crystal-clear water, and easy access for swimming, picnicking, and family-friendly recreation with nearby trails and viewpoints. Wildlife includes waterfowl such as ducks and geese, with occasional sightings of osprey and bald eagles along the shoreline, and forest birds in the surrounding pines.

Name: Kruse Rhododendron State Natural Reserve
Description: Kruse Rhododendron State Natural Reserve, this reserve protects a high-elevation mosaic of dense rhododendron thickets, evergreen forests, and rugged cliffs. Visitors can discover mossy ravines, seasonal wildflowers, and an extensive network of backcountry trails with sweeping views. Wildlife includes black bears, white-tailed deer, foxes, wild turkeys, and a variety of resident and migratory birds.

Name: La Purisima Mission State Historic Park
Description: This storied California mission site preserves an 18th-century Spanish mission and the surrounding ranchlands that supported it, featuring a largely reconstructed adobe church, convento, grist mills, and period gardens. Trails traverse oak woodland, chaparral, and grassland on rolling hills with sweeping valley views and opportunities for living-history programs. Wildlife includes mule deer, gray fox, bobcats, coyotes, California quail, and a variety of hawks and songbirds.

Name: Lake Del Valle State Recreation Area
Description: This scenic retreat in the eastern Livermore Valley features Lake Del Valle, a large reservoir framed by rolling hills and oak woodlands. In addition to boating, fishing, camping, and lakeside hiking, visitors enjoy picnicking and scenic outings around the shore. Wildlife includes mule deer, coyotes, bobcats, red-tailed hawks, and a variety of waterfowl that frequent the lake.

Name: Lake Oroville State Recreation Area
Description: Lake Oroville State Recreation Area sits along the shores of Lake Oroville in the northern Sierra Nevada foothills of California. This recreation area comprises multiple units around the lake, offering developed campgrounds, boat launches, and day-use areas near the Oroville Dam. Besides boating, fishing, and other water recreation, there are scenic drives and backcountry hikes through oak woodlands and forested hills. Wildlife includes bald eagles and ospreys that hunt over the lake, waterfowl and shorebirds, mule deer, coyotes, and beaver along the rivers and wetland areas.

Name: Lake Perris State Recreation Area
Description: Waterfront recreation amid desert foothills, Lake Perris State Recreation Area centers on a large reservoir bordered by rolling hills, canyon scrub, and riparian corridors. The area offers boating, fishing for bass and catfish, swimming, picnicking, and miles of trails for hiking and biking along the shoreline and into the surrounding hills. Wildlife includes mule deer, coyotes, bobcats, ground squirrels, and a variety of birds—from waterfowl and herons to raptors.

Name: Lake Valley State Recreation Area
Description: This scenic region centers on Lake Valley State Recreation Area, a mosaic of forested hills, sandy beaches, and a large central lake. The area offers boating, fishing, scenic drives, and miles of hiking trails through pine and hardwood forests, plus quiet coves and wetlands. Wildlife includes bald eagles, white-tailed deer, beavers, river otters, great blue herons, and a diversity of fish and waterfowl.

Name: Leland Stanford Mansion State Historic Park
Description: Leland Stanford Mansion State Historic Park, in downtown Sacramento, this meticulously restored late-19th-century mansion preserves the home and public spaces of California's early political era, with grand public rooms, ornate interiors, and period furnishings. The park offers guided tours and exhibits that illuminate state government, architecture, and the Stanford family's influence on California history.

Name: Leo Carrillo State Park
Description: Leo Carrillo State Park, stretching along the Malibu coast, Leo Carrillo State Park preserves a rugged shoreline of sandstone cliffs, sea caves, tide pools, and 1.5 miles of beach. The park offers backcountry hiking along coastal bluffs and scenic overlooks amid coastal sage scrub and oak woodlands. Wildlife includes harbor seals and sea lions along the shore, gray whales during migration, and a variety of seabirds, with the area long used as a film location and named for actor and conservationist Leo Carrillo.

Name: Leucadia State Beach
Description: Leucadia State Beach stretches along the North County coast, where sandstone bluffs overlook a long sandy shoreline and the Pacific Ocean. The beach protects tidal pools, rocky intertidal zones, and coastal bluff habitats, with opportunities for surfing, walking, and tidepool exploration. Wildlife includes harbor seals hauled out on rocks, pelicans and shorebirds along the shore, and gray whales offshore during annual migrations.

Name: Lighthouse Field State Beach
Description: This coastal state beach near Santa Cruz spans a broad sandy shoreline with grassy bluffs and the historic Santa Cruz Lighthouse at the bluffs’ edge. Besides easy beach access, there are bluff-top trails, tide pools at low tide, and scenic overlooks along the coast. Wildlife includes harbor seals, shorebirds, pelicans, and migrating birds, with dune, bluff, and coastal scrub habitats supporting a variety of plants and animals.

Name: Limekiln State Park
Description: This rugged stretch of California's central coast preserves dramatic limestone shorelines and the historic lime kilns that gave Limekiln its name. Besides the kilns, the park features coastal scenery, creekside forests, and backcountry hiking opportunities to viewpoints, a waterfall, and the beach along Limekiln Creek. Wildlife includes harbor seals, black-tailed deer, peregrine falcons, and numerous seabirds along the coast.

Name: Little River State Beach
Description: Located along California’s rugged North Coast near the town of Mendocino, Little River State Beach protects a scenic stretch of coastline where forested bluffs meet sandy beaches and a coastal lagoon. The park features tide pools, driftwood-lined shores, and the Little River estuary, which supports diverse birdlife and aquatic species. Visitors can explore coastal trails, enjoy beachcombing and kayaking, or camp among redwood groves while experiencing sweeping ocean views and frequent coastal fog.

Name: Los Angeles State Historic Park
Description: This urban park in downtown Los Angeles preserves the city’s historic riverfront and the era of growth that shaped modern Los Angeles. Restored streets, period-era structures, and open lawns host interpretive displays and community events, inviting visitors to explore the evolving story of the region. The park offers accessible trails and gathering spaces that connect neighborhoods along the river, providing city views, cultural programs, and a sense of place.

Name: Los Osos Oaks State Natural Reserve
Description: This intimate coastal woodland refuge protects a rare stand of ancient coast live oaks along rolling hills near Morro Bay. The reserve preserves oak woodland and grassland habitats on shallow soils, where gnarled trunks, expansive canopies, and ample shade host a variety of birds, small mammals, and seasonal wildflowers. A short network of trails offers peaceful hikes and opportunities for nature study, photography, and quiet wildlife watching in a compact, accessible landscape.

Name: MacKerricher State Park
Description: Stretching along nine miles of Northern California coastline, MacKerricher State Park protects dunes, tidal lagoons, a freshwater lake at Lake Cleone, and forested bluffs. Scenic drives, dune overlooks, beach walks, and backcountry hikes reveal a habitat-rich coast with wildlife including harbor seals on the beaches, migrating gray whales offshore, and a broad array of shorebirds.

Name: Mailliard Redwoods State Natural Reserve
Description: Mailliard Redwoods State Natural Reserve preserves ancient coast redwood groves along California’s fog-kissed northern coast. Towering trunks, moss-draped limbs, and a lush understory of ferns frame creeks, wetlands, and backcountry trails that invite quiet hikes among the trees. Wildlife includes black-tailed deer, gray fox, river otters, banana slugs, and a diverse chorus of forest birds.

Name: Malakoff Diggins State Historic Park
Description: This rugged Sierra Nevada foothill landscape preserves one of the largest hydraulic mining operations from the California Gold Rush, with sprawling diggings, towering tailings, sluices, and the ruins of historic mining camps. Scenic canyons, ridges, and terraces invite backcountry hikes and interpretive trails that tell the story of how mining reshaped the landscape. Wildlife includes mule deer, gray fox, coyotes, black bears, and a variety of birds that inhabit oak woodlands and riparian zones.

Name: Malibu Creek State Park
Description: Located in the Santa Monica Mountains of Southern California, Malibu Creek State Park preserves a dramatic landscape of rolling grasslands, oak woodlands, and rugged volcanic rock formations carved by Malibu Creek. The park features scenic canyon views, the popular Rock Pool swimming hole, and miles of trails for hiking, biking, and horseback riding. Wildlife includes mule deer, coyotes, bobcats, and a wide variety of bird species, while the park’s terrain and scenery have made it a longtime location for film and television productions.

Name: Malibu Lagoon State Beach
Description: This coastal estuary and beach along the Pacific in Malibu preserves a dynamic mosaic of tidal flats, salt marsh, dune systems, and sandy shoreline. The Malibu Lagoon, fed by Malibu Creek, supports migratory and resident waterfowl, shorebirds, tidepool life, and small fish, while the surrounding coastal habitats host native plants adapted to sandy soils. The area offers birdwatching, beachcombing, hiking, and scenic views of the Pacific and Malibu Pier.

Name: Manchester State Park
Description: This coastal state park sits on a peninsula along Puget Sound in Kitsap County, Washington. The landscape features saltwater shoreline, grassy bluffs, and forested uplands with expansive views across the water to the Olympic Mountains. Wildlife includes harbor seals, river otters, bald eagles, and a variety of shorebirds.

Name: Mandalay State Beach
Description: Stretching along a sunlit Pacific coastline, Mandalay State Beach features a broad sandy shoreline, rolling dune fields, and tidal flats that cradle sheltered coves and seasonal wetlands. Visitors enjoy long walks, surfing, birdwatching, and sunset photography, while offshore waters host dolphins, seals, pelicans, and diverse fish.

Name: Manresa State Beach
Description: This stretch along California's central coast centers on Manresa State Beach, a long ribbon of sandy shoreline backed by dune fields, pine-covered bluffs, and coastal scrub. Besides beach recreation, there are scenic overlooks and short coastal trails that weave through nearby state park lands. Wildlife includes harbor seals along the rocks, migrating gray whales offshore, pelicans, oystercatchers, and tidepool life such as sea stars, anemones, and crabs.

Name: Marconi Conference Center State Historic Park
Description: Situated on coastal bluffs overlooking Tomales Bay in Northern California, Marconi Conference Center State Historic Park preserves a historic wireless communication site set amid rolling grasslands and coastal scrub. Once home to early radio pioneer Guglielmo Marconi’s transpacific receiving station, the park features historic buildings, sweeping views of bay and ocean, and open landscapes shaped by wind and fog. Wildlife includes tule elk, raptors, and migratory birds, while the park offers walking paths and interpretive opportunities highlighting the intersection of natural scenery and technological history.

Name: Marina State Beach
Description: Marina State Beach sits along the central California coast near Monterey, a long, windswept shoreline backed by rolling dunes and sweeping views of Monterey Bay. Coastal dunes, tidal flats, and adjacent marine waters support a mosaic of habitats. Wildlife includes migratory shorebirds such as the snowy plover, pelicans, and seals in the bay.

Name: Marshall Gold Discovery State Historic Park
Description: On the American River near Coloma, Marshall Gold Discovery State Historic Park preserves the 1848 gold discovery that sparked the California Gold Rush, with the Gold Discovery Museum, mining-era foundations, and interpretive trails. The landscape features oak woodlands and riparian habitats along the river, supporting wildlife such as mule deer and a variety of waterfowl.

Name: Martial Cottle Park State Recreation Area
Description: Martial Cottle Park State Recreation Area sits in southern San Jose, California, a large open-space park preserving farmland, wetlands, and rolling grasslands within an urban setting. The park offers miles of multi-use trails for hiking, biking, and horseback riding, with ponds and creeks weaving through the landscape. Wildlife includes deer, coyotes, foxes, rabbits, hawks, and a variety of waterfowl and songbirds.

Name: McArthur Burney Falls State Park
Description: Located in northeastern California near the southern Cascades, McArthur-Burney Falls State Park protects a lush landscape shaped by volcanic geology and abundant spring-fed waters. The park is centered on Burney Falls, a 129-foot waterfall renowned for its constant flow cascading through moss-covered basalt cliffs into a clear pool below. Surrounding the falls are evergreen forests, meadows, and streams that support deer, black bear, river otters, and diverse birdlife. Visitors can explore hiking trails, fish along Burney Creek, and experience cool, misty conditions year-round.

Name: McConnell State Recreation Area
Description: This river-bottom landscape along the Stanislaus River preserves a mosaic of oak woodland, riparian forest, and seasonal wetlands. The area offers levee trails, picnic areas, fishing access, and boat launches for kayaks and small craft. Wildlife includes white-tailed deer, beavers, river otters, great blue herons, ospreys, and a variety of waterfowl.

Name: McGrath State Beach
Description: This coastal California beach along the Pacific offers a long sandy shoreline, rolling dunes, and ocean vistas. Besides sun and surf, there are campground amenities nearby and ample opportunities for picnicking, birdwatching, and fishing. Wildlife includes shorebirds, harbor seals, dolphins, and seasonal whale migrations; habitats include beach, dune, and estuarine zones.

Name: Mendocino Headlands State Park
