Description: This windswept Pacific coastline along northern California comprises Mendocino Headlands State Park, a dramatic stretch of cliff-and-shoreline that frames the village of Mendocino. Rugged headlands, sea stacks, and tide pools punctuate miles of scenic coastal trails and overlook points, with access to beaches along the shore. Offshore kelp forests and rocky shores support a diverse marine ecosystem. Wildlife includes harbor seals and sea lions hauled out on offshore rocks, gray whales during seasonal migrations, and a wide array of seabirds such as pelicans, cormorants, oystercatchers, and gulls.

Name: Mendocino Woodlands State Park
Description: Along California's rugged north coast, Mendocino Woodlands State Park preserves a forested landscape of towering coast redwoods and mixed evergreen trees, threaded by creeks and open meadows that invite exploration. The area encompasses coastal woodland, riparian, and meadow habitats, supporting native wildlife such as deer, foxes, owls, hawks, and a variety of songbirds.

Name: Millerton Lake State Recreation Area
Description: This recreation area sits along a broad reservoir in the Sierra foothills, created by Friant Dam on the San Joaquin River. The area offers boating, fishing, camping, and hiking, with scenic shoreline views and varied backcountry trails. Wildlife includes mule deer, waterfowl, and a range of songbirds, with seasonal migrations bringing additional birds to the lakefront and surrounding riparian habitats.

Name: Mono Lake Tufa State Natural Reserve
Description: Mono Lake Tufa State Natural Reserve protects Mono Lake, a stark high-desert basin in the eastern Sierra Nevada famous for its dramatic limestone tufa towers rising from alkaline waters. The reserve offers scenic overlooks, backcountry hiking, and kayaking opportunities amid otherworldly tufas and rugged shorelines. Wildlife includes brine shrimp, alkali flies, and migratory birds such as California gulls and eared grebes.

Name: Montana de Oro State Park
Description: Montaña de Oro State Park sits along California's Central Coast near Morro Bay. The park features dramatic coastal bluffs, sandy beaches, and deep canyons carved into rolling hills, with miles of trails for hiking, horseback riding, and backcountry exploration. Its habitats include coastal sage scrub, oak woodland, and riparian areas, and it's home to mule deer, coyotes, harbor seals, and a variety of shorebirds and raptors; gray whales can be seen offshore during migration.

Name: Montara State Beach
Description: This scenic stretch of the Northern California coast near Montara encompasses Montara State Beach, a long, sandy shoreline backed by rugged bluffs. There are popular surfing breaks, beachcombing opportunities, and bluff-top trails with sweeping ocean views. Wildlife includes harbor seals, pelicans, and migrating gray whales along the shoreline.

Name: Monterey State Beach
Description: Stretching along the southern edge of Monterey Bay on California’s central coast, Monterey State Beach protects a wide expanse of sandy shoreline backed by coastal dunes and views of the Pacific Ocean. The beach offers open vistas of Monterey Bay, gentle surf, and accessible waterfront recreation. Shorebirds, seabirds, and marine life are commonly observed along the coast, while visitors enjoy walking, biking, beachcombing, and seasonal whale watching in a setting shaped by ocean winds and shifting sands.

Name: Monterey State Historic Park
Description: Monterey State Historic Park preserves a compact district of 19th-century adobe houses and public buildings in downtown Monterey. The park’s historic units include the Custom House and Colton Hall, centers of governance and trade from the Mexican era through California’s early statehood. Visitors can wander self-guided routes through Old Town and the waterfront, participate in living-history programs, and imagine Monterey’s bustling maritime commerce and daily life in the 19th century.

Name: Montgomery Woods State Natural Reserve
Description: Montgomery Woods State Natural Reserve protects a pristine stand of ancient coastal redwoods in northern Mendocino County. Towering trees rise above mossy trunks and fern-filled canyons along quiet, shaded trails through an old-growth forest. Wildlife includes black-tailed deer, gray fox, owls, and a chorus of forest birds.

Name: Moonlight State Beach
Description: Moonlight State Beach sits along California's Pacific coast in Encinitas, a broad stretch of sunlit sand bordered by dunes and blue water. Beyond the shoreline, the area features tide pools, scenic coastal trails, and picnic areas with panoramic ocean views. Wildlife includes harbor seals along the shore, dolphins offshore, pelicans, and shorebirds.

Name: Morro Bay State Park
Description: Situated along California's Central Coast, Morro Bay State Park protects a tidal estuary and adjacent coastal habitats anchored by Morro Rock, a volcanic plug rising from the harbor. The park includes salt marshes, dunes, and open-water habitats that host a rich community of waterfowl, shorebirds, harbor seals, and other coastal wildlife. Opportunities include hiking, birding, kayaking, camping, and a Museum of Natural History that interprets the area's geology and ecosystems.

Name: Morro Strand State Beach
Description: This coastal stretch along California's Central Coast traces Morro Strand State Beach, a long sandy shoreline backed by rolling dunes near Morro Bay. Dominating the offshore view, Morro Rock rises as a volcanic plug, guarding a coastline of open ocean, tidal flats, and dune habitats. Wildlife includes harbor seals, pelicans, and a variety of shorebirds, with gray whale migrations passing offshore along the coast.

Name: Moss Landing State Beach
Description: This coastal stretch along California's central coast features broad sandy beaches, dune fields, and nearby estuarine habitats. There are opportunities for beachcombing, fishing, surfing, kayaking, and wildlife watching. Wildlife includes harbor seals, sea otters, gray whales in migration, dolphins, pelicans, and shorebirds.

Name: Mount Diablo State Park
Description: This eastern Bay Area landmark rises to Mount Diablo’s granite summit, a dramatic peak in the Diablo Range. Mount Diablo State Park protects a mosaic of habitats—oak woodland, chaparral, grassland, and pockets of conifer stands—supporting diverse wildlife and spring wildflowers. The Summit Road and overlooks offer panoramic, 360-degree views across the Bay Area, while a network of trails provides everything from easy walks to backcountry routes. Wildlife includes mule deer, foxes, coyotes, bobcats, and a variety of birds.

Name: Mount Tamalpais State Park
Description: This coastal mountain park in Marin County features rolling ridges, oak woodlands, and pine forests with sweeping views of the San Francisco Bay and the Pacific Ocean. In addition to summit vistas and scenic overlooks, there are scenic drives and extensive backcountry hiking opportunities that traverse a mosaic of habitats. Wildlife includes mule deer, coyotes, foxes, and a diverse bird life such as hawks, falcons, and woodpeckers.

Name: Natural Bridges State Beach
Description: Along the Central California coast, Natural Bridges State Beach is renowned for its iconic natural arches carved by the Pacific, offering dramatic ocean views and a broad sandy shore. The park protects beach and dune habitats, tide pools, and seasonal monarch butterfly roosts that attract visitors each fall and winter. Visitors can enjoy easy coastal trails, tide pool explorations, and wildlife viewing along the shoreline.

Name: Navarro River Redwoods State Park
Description: Navarro River Redwoods State Park sits along California’s North Coast, protecting old-growth coast redwoods and the winding Navarro River. The park features cathedral groves, riparian woodlands, and forested canyons with easy to moderate trails and river access for quiet recreation. Wildlife includes black-tailed deer, foxes, and a variety of birds, and anadromous fish such as salmon and steelhead use the Navarro River.

Name: New Brighton State Beach
Description: New Brighton State Beach sits along the central California coast in Santa Cruz County. The park features a long sandy shoreline backed by dune fields and coastal bluffs, with a campground and day-use areas for picnicking, swimming, surfing, and tidepool exploration. Wildlife includes harbor seals, seabirds such as pelicans and shorebirds, and gray whales that migrate along the coast.

Name: Oceano Dunes State Vehicular Recreation Area
Description: This coastal dune system along California’s central coast preserves the Oceano Dunes State Vehicular Recreation Area, one of the nation’s largest expanses of coastal dunes. The area combines miles of rideable sand for off-highway recreation with broad beaches and linked dune and wetland habitats that support a variety of wildlife. Wildlife includes the western snowy plover and other shorebirds that nest and forage on the dunes, along with dune-adapted plants and small mammals.

Name: Ocotillo Wells State Vehicular Recreation Area
Description: Ocotillo Wells State Vehicular Recreation Area is a vast desert landscape in southern California, formed by dunes, washes, and rugged backcountry terrain. It offers miles of designated off-highway vehicle routes, open riding areas, and trails framed by ocotillo, creosote, and cactus. Wildlife includes coyotes, roadrunners, and lizards that thrive in this arid environment.

Name: Old Sacramento State Historic Park
Description: This district that enticed and influenced California’s Gold Rush and rail era consists of Old Sacramento State Historic Park in downtown Sacramento. Wooden sidewalks, brick storefronts, and restored 19th‑century warehouses line Front Street along the Sacramento River, preserving a living snapshot of 1850s–1870s commerce, while the California State Railroad Museum within the district houses historic locomotives and exhibits that celebrate the region’s transportation heritage.

Name: Old Town San Diego State Historic Park
Description: Old Town San Diego State Historic Park sits in downtown San Diego, preserving a 19th-century Mexican and early American town. It features restored adobe buildings, a central plaza, and living-history programs that recreate daily life from the era, with historic shops, museums, and period-appropriate architecture.

Name: Olompali State Historic Park
Description: Located in Marin County, Olompali State Historic Park preserves a Coast Miwok village site, the ruins of a 19th-century hacienda, and a mosaic of oak woodland and redwood canyon along Olompali Creek. Trails wind through grassy meadows and forested ravines, offering views of San Pablo Bay and Mount Tamalpais while interpreting a long history of Indigenous settlement and ranching. Wildlife includes deer, foxes, hawks, and a variety of songbirds.

Name: Pacheco State Park
Description: This rugged corridor in the Diablo Range preserves oak woodlands, chaparral, and grassy hills along the Pacheco Pass. It features sweeping views, seasonal wildflowers, and backcountry trails for hiking, horseback riding, and mountain biking, plus quiet campsites under starry skies. Wildlife includes mule deer, coyotes, bobcats, and a diversity of hawks, songbirds, and ground squirrels.

Name: Pacifica State Beach
Description: Pacifica State Beach sits on a broad stretch of the Northern California coast just south of San Francisco. It features a long sandy shoreline, rolling dunes, and rugged bluff headlands with tide pools at low tide. Scenic coastal drives and bluff-top hiking trails reveal wild, windswept vistas and ocean spray. Wildlife includes harbor seals and sea lions hauled out on offshore rocks, gray whales offshore during migration, and a variety of shorebirds that feed along the shoreline.

Name: Palomar Mountain State Park
Description: This high-elevation sanctuary on Palomar Mountain features dense pine and oak woodlands, rugged granite ridges, and sweeping views across San Diego County to the Pacific. Scenic drives and backcountry hiking opportunities wind through cool forests and open meadows, with excellent stargazing under some of Southern California's darkest skies. Wildlife includes mule deer, gray fox, coyotes, and a variety of birds.

Name: Sue-meg State Park
Description: This coastal-forest park spans three distinct districts along the rugged northern shore, where wind-swept cliffs meet spruce-fir forests and glacial lakes. Besides scenic drives and backcountry hiking opportunities, there are tidal pools, a historic lighthouse, and sheltered coves. Wildlife includes moose, white-tailed deer, black bear, beaver, harbor seals, and ospreys.

Name: Pelican State Beach
Description: Stretching along a sunlit coastline, Pelican State Beach protects a mosaic of dunes, salt marshes, and tidal flats that shelter coastal ecosystems and backcountry trails. The area is home to brown pelicans, shorebirds, sea turtles, and a diverse array of fish and crabs, with scenic overlooks, boardwalks, and kayaking routes.

Name: Pescadero State Beach
Description: This stretch of the Central California coast features a long, wide sandy beach backed by rolling dunes and scenic bluffs. Tide pools at low tide reveal small marine life, and nearby marshes support a variety of birds and coastal habitats. The area offers picnicking, beach access, and easy coastal walks.

Name: Petaluma Adobe State Historic Park
Description: This historic ranch near Petaluma in Sonoma County preserves a 19th-century Mexican-era adobe complex—the largest adobe in California—along the Petaluma River. The centerpiece is the adobe home and its outbuildings, with restored rooms, period tools, and demonstrations of 19th-century ranch life. Wildlife includes white-tailed deer, gray fox, red-tailed hawks, and waterfowl along the river.

Name: Picacho State Recreation Area
Description: Picacho State Recreation Area sits along the Colorado River in southeastern California, where rugged desert scenery meets broad river valleys. The landscape features rocky canyons, desert scrub, and miles of shoreline with opportunities for camping, boating, fishing, and hiking. Wildlife includes desert bighorn sheep, mule deer, coyotes, roadrunners, and a variety of waterfowl along the river.

Name: Pigeon Point Light Station State Historic Park
Description: The Pigeon Point Light Station State Historic Park preserves a dramatic segment of California’s central coastline along Highway 1, near Pescadero. The 115-foot lighthouse, built in 1871, rises above rugged sea cliffs and anchors the site with keeper’s quarters and a historic fog signal building. The park offers scenic bluff trails, tide-pool habitats, and interpretive displays about lighthouse life and maritime history. Wildlife includes harbor seals, seabirds, and seasonal gray whale migrations offshore.

Name: Pio Pico State Historic Park
Description: Southern California's Rancho-era landscape centers on the adobe home of California's last Mexican governor, Pío Pico. The site includes the preserved Pío Pico Adobe, historic gardens, and period outbuildings with interpretive exhibits on 19th-century ranch life. Visitors can take guided or self-guided tours and participate in living-history programs that bring California's Mexican era to life.

Name: Pismo State Beach
Description: This coastal region along California's central coast consists of Pismo State Beach, a broad stretch of sandy shoreline backed by rolling dunes and a nearby estuary. Besides expansive ocean views, the area offers beach access, dune trails, and wildlife viewing at the Monarch Butterfly Grove and surrounding habitats. Wildlife includes monarch butterflies, gray whales offshore, harbor seals, pelicans, and shorebirds, with beach, dune, estuary, and coastal scrub habitats.

Name: Placerita Canyon State Park
Description: Located in the foothills of the San Gabriel Mountains near Santa Clarita, Placerita Canyon State Park protects a scenic canyon with oak woodland, chaparral, and riparian habitat along Placerita Creek. The park offers hiking trails, a nature center, and access to California’s early gold-discovery history—the site of the state’s first documented gold discovery. Wildlife includes mule deer, gray fox, bobcats, coyotes, and a variety of birds.

Name: Plumas Eureka State Park
Description: This high Sierra state park preserves a historic gold-mining landscape in the Plumas-Eureka district of the northern Sierra Nevada. Within the park you’ll find preserved mining ruins, restored 19th-century cabins, and CCC-era buildings set among granite outcrops and timbered slopes, with trails linking the old town sites. Wildlife includes mule deer, gray squirrels, and a variety of birds.

Name: Point Dume State Beach
Description: Point Dume State Beach sits on a wind-carved headland along Malibu’s coast, where sandstone cliffs overlook a long sandy shoreline. The area offers dramatic ocean views, rocky coves, and scenic bluff trails that lead to overlook points and tide pools. Wildlife includes harbor seals hauled out on rocky ledges, migrating gray whales and dolphins offshore, and a variety of seabirds that patrol the coast.

Name: Ishxenta State Park
Description: Ishxenta State Park spans three rugged units in the northern highlands, protecting boreal forest, alpine lakes, and dramatic granite spires. The park offers scenic byways, backcountry hiking, and quiet viewpoints to savor its wild grandeur. Wildlife includes American black bears, moose, elk, lynx, beaver, and bald eagles.

Name: Point Lobos State Natural Reserve
Description: Point Lobos State Natural Reserve sits along the central California coast just south of Monterey and near Carmel-by-the-Sea, protecting a dramatic coastline of rocky headlands, sea cliffs, and sheltered coves. The reserve features tide pools, offshore kelp forests, and forested bluffs with Monterey pines and cypresses, plus a network of trails that reveal the marine and coastal ecosystems up close. Wildlife includes sea otters, harbor seals, California sea lions, gray whales (seasonal), dolphins, and a variety of seabirds that rely on the reserve’s rich shoreline and waters.

Name: Point Montara Light Station
Description: Perched on a windswept bluff along California's central coast, Point Montara Light Station preserves a 19th-century lighthouse complex with dramatic ocean views and accessible coastal trails within the Golden Gate National Recreation Area. The rugged coastline includes rocky shorelines, tide pools, and nearby kelp forests, providing habitat for harbor seals, sea lions, and a variety of seabirds such as gulls, cormorants, and oystercatchers.

Name: Point Mugu State Park
Description: Point Mugu State Park spans a scenic stretch of California's Pacific coastline in Ventura County, where rugged sea cliffs meet sandy beaches and the Mugu Lagoon wetlands. It protects coastal sage scrub and chaparral habitats, with tide pools, coastal canyons, and miles of hiking trails, and wildlife includes harbor seals, sea lions, dolphins, pelicans, and diverse shorebirds.

Name: Point Sal State Beach
Description: Point Sal State Beach sits on a windswept headland along California’s Central Coast. A broad sandy beach meets rugged bluffs and dune grass, with sweeping Pacific views and the offshore Channel Islands visible on clear days. Tide pools at low tide reveal small sea stars, crabs, and other intertidal life, while wildlife includes brown pelicans and oystercatchers patrolling the shore, harbor seals hauled out on rocky ledges, and seasonal gray whale migrations offshore. The area offers quiet beach access, bluff-top hikes, and opportunities for fishing and surfing, with limited facilities and parking.

Name: Point Sur State Historic Park
Description: Point Sur State Historic Park sits along California’s central coast, protecting a dramatic basalt headland crowned by a historic lighthouse built in 1889. The rugged coastline features towering cliffs, sea caves, and sweeping Pacific views, preserving a chapter of California maritime heritage. Wildlife includes harbor seals and sea lions hauled out on the rocks, migrating gray whales offshore, and a variety of seabirds such as pelicans and cormorants.

Name: Pomponio State Beach
Description: Pomponio State Beach sits along California's Central Coast, a long sandy shore within the California State Parks system. It features broad beaches, rolling dunes, and sweeping Pacific views, with tide pools to explore at low tide and nearby coastal trails for hiking and picnicking. Wildlife includes shorebirds and seabirds, with seasonal marine mammals offshore and gray whales visible during migration.

Name: Portola Redwoods State Park
Description: This stretch of California's northern coastal range protects a lush stand of coast redwoods and evergreen forests set within a network of scenic canyons and creeks. Towering trees, fern-filled understories, and moss-draped banks create a shaded, tranquil landscape with backcountry hiking opportunities along winding creek trails. Wildlife includes black-tailed deer, gray fox, raccoons, coyotes, and a variety of birds such as woodpeckers and owls.

Name: Prairie City State Vehicular Recreation Area
Description: Prairie City State Vehicular Recreation Area sits in rolling foothill country, offering expansive dirt trails, dedicated motocross facilities, and backcountry riding through oak-studded hills and grassy plains. The park provides a mix of challenge and scenery with long straightaways, tight turns, and wide-open vistas of the surrounding valley. Wildlife includes mule deer, coyotes, raptors, and a variety of ground squirrels and reptiles that thrive in this California foothill habitat.

Name: Prairie Creek Redwoods State Park
Description: Prairie Creek Redwoods State Park sits along California’s northern coast within the Redwood National and State Parks system. It protects ancient coast redwoods, fern canyons such as Fern Canyon, and miles of creeks and forested terrain along the rugged shoreline. Wildlife includes Roosevelt elk, black-tailed deer, black bears, and a diverse array of birds that flourish in the park’s old-growth forests and coastal habitats.

Name: Providence Mountains State Recreation Area
Description: This rugged desert region in the Mojave Desert centers on the Providence Mountains, featuring dramatic rock formations and deep canyons carved by wind and water. There are scenic drives and backcountry hiking opportunities that reveal sweeping views across the arid landscape. Wildlife includes desert bighorn sheep, coyotes, jackrabbits, roadrunners, and a variety of lizards and birds.

Name: Railtown 1897 State Historic Park
Description: Railtown 1897 State Historic Park sits in Jamestown, California, preserving a historic Sierra Railway roundhouse, maintenance shops, yards, and a collection of steam locomotives from the late 19th and early 20th centuries. Visitors can ride preserved steam locomotives on select days, tour the roundhouse and yards, and explore film-history displays that recall California’s railroad and Gold Rush eras. Set in the Sierra Nevada foothills, the park's surrounding oak and pine habitats support wildlife such as mule deer, gray fox, and a variety of birds.

Name: Red Rock Canyon State Park
Description: Red Rock Canyon State Park sits in California's Mojave Desert, where multicolored red sandstone cliffs, hoodoos, and dramatic canyons create a striking desert landscape. Besides scenic drives along the park's winding roads, there are backcountry hiking opportunities and climbing routes. Wildlife includes desert bighorn sheep, mule deer, coyotes, roadrunners, lizards, and a variety of birds.

Name: Refugio State Beach
Description: This coastal stretch along California’s central coast features Refugio State Beach, a long sandy strand backed by rolling dunes and rugged bluffs. In addition to swimming, picnicking, and camping nearby, visitors can hike coastal trails and watch wildlife along Refugio Creek and the dune habitats. Wildlife includes shorebirds, seabirds, and various marine life that frequent the surf, tide pools, and nearshore waters.

Name: Reynolds Wayside Campground
Description: Reynolds Wayside Campground sits amid the northern badlands, where wind-sculpted ridges and sweeping prairies stretch under big skies. This region offers easy scenic drives and backcountry hiking opportunities that reveal the land’s dramatic hoodoos and open valleys. Wildlife includes American bison, pronghorn, bighorn sheep, and wild horses.

Name: Richardson Grove State Park
Description: Richardson Grove State Park preserves a cathedral of ancient coastal redwoods along the Eel River. Ancient trunks rise in a moss-draped corridor as forest roads and trails wind through the shaded groves for scenic drives and backcountry hiking opportunities. The river and riparian habitats support wildlife such as black-tailed deer, river otters, gray fox, and a variety of birds.

Name: Rio de LA State Park State Recreation Area
Description: Rio de Los Angeles State Park sits along the Los Angeles River in downtown Los Angeles, an urban oasis of wetlands and open space. Protecting a restored riparian corridor, the park features wetlands, grasslands, and riverbank habitats, along with paved and natural surface trails for walking and biking. Wildlife includes waterfowl, wading birds, songbirds, and small mammals, with seasonal migrations drawing visitors to the wetlands.

Name: Robert H Meyer Memorial State Beach
Description: This sunlit stretch along California's coast entices visitors with long sandy beaches, grassy dunes, and dramatic ocean bluffs. The coastline offers accessible shorelines, scenic overlooks, tide pool explorations, and opportunities for swimming, strolling, biking, and beachcombing. Wildlife includes harbor seals along the shoreline, brown pelicans, ospreys, and a variety of shorebirds, with occasional gray whales and dolphins visible offshore.

Name: Robert Louis Stevenson State Park
Description: The Mayacamas foothills above Napa Valley—the landscape that captivated Robert Louis Stevenson—encompass Robert Louis Stevenson State Park. Rugged ridges, oak woodlands, and pine forests rise above deep canyons with sweeping views of the valley. There are backcountry hiking opportunities and habitats including oak woodland, conifer forest, and riparian streams, supporting wildlife such as black-tailed deer, coyotes, foxes, and a variety of birds.

Name: Robert W Crown Memorial State Beach
Description: Robert W. Crown Memorial State Beach sits along the southern shore of San Francisco Bay on Alameda Island, a long, sun-washed stretch of sand with sweeping bay views. Beyond the open beach, the dunes and tidal flats support a variety of habitats, while a paved boardwalk and picnic areas provide easy access for cycling, strolling, fishing, and family recreation. Wildlife includes harbor seals hauled out on the rocks, shorebirds such as sandpipers and plovers, brown pelicans, and a host of migratory waterfowl that help define this urban coastal ecosystem.

Name: Russian Gulch State Park
Description: Along the Mendocino Coast, Russian Gulch State Park features dramatic sea cliffs, coastal redwood groves, and a cascading creek waterfall. Scenic overlooks and a network of forest and coastal trails invite hikers and nature watchers. Wildlife includes black-tailed deer, gray fox, and a variety of seabirds.

Name: Saddleback Butte State Park
Description: Saddleback Butte State Park preserves a dramatic desert landscape in Southern California, centered on a saddle-shaped granite butte that rises above a scrubby plain of sagebrush and creosote. The park offers a climb to sweeping views across the Mojave Desert and Antelope Valley, with backcountry hiking and quiet picnic spots along shaded trails. Wildlife includes desert cottontails, jackrabbits, coyotes, lizards, and a variety of birds, while seasonal wildflowers brighten the trails in spring. Stargazers also flock to the park for some of Southern California’s clearest night skies.

Name: Salinas River State Beach
Description: This central California coast stretch along the Salinas River preserves a dynamic estuary-dune-beach landscape where the river meets the Pacific. The miles of sandy shoreline, dune fields, and tidal flats support opportunities for surfing, fishing, hiking, and birdwatching, with viewing access along bluffs and coastal trails. Wildlife includes western snowy plovers, shorebirds, pelicans, harbor seals, and sea otters, with the estuary hosting diverse fish and migratory bird communities.

Name: Salt Point State Park
Description: This coastal stretch along the Hudson River preserves rugged shoreline and maritime forests, offering dramatic river views and a sense of wild coastline. Salt Point State Park features rocky headlands, tide pools, sandy coves, and miles of trails that wind along the water’s edge. Wildlife includes ospreys, shorebirds, foxes, and river otters.

Name: Salton Sea State Recreation Area
Description: This vast inland sea in southern California sits in the Sonoran Desert, its shoreline edged by salt flats, dunes, and rugged hills. Salton Sea State Recreation Area features lakeside camping, scenic drives, boating and fishing access, and backcountry hiking along the shore and surrounding ridges. The area hosts a spectacular migration of migratory birds—pelicans, grebes, cormorants, herons, and other waterfowl—making it a premier birdwatching destination.

Name: Samuel P Taylor State Park
Description: Located in Marin County just north of San Francisco, Samuel P. Taylor State Park protects a tranquil forested valley along Lagunitas Creek at the edge of the Mount Tamalpais watershed. The park features towering coast redwoods, shaded picnic areas, and gently rolling hills that support oak woodlands and mixed evergreen forest. Lagunitas Creek provides critical habitat for coho salmon and steelhead trout, while wildlife includes deer, foxes, and a wide variety of birds. Visitors can enjoy hiking, biking along the Cross Marin Trail, and camping in a cool, creekside setting.

Name: San Bruno Mountain State Park
Description: On the northern San Francisco Peninsula, San Bruno Mountain State Park protects a mosaic of coastal scrub, grassland, and oak woodland perched above the Bay. The area is renowned for the endangered Mission blue butterfly and rich native plant communities, with lupine-dominated slopes that bloom in spring and miles of trails offering panoramic views of the city and bay.

Name: San Buenaventura State Beach
Description: Located along Ventura’s coastline, San Buenaventura State Beach offers a long, sun-kissed sandy shoreline with gentle surf and sweeping views of the Channel Islands. The area features beach, dune, and nearshore marine habitats that support a variety of wildlife. You may glimpse brown pelicans and other seabirds along the shore, seals hauled out on rocks offshore, and seasonal migrations of gray whales offshore.

Name: San Clemente State Beach
Description: This coastal stretch along Southern California’s Orange County features San Clemente State Beach, a long sandy shoreline backed by rolling dunes and rugged bluffs. There are campground and picnicking areas, easy beach access for swimming and surfing, and nearby bluff trails with ocean panoramas. Wildlife includes snowy plovers, pelicans, shorebirds, and dolphins offshore, with gray whales seen during seasonal migrations.

Name: San Elijo State Beach
Description: San Elijo State Beach sits along a sunlit stretch of the Pacific coast in northern San Diego County. The park features a long sandy beach with scenic bluffs, plus a campground and day-use areas for surfing, picnicking, and tide-pooling. Wildlife includes shorebirds, dolphins, seals and sea lions, and tide pools that cradle starfish, urchins, crabs, and anemones.

Name: San Gregorio State Beach
Description: This stretch of California’s Central Coast is San Gregorio State Beach, a windswept shoreline where golden sands meet rolling dunes and rugged blufflines. Trails along the bluffs connect to the San Gregorio Creek estuary, offering backcountry hiking, birdwatching, and seasonal surf access. Wildlife includes harbor seals hauled out on rocky ledges, gray and humpback whales offshore during migrations, snowy plovers and other shorebirds, and tidepool communities of sea stars, anemones, and crabs.

Name: San Juan Bautista State Historic Park
Description: On California's Central Coast, San Juan Bautista State Historic Park preserves Mission San Juan Bautista and the surrounding 19th‑century adobe buildings around a historic plaza. The mission church, with its tall bell tower, anchors a living history of early California, complemented by the Anza House and restored mission‑era rooms. Oak woodlands and riparian habitats along the San Juan Bautista Creek frame the site, where mule deer, hawks, and migratory songbirds roam.

Name: San Luis Reservoir State Recreation Area
Description: San Luis Reservoir State Recreation Area sits in the Central California foothills along the western San Joaquin Valley, surrounding the expansive San Luis Reservoir and the O’Neill Forebay. It offers boating, fishing, camping, and hiking along water’s edge and scenic ridges. Wildlife includes bald eagles, ospreys, waterfowl, mule deer, and coyotes, with oak woodlands, grasslands, riparian, and wetland habitats providing diverse living spaces.

Name: San Onofre State Beach
Description: This sun-warmed stretch of Southern California’s coast comprises three beach zones along the San Onofre coastline, where expansive sands meet sandstone bluffs and rolling dunes. Beyond world-class surfing at Trestles and scenic coastal trails, the area features tide pools and dune habitats that support seals and sea lions on the shore, dolphins offshore, and a variety of shorebirds along the beaches.

Name: San Pasqual Battlefield State Historic Park
Description: This battlefield site in the San Pasqual Valley near Escondido in northern San Diego County preserves the landscape of the 1846 Battle of San Pasqual. The park centers on the battlefield itself, with a visitor center and interpretive displays that tell stories of California’s early statehood and the Mexican-American War. A self-guided trail traverses the historic terrain, with scenic views of rolling hills and the surrounding coastal sage scrub and oak woodland. Wildlife includes mule deer, coyotes, gray foxes, hawks, and a variety of songbirds.

Name: San Timoteo Canyon Park Property
Description: This canyon landscape in Southern California’s Inland Empire preserves rugged sandstone walls, oak woodlands, and seasonal streams that thread through the canyon. Besides the scenic overlooks, the property offers miles of backcountry hiking and interpretive trails through native plant communities and historic ranch remnants. Wildlife includes mule deer, coyote, bobcat, gray fox, red-tailed hawk, and a variety of songbirds and ground squirrels.

Name: Santa Cruz Mission State Historic Park
Description: This historic site on California’s Central Coast preserves Mission Santa Cruz, founded in 1791 as part of Spain’s chain of missions. The park protects the mission’s adobe walls and foundations, the site of the original church, and surrounding period gardens and cemetery, with interpretive displays that bring the mission era to life. The area offers a window into early California history, featuring guided programs and self-guided tours that explore daily life of missionaries and Native communities along the coast.

Name: Santa Monica State Beach
Description: Santa Monica State Beach sits along the Pacific coast near Los Angeles, offering a long white-sand shoreline and the iconic Santa Monica Pier. A palm-lined promenade and adjacent dunes back the beach, with bike paths and parkland that invite sun, surf, and scenic coastal views. Habitats include beach, dune, and coastal bluff, supporting shorebirds and seabirds along the shore, with dolphins frequently seen offshore and marine life along the tide lines.

Name: Santa Susana Pass State Historic Park
Description: Santa Susana Pass State Historic Park preserves a historic gateway through the Santa Susana Pass, linking the San Fernando Valley with the Simi Valley. The park protects historic routes such as the Old Stage Road and surrounding cultural resources, while offering scenic canyons, oak woodlands, and sweeping valley views. Backcountry trails invite exploration of a landscape shaped by Indigenous heritage, ranching, and transportation history. Wildlife includes coyotes, mule deer, bobcats, and a variety of hawks and songbirds.

Name: Schooner Gulch State Beach
Description: Located on California's Mendocino Coast, Schooner Gulch State Beach preserves a wild, windswept shoreline with sandstone cliffs, a natural sea arch, and a long sandy cove. Rugged headlands, tide pools, and coastal scrub create dramatic scenery and opportunities for wildlife watching. Habitats include coastal bluffs, intertidal zones, and nearshore waters; wildlife commonly seen includes harbor seals, shorebirds, and migrating gray whales.

Name: Seacliff State Beach
Description: This coastal stretch along California's central coast centers on Seacliff State Beach, a long sandy shoreline backed by bluffs and home to the iconic cement ship SS Palo Alto. There are ocean views, bluff-top trails, tidepools at low tide, and picnic areas. Wildlife includes harbor seals, pelicans, cormorants, and migrating gray whales.

Name: Shasta State Historic Park
Description: This riverfront state historic park preserves the remains of a 19th‑century gold rush town along the Sacramento River. Visitors can explore a preserved Main Street with period storefronts, the courthouse ruin, and historic buildings, augmented by interpretive displays about California’s early mining era and county government. Trails along the river provide scenic overlooks and a glimpse into frontier life.

Name: Silver Strand State Beach
Description: This coastal park sits on the southern edge of San Diego Bay, linking Coronado and Imperial Beach. Silver Strand State Beach features a long, sandy shoreline along protected bay waters, dune fields, and tidal flats that support a mix of coastal habitats. The park offers swimming, sunbathing, fishing, camping nearby, and biking or strolling along the strand with views of ships in the bay and the San Diego skyline. Wildlife includes harbor seals, pelicans, ospreys, and a variety of shorebirds.

Name: Silverwood Lake State Recreation Area
Description: Silverwood Lake State Recreation Area sits in the northern San Bernardino Mountains of Southern California, centered on a large reservoir surrounded by pine and oak woodlands. The area offers boating, fishing, swimming, camping, hiking, and scenic drives along the lake and through the foothills. Wildlife includes mule deer, foxes, raccoons, and a variety of birds, while habitats encompass montane forest, riparian zones along the lake, and freshwater lake ecosystems.

Name: Sinkyone Wilderness State Park
Description: Located along California's remote Lost Coast, Sinkyone Wilderness State Park protects a wild, hike-in landscape where ancient coastal redwoods rise above rugged cliffs, beaches, and tide pools. The park preserves a mosaic of habitats—old-growth coastal redwood forest, coastal scrub, estuaries, streams, and intertidal zones. Wildlife includes black-tailed deer, black bears, mountain lions, river otters, harbor seals, and gray whales, with abundant birds such as ospreys and bald eagles.

Name: Smithe Redwoods State Natural Reserve
Description: Located in Northern California’s redwood country near the town of Trinidad, Smithe Redwoods State Natural Reserve preserves a quiet grove of ancient coast redwoods rising above a forested canyon. The reserve protects old-growth trees, lush understory vegetation, and a shaded stream environment shaped by fog and abundant rainfall. Wildlife includes banana slugs, amphibians, and forest-dwelling birds. Visitors can experience the scale and serenity of the redwood ecosystem along short trails and roadside pullouts in a setting focused on preservation and natural quiet.

Name: Sonoma Coast State Park
Description: This rugged stretch of California’s coastline comprises a linked series of units within Sonoma Coast State Park. Besides sweeping ocean vistas and dramatic cliffs, there are scenic drives along Highway 1 and backcountry hiking through dunes, coastal prairies, and windswept bluffs. Wildlife includes harbor seals and elephant seals hauled out on beaches, migrating gray whales offshore, sea otters, and a variety of seabirds.

Name: Sonoma State Historic Park
Description: This region that helped shape California history is Sonoma State Historic Park, a compact collection of four historic units in Sonoma Plaza. The park preserves Mission San Francisco Solano—the northernmost of the California missions—along with La Casa Grande, the Vallejo family’s adobe home; the Blue Wing Inn, a 19th-century hotel; and the Sonoma Barracks, a military building from the era. Visitors can stroll the plaza to step into mission life, early Californian governance, frontier hospitality, and military life that helped settle the region.

Name: South Carlsbad State Beach
Description: Situated along the northern San Diego County coastline, South Carlsbad State Beach preserves a series of coastal bluffs overlooking sandy beaches and the Pacific Ocean. The park features long stretches of shoreline, ocean-view campgrounds, and access to swimming, surfing, and beach walking. Coastal sage scrub and bluff-top vegetation support shorebirds and seabirds, while marine life is visible offshore. Visitors experience open coastal scenery, steady ocean breezes, and sweeping views that reflect Southern California’s classic beach landscape.

Name: South Yuba River State Park
Description: South Yuba River State Park protects a rugged canyon corridor along the Yuba River in the Sierra Nevada foothills of California, featuring granite cliffs, riparian woodlands, and a collection of historic mining-era bridges such as the Bridgeport Covered Bridge. The park offers scenic river viewpoints, miles of hiking and backcountry trails, and river access for swimming and picnicking, with wildlife including mule deer, foxes, and a variety of birds.

Name: Standish Hickey State Recreation Area
Description: Along the Trinity River in northern California, Standish-Hickey State Recreation Area protects a rugged canyon country of pine and oak forests and riparian habitats. The area offers scenic drives, backcountry hiking, camping, and river access for fishing and paddling. Wildlife includes black-tailed deer, river otters, osprey, bald eagles, and a variety of waterfowl and songbirds.

Name: State Indian Museum State Historic Park
Description: This region preserves Indigenous heritage and pioneers’ histories at the State Indian Museum and State Historic Park. The museum highlights ancestral cultures through artifacts, exhibits, and living-tradition demonstrations, while the historic park preserves village sites, ceremonial spaces, and period buildings. Scenic trails wind through river valleys, woodlands, and wetlands, offering backcountry walks, overlooks, and interpretive programs. The area protects archaeological and cultural landscapes, with seasonal events that bring crafts, storytelling, and history to life. Wildlife thrives in the surrounding habitats, including white-tailed deer, beaver, and a variety of birds along the river and wetlands.

Name: Stone Lake Park Property
Description: This region that entices visitors consists of a park with three distinct units encircling Stone Lake. Besides Stone Lake Park Property's historic lodge, there are scenic drives and backcountry hiking opportunities. Wildlife includes white-tailed deer, beavers, bald eagles, and wild turkeys.

Name: Sugarloaf Ridge State Park
Description: Sugarloaf Ridge State Park sits in the eastern Sonoma County foothills, centered on the granite Sugarloaf Mountain. The park preserves a mosaic of oak woodland, grassland, and chaparral with rocky outcrops, ridges, and seasonal streams. There are scenic viewpoints, a network of trails for hiking and biking, and ample backcountry opportunities. Wildlife includes mule deer, coyotes, bobcats, gray foxes, and a variety of raptors and songbirds.

Name: Sunset State Beach
Description: Sunset State Beach sits along California’s central coast, a long ribbon of sandy shoreline facing the Pacific and famed for its sunsets. The beach features expansive sands, dune systems, and coastal bluffs that create a scenic backdrop for walking, birdwatching, and tideside views. Wildlife includes harbor seals along the shoreline, shorebirds such as plovers and sandpipers, and seasonal migrations of whales and dolphins offshore.

Name: Sutter Buttes State Park
Description: This California state park protects Sutter Buttes, a ring of volcanic lava domes rising from the Central Valley. The area offers sweeping valley views, interpretive displays about the Buttes’ geologic origins, and limited backcountry hiking across grasslands and shrubland. Wildlife includes mule deer, coyotes, bobcats, raptors, and a variety of songbirds, with seasonal wildflowers brightening the slopes in spring.

Name: Tahoe State Recreation Area
Description: Tahoe State Recreation Area comprises three units along Lake Tahoe in the Sierra Nevada, where jagged granite peaks meet crystal-clear alpine lakes and pine forests. Besides scenic drives and backcountry hiking opportunities, the area offers boating, skiing, and year-round outdoor recreation around the lake. Wildlife includes American black bears, Sierra Nevada bighorn sheep, mule deer, mountain lions, and bald eagles.

Name: The Forest of Nisene Marks State Park
Description: The Forest of Nisene Marks State Park lies in the Santa Cruz Mountains east of Santa Cruz, California. It protects a vast coast redwood forest with fern-filled canyons and riparian streams winding through rugged ridges and former logging areas. There are miles of backcountry trails for hiking, mountain biking, and nature study, offering scenic overlooks and abundant wildlife, including mule deer, coyotes, foxes, bobcats, and a diverse array of birds.

Name: Thornton State Beach
Description: This coastal stretch along California's Pacific coastline protects Thornton State Beach, a long sandy shoreline backed by grassy dunes and rugged bluffs. The area features a mix of beach, dune, and coastal bluff habitats with open ocean views, tidal pools, and seasonal surf zones. Wildlife commonly includes harbor seals that haul out on the rocks, shorebirds along the tideline, and migrating gray whales offshore.

Name: Tijuana Estuary NP Point of Interest
Description: This coastal estuary at the mouth of the Tijuana River spans tidal marshes, estuarine channels, and coastal dunes along the U.S.–Mexico border. Boardwalks, a visitor center, and a network of short nature trails offer birdwatching opportunities, interpretive programs, and access to the estuary’s habitats. Wildlife includes the endangered light-footed Ridgway's rail, snowy plover, harbor seal, and brown pelican, with hundreds of bird species and seasonal gray whale activity offshore.

Name: Tolowa Dunes State Park
Description: This rugged slice of the Northern California coast protects a sweeping dune and estuary landscape where miles of beach meet marsh and coastal forest. Tolowa Dunes State Park offers scenic coastal trails, backcountry hiking opportunities, and quiet places to reflect on Tolowa heritage amid sand, wetlands, and open horizons. Wildlife includes gray whales offshore, harbor seals hauled out on the beach, river otters in the estuary, and a variety of shorebirds.

Name: Tomales Bay State Park
Description: Tomales Bay State Park sits along the sheltered Tomales Bay on Marin County’s coast. It features tidal marshes, estuary habitats, coastal bluffs, and beaches that frame the bay and nearby grasslands, with backcountry trails for hiking and kayaking along the shore. Wildlife includes harbor seals hauled out on rocky shores, river otters, and a wide array of waterfowl, shorebirds, and raptors.

Name: Topanga State Park
Description: Topanga State Park sits in the Santa Monica Mountains, where rugged canyons, oak woodlands, and coastal sage scrub meet sweeping views of the Pacific. The park protects a mosaic of habitats—from riparian streams to dry hillside chaparral—offering extensive hiking and scenic overlooks within easy reach of the Los Angeles area. Wildlife includes mule deer, gray foxes, coyotes, bobcats, and a variety of raptors and songbirds, with brilliant wildflowers blooming along the trails in season.

Name: Torrey Pines State Beach
Description: This coastal sanctuary along Southern California’s coast comprises Torrey Pines State Beach near San Diego, where towering sandstone cliffs overlook a long, sheltered shoreline. Beyond ocean views, the area protects the rare Torrey pine, endangered coastal sage scrub, and tide pools, with backcountry hikes and beach access that showcase the scenery. Wildlife includes harbor seals, peregrine falcons, gray foxes, and seasonal whale migrations.

Name: Torrey Pines State Natural Reserve
Description: This coastal sanctuary along the Pacific preserves dramatic sandstone cliffs, windswept bluffs, and the rare groves of Torrey pine. Trails wind through coastal sage scrub and chaparral to beaches, tide pools, and sweeping ocean views. Wildlife includes the iconic Torrey pine, mule deer, gray fox, and bobcats, with seabirds such as pelicans and shorebirds, and seals or sea lions that may haul out on the beaches.

Name: Trinidad State Beach
Description: This stretch of Pacific coastline near Trinidad State Beach features rugged sea cliffs, basalt formations, and miles of windswept beaches. Tide pools along the shore host sea stars, anemones, urchins, and crabs, while seals and a variety of seabirds frequent the coast. Seasonal migrations bring gray whales and dolphins offshore, and kelp forests thrive just offshore.

Name: Tule Elk State Natural Reserve
Description: This expansive grassland region in California's southern Central Valley protects a remnant herd of tule elk. Tule Elk State Natural Reserve features rolling native grasslands, scattered oak woodlands, and seasonal wetlands that support diverse plant and animal life. Wildlife includes tule elk, mule deer, coyotes, burrowing owls, golden eagles, and a variety of waterfowl and songbirds.

Name: Turlock Lake State Recreation Area
Description: This inland reservoir along the Tuolumne River protects riparian woodlands and wetlands amid rolling Central Valley foothills. Besides boating and fishing, visitors enjoy camping, picnicking, and miles of shoreline for hiking and wildlife watching. Wildlife includes white-tailed deer, waterfowl, shorebirds, and raptors.

Name: Twin Lakes State Beach
Description: Located along the northern edge of Monterey Bay in Santa Cruz, Twin Lakes State Beach protects a sheltered stretch of sandy shoreline adjacent to a tidal lagoon and harbor. The beach features gentle surf, coastal wetlands, and views of offshore kelp forests that support a variety of marine and bird life. Shorebirds, seabirds, and sea lions are commonly observed, while the calm waters make the area popular for swimming, kayaking, and beach walking. Visitors experience a blend of open ocean scenery and quiet coastal habitat shaped by tides and seasonal migration.

Name: Van Damme State Park
Description: Van Damme State Park sits along California's north-central coast, where coastal redwoods rise beside the Pacific and a tidal river winds through a forested canyon. The park features a mosaic of forest, fern-filled ravines, dune and bluff habitats, and accessible coastal beaches with miles of trails for hiking and biking. Wildlife includes black-tailed deer, gray foxes, red-tailed hawks, and river otters along the estuary and shore.

Name: Verdugo Mountains Park Property
Description: This region in the foothills of the Verdugo Mountains near the Los Angeles basin consists of a park of three units that thread through ridges and canyons. Besides sweeping city views, there are scenic trails and backcountry hiking opportunities. Wildlife includes mule deer, coyotes, bobcats, gray fox, and a variety of birds.

Name: Ward Creek Park Property
Description: Ward Creek Park Property sits along Ward Creek in a mosaic of forested uplands, riparian wetlands, and open meadows that define a river valley. Wildlife includes beaver, river otter, white-tailed deer, and bald eagles, and habitats range from riparian wetlands to upland forests and grasslands.

Name: Washoe Meadows State Park
Description: This Sierra Nevada meadow–riparian landscape protects rolling wetlands, aspen groves, and conifer forests along the southern edge of Lake Tahoe. Washoe Meadows State Park offers scenic trails for hiking and biking and easy access to backcountry experiences through meadows and forested canyons. Wildlife includes mule deer, black bears, raccoons, and a variety of birds that attract nature watchers year-round.

Name: Wassama Round House State Historic Park
Description: This cultural heritage site in the Sierra Nevada foothills preserves a traditional roundhouse and the living heritage of the local Native American communities. The Wassama Round House State Historic Park centers on the roundhouse as a ceremonial and educational hub, with interpretive displays, guided tours, and cultural demonstrations that often include storytelling and dances. The surrounding landscape features oak woodlands, pine forests, and granite outcrops with scenic views across the foothills, and wildlife such as deer, hawks, and a variety of songbirds.

Name: Watts Towers of Simon Rodia
Description: This urban sculpture complex in the Watts neighborhood of Los Angeles consists of 17 interconnected towers and a surrounding plaza. The towers, built by Italian immigrant Simon Rodia between 1921 and 1954, are adorned with mosaic tile, glass, shells, and other found objects, rising nearly 100 feet tall. It remains a powerful example of folk art and immigrant craftsmanship, preserved as a National Historic Landmark and visited for its remarkable creativity.

Name: Weaverville Joss House State Historic Park
Description: Located in northern California's Trinity County, this State Historic Park preserves the Weaverville Joss House, California's oldest Chinese temple built during the Gold Rush era. Inside, the temple features a richly decorated red interior, carved wooden beams, and ancestral altars, with interpretive displays that illuminate the lives of Chinese miners and immigrants who built and used the temple as a center of worship and community. A nearby herb shop building and modest museum round out the experience, offering a window into 19th-century immigrant life in Weaverville.

Name: Westport Union Landing State Beach
Description: This coastal stretch along the Northern California coast near Westport comprises Westport Union Landing State Beach, a long shoreline backed by dunes and rugged headlands. It features wide beaches with tide pools and bluff overlooks ideal for scenic viewing, beachcombing, and coastal walks. Wildlife includes harbor seals hauled out on rocks, gray whales offshore during migration, sea otters in nearby kelp forests, and a variety of shorebirds and seabirds. Habitats include beach, dune, coastal bluff, and nearshore marine and intertidal zones.

Name: Wilder Ranch State Park
Description: Wilder Ranch State Park sits along the Pacific coast near Santa Cruz. It preserves a historic 19th‑century cattle ranch, with rolling coastal grasslands, oak woodlands, and riparian canyons that thread a network of trails. Scenic bluffs overlook Monterey Bay, and trails are popular for hiking, biking, and horseback riding, connecting with the California Coastal Trail. Wildlife includes mule deer, gray fox, coyotes, ground squirrels, and a variety of seabirds and shorebirds that frequent the coastal habitat.

Name: Wildwood Canyon Park Property
Description: Wildwood Canyon Park Property spans a rugged canyon landscape in the Wildwood region, consisting of three canyons—North, Central, and South—that carve through cedar and oak woodlands above desert scrub. Besides a preserved historic lodge, there are scenic drives along the canyon rim and backcountry hiking opportunities. Wildlife includes mule deer, coyotes, bobcats, foxes, and a broad array of hawks, owls, and songbirds.

Name: Will Rogers State Beach
Description: This coastal recreation area along the Pacific in southern California preserves Will Rogers State Beach and the surrounding foothills of the Santa Monica Mountains. The site features a long sandy shoreline, ocean vistas, and the historic Will Rogers State Park ranch house with trails for hiking and horseback riding. Wildlife includes brown pelicans and other shorebirds along the coast, harbor seals along the shore, and small mammals in the upland chaparral and coastal sage scrub.

Name: Will Rogers State Historic Park
Description: This hillside preserve in the Santa Monica Mountains preserves the Will Rogers House and Ranch, the former home of the beloved American actor and humorist. The site features the historic house, a polo field, and a network of trails that wind through oaks, coastal sage scrub, and chaparral with panoramic views of the Pacific. Wildlife includes mule deer, gray foxes, coyotes, and a variety of raptors and songbirds.

Name: Woodland Opera House State Historic Park
Description: Nestled in downtown Woodland, California, Woodland Opera House State Historic Park preserves a late-19th-century theatre that has long served as the cultural heart of the community. Inside, the restored proscenium stage, decorative plaster, and period furnishings offer a window into the town's vibrant performing-arts heritage. Set amid the Central Valley's farmland and historic storefronts, the park hosts tours, exhibits, and live performances that celebrate California's civic and entertainment history.

Name: Woodson Bridge State Recreation Area
Description: Woodson Bridge State Recreation Area sits along the Sacramento River near Red Bluff, California, spanning riverine woodlands and expansive water views beneath the iconic Woodson Bridge. The recreation area offers river access for fishing and boating, as well as short trails, picnic sites, and camping opportunities. Wildlife includes osprey and bald eagles along the river, river otters and beavers, and a diverse array of waterfowl and riparian birds.

Name: Zmudowski State Beach
Description: Zmudowski State Beach sits along California's central coast near Moss Landing, preserving a long sandy shoreline backed by dunes and tidal flats. The area features dune and estuarine habitats with ocean views and opportunities for beachcombing, birding, and coastal walks. Wildlife includes Western snowy plover, shorebirds, and harbor seals.

Name: Mount San Jacinto State Park
Description: This high-elevation escape in the San Jacinto Mountains overlooks the Palm Springs area, featuring granite peaks, pine forests, and blooming meadows that frame sweeping desert-to-sky views. The park offers year-round hiking, scenic trails, and access via the Palm Springs Aerial Tramway to alpine terrain and backcountry routes. Wildlife includes bighorn sheep, mule deer, and a variety of birds.

Name: Point Sal State Beach
Description: Point Sal State Beach comprises a windswept, sandy coastline backed by tall dunes and rugged coastal bluffs along California’s central coast. The area preserves dune and coastal sage scrub habitats, with intertidal zones and offshore kelp forests supporting a diversity of marine life. Wildlife includes harbor seals and sea lions hauled out on beaches and rocks, gray whales off the point during migration, pelicans and cormorants along the shore, and a variety of shorebirds and tidepool creatures.

Name: Kenneth Hahn State Recreation Area - Baldwin Hills Scenic Overlook
Description: Rising above the urban landscape of Los Angeles, Kenneth Hahn State Recreation Area and the Baldwin Hills Scenic Overlook protect a prominent ridgeline of grasslands, coastal scrub, and restored wetlands. The area features panoramic views of the Los Angeles Basin, downtown skyline, Santa Monica Mountains, and, on clear days, the Pacific Ocean. A network of trails and stairways provides opportunities for hiking, fitness walking, and wildlife observation. Native plants support birds, butterflies, and small mammals, offering a rare open-space refuge where natural habitats and sweeping vistas meet the city below.

Name: Long Beach Marine Stadium
Description: Located along the coast of Southern California in the city of Long Beach, Long Beach Marine Stadium preserves a protected saltwater lagoon originally engineered for aquatic sports and coastal recreation. The stadium features calm waters bordered by beaches, grassy parkland, and views toward the Pacific Ocean. It supports rowing, kayaking, sailing, and swimming, while also providing habitat for shorebirds, waterfowl, and marine species adapted to the lagoon environment. Visitors experience a blend of open water, coastal breezes, and urban shoreline in a setting shaped by both natural processes and human design.

Name: Eastern Kern County Onyx Ranch State Vehicular Recreation Area
Description: Eastern Kern County Onyx Ranch State Vehicular Recreation Area sits in the eastern Mojave Desert, where rolling badlands, sandstone canyons, and wide, open flats create a rugged desert landscape. It offers miles of designated OHV trails, dunes, and backcountry routes for dirt bikes, ATVs, and 4x4 vehicles, with scenic drives and opportunities to explore remote deserts. Wildlife includes desert bighorn sheep, coyotes, roadrunners, and a variety of lizards and raptors.

Name: Locke Boarding House Museum Point of Interest
Description: This historic Locke Boarding House Museum preserves the daily life of travelers and town residents from the 19th and early 20th centuries. The house features restored guest rooms, a kitchen, and the original parlor, with exhibits on hospitality, domestic life, and local commerce. Guided tours, archival collections, and living-history programs bring the era to life, while the surrounding streetscape and garden offer a tangible sense of the town's heritage.

Name: Santa Ines Mission Mill
Description: Nestled in the Santa Ynez Valley, Santa Ines Mission Mill National Park preserves an 18th-century mission complex connected by a historic water-powered mill. The site offers scenic drives and backcountry hiking, with demonstrations of mission life amid adobe walls, terraced gardens, and shaded plazas. Habitats include chaparral, oak woodland, and riparian canyons, with cultivated vineyards and orchards nearby; wildlife includes mule deer, gray fox, coyotes, red-tailed hawks, and a variety of songbirds.

Name: Heilbron Mansion
Description: This heritage landscape around Heilbron Mansion comprises a three-part estate—the Main House, the Formal Gardens, and the Service Wing—preserved as a cultural park. Besides the mansion's historic interiors, there are carriage trails, restored fountains, and seasonal exhibits. Wildlife includes white-tailed deer, red foxes, eastern gray squirrels, and a chorus of birds that visit the grounds.

Name: Dos Rios
Description: Dos Rios National Park spans a mosaic of river valleys and rugged canyons where two rivers converge to sculpt basalt mesas and forested rims. Scenic drives traverse dramatic overlooks, and backcountry trails wind through cottonwood riparian corridors, pinyon-juniper woodlands, and alpine meadows. Wildlife includes mule deer, elk, black bears, mountain lions, beavers, river otters, and a diverse array of birds.

Name: El Presidio de Santa Barbara State Historic Park
Description: El Presidio de Santa Barbara State Historic Park preserves the original 18th‑century Spanish fort that guarded the early town of Santa Barbara. The site features reconstructed adobe walls, a guardhouse, and a small museum with interpretive exhibits about frontier life and the mission era. Located beside downtown Santa Barbara, the park offers easy strolls through historic courtyards with views of the harbor and surrounding hills.

Name: Governor's Mansion State Historic Park
Description: This historic estate in downtown Sacramento preserves the California Governor’s Mansion, a late-19th-century residence that has housed California’s chief executives for generations. The property features formal gardens and carriage drives set within a landscape that reflects the era of state government life. Inside, restored rooms and period furnishings illustrate daily life and governance during California’s early statehood, with guided tours and living-history programs available. The surrounding capitol district landscape includes mature trees and city views, offering a tranquil counterpoint to the urban setting. Wildlife is typical of an urban park, including resident birds and small wildlife that frequent the grounds.

Name: Los Encinos State Historic Park
Description: Located in the central highlands of Mexico, Los Encinos State Historic Park preserves a 19th-century hacienda set among a spring-fed chain of ponds, landscaped gardens, and encino oak woodlands. Besides the historic buildings, the park offers shaded trails, serene waterways, and interpretive displays that reveal the region’s cultural and natural heritage. Wildlife includes a variety of birds, small mammals, and reptiles that thrive in the park’s wetlands and woodlands.

Name: Point Cabrillo Light Station State Historic Park
Description: This windswept headland along the Mendocino coast preserves a 1909 lighthouse, the fog signal building, and keeper’s cottages. The site includes a small museum and public trails offering dramatic ocean views, rocky shoreline, and tide pools. Wildlife includes harbor seals and seabirds along the coast, with gray whales visible offshore during migration.

Name: Sutter’s Fort State Historic Park
Description: This state historic park in California preserves the 19th-century fort founded by John Sutter along the American River in Sacramento. The site features restored adobe and brick buildings, a blacksmith shop, kitchens, a garden, and period rooms that reveal life on the frontier during the 1840s. Exhibits tell the story of California’s Gold Rush era, early statehood, and the Indigenous Miwok people who inhabited the region. The park offers guided tours and living-history programs that bring to life Sutter’s Fort and its pivotal role in California history.

Name: William B. Ide Adobe State Historic Park
Description: This frontier landscape in California’s Central Valley preserves the adobe home of William B. Ide, a Bear Flag Revolt leader whose early life helped shape the state. William B. Ide Adobe State Historic Park features the restored adobe, a small museum with interpretive displays, and gentle trails that wind through oak woodland and riparian habitat. Wildlife includes mule deer, squirrels, and a variety of songbirds and raptors common to valley ecosystems. Visitors can enjoy self-guided tours, living history programs, and picnicking amid a setting that celebrates California history and natural beauty.

Name: Tomo-Kahni State Historic Park
Description: The Mojave Desert landscape of Tomo-Kahni State Historic Park sits in California’s arid southwestern high desert. It protects a well-preserved Paiute village site alongside extensive petroglyph panels carved into canyon walls. Rugged canyons, desert scrub, and sweeping overlook views frame guided hikes and cultural programs, with wildlife including desert bighorn sheep, mule deer, coyotes, lizards, and a variety of birds.

Name: Marsh Creek State Park
Description: Marsh Creek State Park sits along a broad reservoir in southeastern Pennsylvania, surrounded by woodlands, wetlands, and rolling meadows. The park offers boating and fishing on the lake, swimming, hiking and biking on scenic trails, and plentiful picnic spots along the shoreline. Wildlife includes white-tailed deer, beavers, red-tailed hawks, great blue herons, and a variety of waterfowl.

Name: Pfeiffer Big Sur State Park
Description: This stretch of California’s central coast preserves a mosaic of coastal redwood forest, oak woodlands, and riparian canyons along the Big Sur River. Pfeiffer Falls and a network of forest trails wind through towering redwoods and fern-filled ravines, offering vistas of the dramatic Pacific coastline. Wildlife includes mule deer, gray fox, and a variety of birds that inhabit the park’s mixed habitats.
